instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Meet our protagonist, John, a hard-working banker devoured by the relentless pace of New York.
2) His dream of an alleviating break is manifested in the form of a long-awaited trip to the charming city of Paris.
3) His artistic cousin, Ava, resides there, painting her days towards success.
4) His plane lands smoothly at Charles de Gaulle Airport, where he is welcomed with warmth by the radiant Ava and her eccentric Parisian roommate, Lily.
5) Lily's effortless charm, abundant energy, and unparalleled zest for life fascinate John from the very first encounter.
6) Struck by enchantment, John often finds himself lost for words in Lily's presence.
7) The task of articulating his sudden affection turns into a peculiar struggle he hadn’t been prepared for.
8) In the meantime, Ava, completely oblivious of this nascent romance, humorously tries to pair off John with her colorfully diverse circle of friends.
9) However, Ava’s innocent meddling brings about a chain of laugh-out-loud moments and potently awkward situations, turning John's attempts to confess his affection into a series of regrettable blunders.
10) Despite the numerous obstacles, John is valiantly determined to win Lily's heart.
11) His journey spirals into a whirlwind of hilarious capers and absurdities, burlesquely magnified by the French setting.
12) In a humorous endeavor, he finds himself in a chaotic situation of becoming a reluctant participant in a disgruntled mime's performance at the renowned Café de Flore.
13) In another misadventure, he unintentionally offends a dignified French chef at the prominent restaurant, Le Meurice.
14) An innocently misplaced critique of Escargot soon escalates into a theatrical fiasco.
15) The art enthusiast in John leads him to the Louvre, where he gets lost among the captivating, history-infused corridors.
16) This promptly triggers a comedy of errors that leaves visitors and tour guides agape.
17) Amidst the mirthful chaos, Lily's fondness for the diffident yet captivating John grows.
18) His endearing personality and heartwarming clumsiness tug at her heartstrings, making her slowly fall for him.
19) Their relationship engenders several raw and heartfelt encounters that sensitively enforce a deep connection, paving a path into an unexpected romance.
20) After an emotional journey, John musters enough courage to divulge his feelings for Lily.
21) However, his declaration is preempted by devastatingly ill-timed intervention.
22) Lily's ex-boyfriend, Pierre, an impeccably polished Frenchman, makes an unexpected return.
23) His entry sends unforeseeable shockwaves through John's hopeful plan.
24) Lily, unaware of John's deep feelings, neutrally distances herself from him.
25) She erroneously assumes John’s affection towards Ava’s friends, a misunderstanding engineered unintentionally by Ava's constant setups.
26) Disillusioned and heartbroken, John decides to escape the emotional cyclone stirring within him.
27) He disguises his sorrow with practiced humor and impulsively decides to cut short his Parisian endeavor.
28) He books a rushed flight back to New York, abandoning his hopes and dreams of a love-filled Parisian adventure.
29) Ava stumbles upon a heartfelt letter John had penned for Lily but never delivered.
30) The unsent letter reveals the depth of his feelings, along with Ava's accidental hand in John's heartache.
31) Ava, confronted by the colossal misunderstanding, implores John to confess his love before abandoning it entirely, forcing the disheartened lover into a frenzy.
32) Carmaggedon ensues as a frantic John chases time through the labyrinth of the narrow, winding streets of Paris in his rented Peugeot.
33) Witnessing an opportunistically available hot air balloon, he quickly ascends into the Parisian skyline.
34) With a love-powered courage, John throws caution to the wind.
35) In a fervent act of desperation, he shouts his love for Lily across the picturesque Parisian panorama, announcing his suppressed emotions into the open world.
36) Lily fortuitously hears this dramatic display of affection and is profoundly touched.
37) John's declaration resonates deeply within her, inciting a rush of emotions she couldn't possibly ignore.
38) Excited yet fearful, she makes her way to the airport, with the desperate desire to meet John before he departs, etching a potentially tragic end to their affectionate escapades.
39) As Lily's dramatic arrival unfurls with the Eiffel Tower standing benignly in the background, John finds himself at the verge of his return flight.
40) Caught off-guard, John stands frozen as Lily expresses her reciprocated feelings in front of the bustling terminal crowd, epitomizing their moment with a passionate farewell kiss.
41) Lily vows to follow John back to New York, bidding her lover a temporary goodbye at the brink of his departure, imbuing the airport scene with a palpable romantic tension.
42) Back to his mundane job in New York, the resilient John re-enters his old life with a heart brimming with Parisian memories.
43) His monotonous routine is abruptly disrupted by a delightful surprise.
44) Lily, true to her word, strides into John's Wall Street office.
45) Her entrance rekindles their adventurous romance, promising an exciting continuation of their love story, which seems to have just begun.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

Ground Truth Turning Points:
- Opportunity (tp1): 6.0 - Introductory event that occurs after presenting the setting and background of the main characters.
- Change of Plans (tp2): 10.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 20.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 24.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 35.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:
### TASK COMPLETION

1. **Protagonist identification:** The protagonist in the story is John, a hard-working banker.

2. **First turning point (Opportunity, tp1):** At sentence 6: "Struck by enchantment, John often finds himself lost for words in Lily's presence."
   - **Protagonist's state:** John is smitten by Lily and feels enchantment but struggles to express himself.
   - **Protagonist's condition:** 6

3. **Second turning point (Change of Plans, tp2):** At sentence 10: "Despite the numerous obstacles, John is valiantly determined to win Lily's heart."
   - **Change relative to the first turning point:** John becomes more determined to win Lily's heart, indicating a rise in his emotional state and resolve.
   - **Protagonist's condition:** 7

4. **Third turning point (Point of No Return, tp3):** At sentence 20: "After an emotional journey, John musters enough courage to divulge his feelings for Lily."
   - **Change relative to the second turning point:** John gains courage to express his feelings, showing an improvement in his emotional state.
   - **Protagonist's condition:** 8

5. **Fourth turning point (Major Setback, tp4):** At sentence 24: "Lily, unaware of John's deep feelings, neutrally distances herself from him."
   - **Change relative to the third turning point:** John faces a setback as Lily distances herself, indicating a decline in his emotional state.
   - **Protagonist's condition:** 4

6. **Fifth turning point (Climax, tp5):** At sentence 35: "In a fervent act of desperation, he shouts his love for Lily across the picturesque Parisian panorama, announcing his suppressed emotions into the open world."
   - **Change relative to the fourth turning point:** John takes a bold action and expresses his love, leading to a significant improvement in his emotional state.
   - **Protagonist's condition:** 10

7. **Protagonist's condition list:** [6, 7, 8, 4, 10]

8. **Story arc classification:** The story arc type is **Cinderella**. This classification is based on the protagonist's condition list, which shows an initial rise (from 6 to 8), followed by a significant setback (from 8 to 4), and ultimately achieving a higher state (from 4 to 10) than at the beginning. This pattern is characteristic of the Cinderella story arc.

9. **Determined story arc type:** Cinderella

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) John Travers, a battle-hardened journalist formerly employed by The New York Times, grapples with the burdensome weight of financial hardship.
2) The unanticipated downswing of the market instantly erodes his entire life savings, propelling him into a pit of looming credit card bills and burgeoning mortgage obligations.
3) He stumbles upon a dilapidated barn housing a hidden gem – a weather-beaten stack of photos chronicling a 1959 Ferrari 250 GT in its prime.
4) The classic car, worth millions in the collectors' world, belongs to Mrs. Reid, an elderly woman of fading recollection and uncomplicated demeanor, who lives tranquilly with her only daughter, Gwen.
5) Stricken with desperation, John hatches a grand plan to secure the priceless automobile.
6) He initiates a rapport with Gwen Reid, a compassionate woman in her mid-thirties entirely dedicated to caring for her ailing mother.
7) John introduces himself to Gwen as an out-of-work reporter facing financial hardship, and volunteers to help with domestic duties.
8) As he delves deeper into Gwen’s world, John begins to appreciate the earnestness of her existence.
9) Gwen and John unknowingly create a unique bond of mutual respect and affection.
10) One night, unable to resist the material allure of the Ferrari, John attempts to acquire the classic car, but his conscience makes him abandon his plan midway.
11) He leaves the Reid household without an explanation.
12) Struggling with John's inexplicable disappearance, Gwen discovers his initial intentions, leaving her feeling profoundly betrayed.
13) Yet, upon uncovering that John had ultimately abandoned his plan to steal the car, Gwen is overwhelmed with a complex mix of sympathy towards his plight and disappointment in his deception.
14) Gwen rationalizes John's actions, attributing them less to malign intent and more to desperate circumstances.
15) With forgiveness, Gwen decides to auction the invaluable 1959 Ferrari 250 GT with the local automobile collector’s association and plans to pass on the proceeds to John.
16) Gwen finally locates John, surviving amidst squalid conditions in a shabby, low-rent flat in Brooklyn.
17) She shows up unannounced at John’s doorstep, presenting him with a check bearing the substantial amount raised through the sale of the Ferrari.
18) As he processes the circumstances leading to Gwen's unexpected arrival, a tearful reunion ensues, with heartfelt confessions of love and remorse.
19) John consents to Gwen's persuasion of returning to the Reid household.

- Point of No Return (tp3): 10.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.

- Climax (tp5): 17.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:
### TASK SOLUTION

1. The protagonist in the story is John Travers, a battle-hardened journalist.

2. At the sentence indicated by the first turning point (Opportunity), the sentence is:
"He stumbles upon a dilapidated barn housing a hidden gem – a weather-beaten stack of photos chronicling a 1959 Ferrari 250 GT in its prime."
The protagonist's state at this point is one of discovery and potential opportunity. His financial situation is still dire, but he has found something that could possibly change his circumstances. Approximate condition: 2

3. The second turning point is Change of Plans, and the corresponding sentence is:

The protagonist's state has changed relative to the first turning point in that he now has a plan to improve his financial situation. However, his desperation and willingness to potentially deceive others to achieve his goal suggest that his condition is still relatively low. Approximate condition: 3

4. The third turning point is Point of No Return, and the corresponding sentence is:

The protagonist's state has changed relative to the second turning point in that he has now taken concrete action to achieve his goal, but his conscience has also gotten in the way, suggesting that he is not entirely comfortable with his actions. This inner conflict suggests that his condition is still relatively low. Approximate condition: 4

5. The fourth turning point is Major Setback, and the corresponding sentence is:
"Struggling with John's inexplicable disappearance, Gwen discovers his initial intentions, leaving her feeling profoundly betrayed."
The protagonist's state has changed relative to the third turning point in that his actions have now had negative consequences, causing harm to someone he cares about. This setback suggests that his condition is now lower than before. Approximate condition: 1

6. The fifth turning point is Climax, and the corresponding sentence is:
"She shows up unannounced at John’s doorstep, presenting him with a check bearing the substantial amount raised through the sale of the Ferrari."
The protagonist's state has changed relative to the fourth turning point in that he has now been forgiven and has received a significant benefit from Gwen's actions. This suggests that his condition is now much improved. Approximate condition: 10

7. The list of protagonist's conditions in chronological order is:

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) A family home is raided by an armed gang of thieves in the middle of the night.
2) Brothers Jake and Duncan are saved by Lester.
3) They are devastated to find their parents shot dead and watch helplessly as their house burns to the ground.
4) Years later, the Dalton gang meets up with Jake, who is working in a saloon.
5) After losing one of their members in a gun fight, the gang realizes they will not have enough manpower for their upcoming train heist.
6) At the objection of his older brother Duncan, Jake volunteers and the gang is forced to use him as a substitute.
7) The gang successfully pulls off the train heist, but instead of gold, the chest they steal reveals a young woman inside named Pearl.
8) She claims she was taken from her home in Potemkin.
9) She also claims there would be a handsome reward for the gang if they return her home.
10) Duncan is wounded by a Pinkerton's bullet.
11) The gang travel to Potemkin with Pearl and arrive at the town brothel in order to get help for Duncan, who is slowly dying.
12) The gang is welcomed by Maria, the leader of the brothel.
13) They drink and partake in the pleasures of the town-women.
14) Maria sits Jake down and shows him her past, where she was burned at the stake as a witch while pregnant with Pearl.
15) The women transform into their true selves, hideous burnt witches and attack the gang, some of which are killed off.
16) The remaining survivors fall back to a cabin to strategize an escape.
17) Maria gathers her fellow witches and reveals that Jake is the one who can sustain them for many more years, as he's "innocent blood", having never taken a life and is a virgin.
18) Jake and Dodd go back to the brothel to find Duncan, but he's not there.
19) They rendezvous with the rest of the group and fight their way to a church.
20) In a hallucinatory state, Wylie eats some broken glass.
21) Lester reveals to Jake that the reason his family was killed was because they were thieves, and they stole the farm they lived on.
22) Later, Jake goes outside and finds Duncan apparently healed.
23) But Dodd shoots him and he morphs into a flock of crows.
24) Lester starts convulsing and vomiting a black liquid, and a black crow crawls out of his mouth, killing him.
25) Wylie is found having cut himself all over with broken glass and is cutting out his eyes.
26) He then slashes his own throat and dies.
27) Dodd and Jake leave the church to escape but are ambushed and fall back to the town.
28) Dodd takes on the witches and is killed while Jake moves forward.
29) He comes upon Maria and Pearl, who offer Duncan's life in exchange for Jake.
30) He takes the deal and Duncan rides off, eventually buying back his family's old farm and having a child of his own, named Jacob.
31) A black crow sits ominously on their balcony as the sun sets.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

Ground Truth Turning Points:
- Opportunity (tp1): 7.0 - Introductory event that occurs after presenting the setting and background of the main characters.
- Change of Plans (tp2): 11.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 17.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 27.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 30.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:
### TASK RESPONSE

1.  The protagonist in the story is Jake.

2.  The first turning point is at sentence 7: "The gang successfully pulls off the train heist, but instead of gold, the chest they steal reveals a young woman inside named Pearl." At this point, Jake's state is relatively good. He has just successfully participated in a heist and found a woman who might bring them a reward. His condition can be approximated as a 7.

3.  The second turning point is at sentence 11: "The gang travel to Potemkin with Pearl and arrive at the town brothel in order to get help for Duncan, who is slowly dying." Relative to the first turning point, Jake's situation has become more complicated. His brother is dying, and they are in a new, potentially dangerous town. However, they are also seeking help and have a goal to return Pearl for a reward, so his condition hasn't drastically worsened. It can be approximated as a 6.

4.  The third turning point is at sentence 17: "Maria gathers her fellow witches and reveals that Jake is the one who can sustain them for many more years, as he's 'innocent blood', having never taken a life and is a virgin." Relative to the second turning point, Jake's situation has significantly worsened. He has just discovered that he is the target of a group of witches who want to use him for their own survival. His condition can be approximated as a 2.

5.  The fourth turning point is at sentence 27: "Dodd and Jake leave the church to escape but are ambushed and fall back to the town." Relative to the third turning point, Jake's situation has continued to deteriorate. He and his companion are under attack and have been forced to retreat. His condition can be approximated as a 1.

6.  The fifth turning point is at sentence 30: "He takes the deal and Duncan rides off, eventually buying back his family's old farm and having a child of his own, named Jacob." Relative to the fourth turning point, Jake's situation has somewhat improved in the sense that his brother is saved, but at the cost of his own freedom and potentially his life. However, considering the ultimate outcome for Jake implied by the ominous ending, his condition can be approximated as a 0.

7.  The list of protagonist's condition in chronological order is: 7, 6, 2, 1, 0.

8.  Based on the protagonist's condition list, the story arc can be classified as "Riches to Rags" because Jake starts in a relatively good situation after the first turning point and gradually worsens until the end, where he is in the worst possible condition.

9.  **Riches to Rags**

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) In 1940 Alice Lamb, who is working on her typewriter, lives in a cottage by the seaside in Kent.
2) She has lived in the village since before the start of WWII, during which time she tolerated the harassment by local children who thought she was a witch because she was a loner.
3) As part of the war effort, the brusque and reclusive writer is entrusted with the care of a young boy, Frank, who has been evacuated from London where it is unsafe.
4) Alice had not volunteered to be a host and does not want to care for him as she fears it will interfere with her work researching mythology and folklore, but reluctantly agrees to let him stay believing that he has nowhere else to go and she will be able to be rid of him in a week.
5) As she begins to accept Frank's presence, she recalls her relationship with Vera, a fellow student at university who wanted to be a novelist and with whom she fell in love.
6) Vera breaks Alice's heart when she decides to end their relationship not because it was considered taboo, but because she has a strong desire to be a mother and it would not be possible with Alice.
7) Alice and Frank start to bond after he takes an interest in her scholarly work and she explains Fata Morgana mirages to him.
8) She tells him about The Summerland, the pagan idea of the afterlife that existed all around them.
9) However, at the end of their week together she is still willing to let him be transferred to another home.
10) Alice changes her mind and decides to keep Frank with her after learning that moving him to a new family will require his moving to another village and school.
11) The day before Frank's birthday Alice is informed that his father has been killed in battle and she must break the news to him.
12) As she was devastated by the similar loss of her own father, Alice decides to delay telling Frank.
13) While preparing a permanent room for him to stay in, she finds photographs of Frank and his parents in his scrapbook and is shocked to discover that his mother is Vera.
14) At the same time, during an argument with a school friend, Frank finds out that his father had died.
15) Hurt and angry because Alice had not told him, Frank runs away to be with his mother in London.
16) Alice goes after him, and the two arrive in time to find his home destroyed and in flames after a bombing.
17) Alice and Frank spend the night in an air raid shelter and head back to Kent the following morning.
18) While driving back to Kent, Frank yells at Alice to stop, jumps out and runs to the sea.
19) Alice follows him onto the rocks, pleading with him that it is not safe and to come back.
20) Frank shouts at her that she knew about his father's death and did not tell him.
21) Distraught, Alice tells him that she wanted to but did not know how to and apologises.
22) Frank says that he saw his father in Summerland.
23) When he turns round, he slips and falls backwards into the water.
24) He flails under the water until Alice swims out to where he is and manages to rescue him.
25) After helping him get out, both of them gasp and cough up water profusely.
26) The next morning, Alice brings Frank breakfast which he initially refuses.
27) Alice reveals how she lost her own father years earlier, that she struggled to come to terms with it.
28) She then shows him the room she prepared for him, comforting him when he becomes upset looking through some family photos.
29) When they return home a few days later, they find Vera waiting for them.
30) She had not been home at the time of the bomb attacks.
31) Vera confesses to having engineered the selection of Alice as the host for Frank because she knew that if anything were to happen to her, Alice would take care of him.
32) Back in the present time, Alice is in the process of completing her manuscript when Vera suddenly interrupts her.
33) Having reunited some time ago, the two now live together.
34) As they stroll along the beach, an adult Frank, who has come for a visit, joins them.
35) Frank discovers the dedication in Alice's manuscript, and to his surprise, it is dedicated to him.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

Ground Truth Turning Points:
- Opportunity (tp1): 4.0 - Introductory event that occurs after presenting the setting and background of the main characters.
- Change of Plans (tp2): 7.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 13.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 23.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 31.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:
1. The protagonist in the story is Alice Lamb.

2. The first turning point is sentence 4:
"Alice had not volunteered to be a host and does not want to care for him as she fears it will interfere with her work researching mythology and folklore, but reluctantly agrees to let him stay believing that he has nowhere else to go and she will be able to be rid of him in a week."
At this point, Alice's state is one of reluctance and annoyance. She doesn't want to care for Frank, but feels obligated to do so. I would approximate her condition as a 2.

3. The second turning point is sentence 7:
"Alice and Frank start to bond after he takes an interest in her scholarly work and she explains Fata Morgana mirages to him."
At this point, Alice's state has improved. She is starting to form a connection with Frank and is sharing her passion with him. This is a significant improvement from her initial reluctance. I would approximate her condition as a 5.

4. The third turning point is sentence 13:
"While preparing a permanent room for him to stay in, she finds photographs of Frank and his parents in his scrapbook and is shocked to discover that his mother is Vera."
At this point, Alice's state is one of shock and potentially re-opened emotional wounds. She is forced to confront her past and the loss of her loved one. This is a significant setback, and I would approximate her condition as a 1.

5. The fourth turning point is sentence 23:
"He slips and falls backwards into the water."
At this point, Alice's state is one of panic and desperation. She is trying to save Frank and is experiencing extreme stress. This is the lowest point in the story for Alice. I would approximate her condition as a 0.

6. The fifth turning point is sentence 31:
"Vera confesses to having engineered the selection of Alice as the host for Frank because she knew that if anything were to happen to her, Alice would take care of him."
At this point, Alice's state is one of resolution and closure. She has reunited with Vera and is caring for Frank. She has found a new sense of purpose and belonging. I would approximate her condition as a 9.

7. The list of protagonist's condition in chronological order is:
[2, 5, 1, 0, 9]

8. Based on this list, I would classify the story arc type as "Man in a Hole". The protagonist starts in a relatively low state, improves slightly, then falls to a much lower state, only to recover and end in a much better state. This is consistent with the "Man in a Hole" story arc type.

9. Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Cradled in the tranquil embrace of Oakhurst, we become acquainted with our two central characters, Charlie Warden and Mac Johnston.
2) These seasoned World War II veterans have resigned themselves to an unhurried and qualitative retirement, a stark contrast to the chaotic reality of their pasts.
3) One day, the placid monotony of their retirement is ruptured by the arrival of an unknown agent from one of the CIA's hidden branches.
4) He comes bearing a collection of dust-laden folders, each bearing witness to the veterans' valorous military past.
5) The tranquil calm of their afternoon is shattered as they are confronted with troubling news: Dr. Richard Lombard, a leading weaponry scientist who has suddenly disappeared, is thought to be a captive of the unforgiving Russian government.
6) The task handed over to them, though seemingly straightforward on paper, is teeming with peril.
7) The prime objective: to track down and safely retrieve Dr. Lombard, while ensuring the security of his revolutionary weapon blueprints that hold high value.
8) As they set out to embark on this mission, their journey is abruptly brought to a grinding halt.
9) The instigator is a surprise coup led by the relentless Colonel Yuri Spalko, spearheading the vicious Russian forces.
10) This unfortunate detention sets in motion a series of unexpected findings, including their confinement within the malevolently designed “The Fortress of the Iron Curtain,” a secretive Russian stronghold.
11) Encased within the stifling walls of the fortress, they discover a tormented Dr. Lombard.
12) The captive scientist reveals his breakthrough research, a weapon of unprecedented potency that could disrupt the balance of the Cold War if utilized maliciously.
13) This revelation dials up the anxiety, prompting Charlie and Mac to devise a plan to escape their current predicament, especially upon understanding the catastrophic potential the weapon possesses.
14) Simultaneously, they discreetly observe the routines of the fortress guards, map out the architecture of the stronghold, and study the layered security system, strategizing potential routes to their escape.
15) Back in Washington, anxiety skyrockets as news of their disappearance permeates the international sphere, further fueling the tensions simmering between the nations.
16) In a risky maneuver, the CIA initiates covert discussions with the Russian government in an attempt to negotiate the release of the esteemed war heroes.
17) Meanwhile, within their confined space, Charlie and Mac construct an audacious escape strategy, secretly gathering required tools and timing the shifts of the Russian guards with surgical precision.
18) Driven by desperation and fueled by audacity, the veteran duo maneuvers a miraculous escape from the clutches of the fortress, successfully securing the confidential blueprints amidst the thrilling chaos.
19) In the course of their startling escape, they manage to free a fragile Dr. Lombard.
20) The sight of these formidable heroes conjures a glimmer of hope within the worn-out scientist.
21) Following their triumphant escape, Charlie and Mac reconnect with their secret CIA handlers who swiftly put an ambitious extraction strategy into motion.
22) As Charlie, Mac, and a weakened Dr. Lombard attempt to navigate the treacherous Russian wilderness, they face considerable challenges including land mines, patrolling enemies, and hostile terrains while racing towards specified extraction coordinates.
23) Colonel Spalko is tipped off about their escape which sets off a relentless chase through the dense wilderness, his forces echoing ominously behind the fleeing trio.
24) Using their battlefield experience, the trio manages to dodge deadly traps, escape ruthless patrols, and progress hastily towards their extraction point, as they strive to stay one step ahead Spalko's advancing forces.
25) A combat rife with adrenaline ensues as Charlie hangs precariously from the rear cargo ramp of the life-bearing chopper, dispensing suppressive fire to provide protective cover.
26) Amidst the high-octane chaos, Mac hoists a semi-conscious Dr. Lombard into the hovering chopper, braving the hail of bullets to prioritize Lombard's safety.
27) Drawing from his reservoir of survival skills, Charlie manages to hold off the remaining threats, compellingly making his way onto the aircraft amidst a shower of spent bullet casings.
28) With the ground cleared, the chopper roars off, a symbol of heroic victory against a swarm of adversities.
29) Upon touching down on home soil, the visibly shaken Dr. Lombard, along with the secured weapon blueprints, are promptly whisked away by the waiting CIA agents.
30) The relieved officials ensure that Dr. Lombard is immediately provided medical care, and the terrifying weapon blueprints are secured in an invincible vault, away from malignant hands.
31) Consciously opting for a low-key resolution, Charlie and Mac decline any public recognition for their valor.
32) Emerging out of their unexpected adventure, they fade back into the anonymity of their retirement.
33) They return to the comforting ambience of Oakhurst, leaving behind a raw tale of unparalleled courage and heroism yet to be spoken of.
34) Back at their porch, they choose to observe the ensuing intercontinental peace unfold – satisfied by the knowledge that they had served their nation silently, but significantly.
35) Seeking an anonymous life, Charlie and Mac become latent figures in their small-town, their shared heroism echoing undisturbed in the clandestine corridors of CIA operations.
36) As dusk descends over Oakhurst, peace creeps back into the town after the intense action saga, restoring tranquillity in its wake.
37) As they retire to their warm beds, their sanctuary reverberates with the tranquil undertones of their unwavering patriotism.
38) Their story, bearing the secret stamp of classified File No.
39) 369, whispers tales of unmatched valour amid the hushed corridors of the CIA.
40) Oblivious to the world outside, the tale of their hidden heroism silently continues, the veterans realizing they served their purpose of preserving peace.
41) As this cinematic tale of bravery reaches its fitting conclusion, the audience is left marveling at the compelling saga of bravery that went unnoticed.
42) A covert post-credit scene reveals a shiny red seal on a new classified dossier, containing details about another high-risk operation, teasing a potentially continued storyline.
43) Thus, concludes the current chapter of our heroes’ journey, setting the stage for a potentially gripping prologue to the ongoing saga of the 'Unseen Hero' series.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Living in Edinburgh, Philippa Langley loses a work promotion to a less experienced and better-looking woman.
2) She unsuccessfully confronts her male boss about being passed over and also appeals that her myalgic encephalomyelitis (or "ME") has never affected her work.
3) Distraught, her ex-husband John, who helps with their two teenage boys, tells her to keep her job as they need the money.
4) Philippa attends the play Richard III, and identifies with Richard whom she feels was unfairly maligned as a hunchback, child killer, and usurper.
5) She begins to have visions of Richard who appears to her.
6) She joins the local Richard III Society who believe he was unfairly vilified by Tudor propagandists.
7) Philippa stops going to work, manages her ME with medication, and begins talking to her Richard III apparition.
8) Her research shows some sources say he was buried in 1485 in the Leicester Greyfriars priory choir area, while others say his body was thrown into the River Soar.
9) After Greyfriars was demolished in the 1530s Reformation, Leicester mayor Robert Herrick around 1600 had a shrine built in his garden saying "Here lies the body of Richard III, sometime king of England."
10) Philippa attends a lecture in Leicester on Richard, lying to her ex-husband about it being a work trip.
11) She meets Dr Ashdown-Hill, who is publishing a genetic genealogy study on a Canadian direct descendant of Richard III's sister.
12) He tells her to look for Richard in open spaces in Leicester because people for centuries have avoided building over old abbeys.
13) While walking around Leicester looking for the ancient site of Greyfriars, and seeing apparitions of Richard, she gets a strong feeling that an "R" painted on a car park is the site of Richard's grave.
14) Returning home, she confesses her activities to John.
15) Philippa contacts University of Leicester archaeologist Richard Buckley, who dismisses her ideas, but when the university cuts his funding, he gets back to her.
16) Buckley finds an old map of Leicester marking Robert Herrick's property, showing a possible public shrine in his garden.
17) They overlay a modern map of Leicester and find that the shrine may be in the middle of the car park that Philippa had felt strongly about.
18) Philippa and Buckley team up.
19) She pitches it to Leicester City Council.
20) Richard Taylor of the University of Leicester advises that her amateur "feeling" is too risky.
21) The Council still approves her plan for the publicity, but when ground-radar finds nothing, funding drops out.
22) She turns to the Richard III Society to crowd-fund her "Looking For Richard," and the money comes in from around the world to fund three trenches.
23) On day one of the dig, Buckley tells Langley that the dig certificate has been signed, but does not tell her that her name has been omitted.
24) Philippa gets Buckley to start trench one at the painted "R" spot, and they immediately find the legs of a skeleton.
25) Buckley thinks it is an extramural graveyard for monks.
26) Philippa also confronts Taylor onsite for now falsely claiming credit for leading the project.
27) She then insists on stopping all work to focus on exposing the complete skeleton in trench one.
28) Buckley angrily relents and goes home while the crew digs the skeleton.
29) The osteologist soon realises that it is indeed Richard III, with the correct kind of death-blow to the skull, a 30-year-old male, and a badly-curved spine, all found on day one.
30) University of Leicester leaders rush in to take over the project.
31) They re-hire Buckley.
32) In February 2013, Taylor announces their findings to the world at a University of Leicester press conference, at which Phillippa is largely sidelined, even by Buckley.
33) Buckley is later given an honorary doctorate by the university.
34) Richard appears to Philippa a final time at Bosworth Field; he thanks her, and rides off.
35) Richard is shown getting a funeral fit for a king in Leicester Cathedral.
36) The closing credits say the royal family's website has reinstated Richard as the rightful King of England 1483–1485, so that he is no longer regarded as a usurper.
37) Langley was awarded an MBE for her work.

Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Quinn Ackerman, a quirky and intelligent high school senior, works as a technical director for the Thunderbirds, her high school's elite dance team, which is well known around the state as the reigning champions of the Work It dance competition.
2) When Quinn sets something on fire by accident, the ruthless leader of the Thunderbirds, Julliard Pembroke, fires her from the position.
3) Quinn's dream to attend Duke University, her late father's alma mater, is soured when the admissions counselor, Veronica Ramirez, informs that her chances of standing out to the admission's team are not good.
4) Quinn misleads Ramirez into thinking that she is a dancer on the Thunderbirds, even though she only worked the lighting.
5) Ramirez is instantly impressed, and vows to see her perform live at the Work It dance competition.
6) Though she considers confessing, Quinn instead decides to commit to it.
7) Quinn enlists the help of her best friend, Jasmine Hale, who is a dancer for the Thunderbirds herself, to teach her how to dance for the team's open auditions in two weeks.
8) Quinn's dancing skills improve substantially, but Julliard still rejects her.
9) After Jasmine stands up to him and defends Quinn, Julliard sarcastically suggests that the two start their own dance team, which Quinn does.
10) Jasmine reluctantly agrees to quit the Thunderbirds in favor of Quinn's new team.
11) Quinn and Jasmine research a former champion of the Work It competition, Jake Taylor, who stopped competing and vanished after a knee injury two years prior.
12) Quinn tracks him down and approaches him at the dance studio where he now works, and asks him to be a choreographer for her team, but Jake rejects her, insisting that dance is done with passion, not learned by thinking.
13) Meanwhile, the girls round up a group of unknown dancers at their school who all differ in style.
14) After seeing the team's potential during an informal dance meetup, Jake agrees to choreograph for Quinn's team, but only if they can win the upcoming qualifying competition by themselves.
15) Under the name "TBD", they cut qualifiers but on a technicality issue with an opposing team.
16) Jake and Quinn spend more time together, and one night, Jake takes her aside and decides to experiment with freestyle dancing with her.
17) As the two practice, Quinn's talent surfaces, and they kiss.
18) With newfound confidence, Quinn takes it easier on herself and puts more effort into her dancing and teamwork.
19) Quinn emails Veronica Ramirez and informs her that she has started her own team and that they will be competing at Work It.
20) However, when Julliard discovers that Jake is choreographing for the Quinn's team, he turns them in for using the studio to practice without paying, and Jake loses his job.
21) Quinn's grades drop due to her dedication to the team, and she receives an email from the Duke admissions team informing her that Veronica no longer works there.
22) Quinn confesses everything to her mom, and they agree that she should quit the dance team and bring her grades up before turning in her final transcript.
23) The team feels betrayed by Quinn's departure, especially Jasmine, who rejoins the Thunderbirds, and Quinn ends her romance with Jake.
24) She later rediscovers her own passion for dance and reconciles with Jake, and they both decide to bring the team back together.
25) Quinn reconciles with Jasmine, who quits the Thunderbirds and rejoins the TBDs.
26) The group begins to learn each other's unique dance styles, and Jake incorporates them into the choreography.
27) On the day of the competition, Quinn's mother discovers that she is still in dance and tries to stop her from leaving, but Quinn steals the car keys and leaves.
28) When Quinn arrives, the TBDs are already on stage, and she enters halfway through the act.
29) The TBDs narrowly win the competition over the Thunderbirds, and both Jasmine and Julliard are approached by a scout from the New York Dance Academy.
30) Quinn runs into Veronica, who is now working at NYU, and she invites her to apply for the fall semester.

2. The first turning point (Opportunity) is at sentence 4: "Quinn misleads Ramirez into thinking that she is a dancer on the Thunderbirds, even though she only worked the lighting." At this point, Quinn's state is hopeful and optimistic, as she sees an opportunity to improve her chances of getting into Duke University. instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Amidst the chaos and disorder in Zadaar, a spaceship-city-state planet on the verge of collapse, King Argo and Queen Ellara faced their most profound fear - the extinction of their ancient and cherished royal bloodline.
2) Their infant son, precious Zephyr, was the clandestine successor to the historic silver throne of Zadaar and carried within him the hope for a monumental rebirth of their planet.
3) Taking advantage of their sophisticated Zadaarian technology, the royal couple constructed a robust and resilient spacecraft named "Stellaron."
4) Exceptionally equipped, the Stellaron was capable of armed interstellar travel, even against the most severe opposition the cosmos could throw its way.
5) Their primary goal was to ensure Zephyr's survival and preserve his bloodline by sending him to Earth, a thriving and prosperous planet teeming with life forms diverse in every conceivable way.
6) Before the momentous departure, King Argo and Queen Ellara placed a powerful cosmic pendant, "The Heart of Zadaar," within their little heir.
7) The pendant was more than a symbolic object; it granted Zephyr the ability to access their planet’s immense energy reservoir, creating in him a living embodiment of Zadaar.
8) Infused with the energy from the cosmic pendant, the spacecraft Zephyr was securely nestled in embarked on its perilous journey across star-filled galaxies.
9) A daunting and adventurous travel to an unknown planet, Earth.
10) After surviving the dangers of interstellar travel and the unpredictability of cosmos, the Stellaron, carrying the future of Zadaar, landed safely in the quiet and serene heart of a secluded wheat field, miles away from a small rural town in Kansas.
11) The unexpected appearance of the alien object provoked curiosity and wonder in a local childless couple, Martha and Jonathan Que.
12) The sight was fascinating yet spine-chilling, an enigma waiting to be unfolded in the heart of ordinary Kansas life.
13) Intrigued and startled by the mysterious baby boy they discovered inside the spaceship, their hearts instantly swelled with protective instinct and unprecedented warmth, bonding them with the celestial child.
14) Interpreting the odd and seemingly divinely orchestrated sign, they decided to adopt the otherworldly baby.
15) They rebranded him as Sean, providing him an earthly identity, yet they unknowingly harbored a royal alien in their humble Kansas home.
16) As time swept by, Sean, nurtured with immense love and care by his doting adoptive Kansas parents, matured into a seemingly unexceptional teenager, blending perfectly into the predictable rhythm of the town.
17) In contrast to his outwardly normal life, an inner turmoil brewed within Sean as he struggled to comprehend and control his sprawling super-human abilities, a troubling contrast to his otherwise typical high school life.
18) His life took an unexpected turn when his cosmic pendant, "The Heart of Zadaar," began acting wildly unpredictable, causing erratic energy spurts and disturbing his attempts at human-like subtlety.
19) The strange behavior of the pendant provoked alarming surges in Sean’s powers, inadvertently attracting attention and threatening his low profile life.
20) Unbeknownst to him, the infamous Zurkon Gang, a notorious group of extraterrestrial marauders, stumbled upon the cosmic energy trail and traced it back to Earth, bringing imminent danger to his newfound sanctuary.
21) Coveting the immense power of the cosmic pendant, this heinous gang of cosmic criminals hatched an insidious plan to capture the pendant and its power, plotting the unsuspecting Earth as their next hunting ground.
22) Amid the impending crisis, Sean was contacted by Alura – the sentient protector entity living within his cosmic pendant.
23) Her virtual form and ethereal voice sprung a series of shocking revelations on the baffled teenager.
24) Alura, in her translucent form, unraveled the secrets of Sean's noble alien origin and his extraordinary superhuman abilities, shaking his perception of his 'ordinary' existence.
25) Amidst breath-taking revelations, Alura metamorphosed into a trusty guide for Sean, teaching him cleverly engineered steps to control his powers and fully inhabit his true identity, Zephyr.
26) Fully harnessed and nurtured by Alura’s guidance, Zephyr debuted his powers in his small town in the form of heroic acts.
27) However, the public display unintentionally opened a glaring beacon for the menacing Zurkon Gang to Earth's existence.
28) The ruthless Zurkon Gang, clawing their path through the galaxies, spotted the opening.
29) In response, they launched a series of terrifying attacks, spreading widespread devastation across Earth, inciting panic and fear in hearts everywhere.
30) To Zephyr's dismay, humans mistakenly assigned blame for the alien attacks on him, misguided by their fear of the unknown, making the once-revered protector an unjustly painted villain.
31) Even burdened by misplaced blame, Zephyr remained determinated to shield his Earth home from interstellar threats.
32) His resolve undeterred and his heart brimming with a sense of duty, he faced the challenge head-on with a promise to win back humans' trust.
33) The stage was set for an epic showdown with the Zurkon Gang.
34) This pivotal conflict was an opportunity for Zephyr's resilience and resolution to be put to the ultimate test against these powerful extraterrestrial foes.
35) The face-off was battle-ridden and cosmic.
36) Zephyr, now fully equipped with skills he'd learned from Alura, engaged in a ruthless struggle, sparing no effort in his determination to safeguard his adopted home.
37) As the interstellar battle surged in intensity, exertion, strategy, and endurance, a victorious glimmer finally dawned, with Zephyr overpowering the ruinous Zurkon Gang and dismantling their wicked plan.
38) The victory, however, came at a severe cost.
39) Alura's life force was entirely depleted in the process, emptying the pendant of its energy and shrouding Zephyr's fate in uncertainty.
40) The sudden loss resulted in an immediate cessation of Zephyr’s superhuman faculties, rendering him momentarily powerless, clashing his world between celestial powers and human limitations.
41) Briefly deprived of his cosmic abilities, Sean, in his wholly human form, was acknowledged by the erstwhile skeptical Earth citizens.
42) His triumph brought a wave of acceptance, mirroring the collective relief felt by the world.
43) Now revered as a true protector and ally, Sean not only regained human trust but also etched his heroism in their memories.
44) Returning to his 'normal' life with Martha and Jonathan, Sean carried with him the silent weight of his celestial legacy and the memory of his heroic acts, filling their simple Kansas abode with a sense of extraordinary accomplishment.
45) He safeguarded the dormant "Heart of Zadaar," the physical link to his alien lineage and biological parents' sacrifices, enriching his earthly existence with a celestial connection.
46) The pendant, although dormant, remained a constant reminder of his extraordinary heritage while simultaneously whispering about the incredible potential of what lay ahead for him.
47) The conclusion hinted at an unexpected twist in Sean's otherwise simple storyline; The cosmic powers ingrained within him started showing signs of reactivation, indicating the possibility of a more impressive future.
48) Alongside the subtle return of his cosmic abilities, traces of other cosmic pendants surfaced.
49) This groundbreaking revelation suggested the existence of other interstellar heirs like Sean across the universe, expanding the realms of possibilities and encounters.

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Renowned for his heroism on the Apollo-50 mission, Richard Patterson, a seasoned astronaut, assumes a powerful leadership position within NASA's vibrant and bustling command center.
2) His years of experience and wisdom fall upon a diverse team—each member carrying an essential piece of the puzzle in pioneering humanity's leap into space.
3) Alongside Richard, Margaret "Meg" Smith, a gifted space engineer whose genius rivals that of the creators of the Hubble telescope, serves as a steady voice of reason and logic—an intellectual powerhouse in the team.
4) Joining this elite team with a heart pounding with nerves and excitement, Jack Philips steps into the world of “Orbital Engineers”—an adept group of repair and maintenance maestros navigating the void of outer space.
5) Richard and Meg, often seen swapping playful banter and classic jibes, not only showcase a camaraderie that was formed decades ago during their first NASA training but also a deep-seated respect and understanding for each other—admirable pillars of their enduring friendship.
6) Jack, fueled by an ambition that could even compete with the pioneering Wright brothers, puts everything on the line.
7) He spends countless hours honing his orbital maneuvering and emergency repair skills, determined to master every complexity and nuance of this art.
8) Their mission—to repair the Hubble Space Telescope that is playing havoc with astronomical tracking on Earth— set forth a daring ascent into the void of space aboard the technologically advanced SpaceX Dragon spacecraft.
9) As they near the iconic Hubble, tension blankets the cabin.
10) The team diligently prepares for their endeavor, equipping themselves with their Extravehicular Mobility Units (EMUs) and unfurling their toolkit against the backdrop of cold, unwavering stars.
11) During his maiden spacewalk, Jack meticulously documents each of his actions on the spacecraft’s state-of-the-art onboard computer system before taking on the critical task of maintenance on the Hubble.
12) However, what started as an ordinary expedition pivots towards disaster when, hidden within the complex workings of the Hubble, they unearth a time bomb threatening devastation on an unprecedented scale.
13) Fear, painted across Jack's green eyes, is echoed amongst the crew.
14) Still, Richard and Meg composure remains unwavering, a testament to their years of rigorous astronautical training and emotional resilience.
15) With the ticking bomb as their ominous companion, Meg and Jack throw themselves into work.
16) The weight of humanity's survival lies heavy on their shoulders, entrusted to their space-suited forms.
17) The situation spirals when the dormant bomb triggers a slew of anomalies in the linked GPS satellites, compounding challenges on Earth.
18) Amid a barrage of stray satellites set loose by the bomb’s detonation, Richard sustains a crippling injury that incapacitates him—leaving the less-experienced Meg and Jack adrift in a sea of mounting challenges.
19) Out of necessity, Meg and Jack find themselves shouldering the relentless tasks of satellite salvage operations and the urgent disarmament of the deadly bomb.
20) Despite his agonizing injury, Richard calls upon every shred of willpower to guide Meg and Jack, fueling them with much-needed practical wisdom and advice through the agony that threatens to engulf him.
21) Demonstrating exceptional courage and determination, Meg and Jack formulate a daring strategy to halt the countdown of the bomb while simultaneously combating the satellite anomalies.
22) With the clock mercilessly ticking away and leaving them a paltry hour to achieve their goals, they dive into their plan—hands steady, movements precise, and minds fixated on the monumental task despite the stress escalator.
23) The frantic voices from Houston’s Mission Control are drowned in the sea of time constraints, leaving the astronauts to rely solely on their instincts, experience, and the fruits of their intensive training.
24) Pitted against astronomical odds and guided by Richard’s vital advice, Meg and Jack push aside their fears and throw themselves into a race against time, leaving no room for error.
25) In the face of impending disaster, with merely seconds on the countdown clock, they manage to disarm the bomb and rectify the malfunctioning satellites—pulling Earth from the jaws of catastrophe.
26) However, the fiasco takes a tragic turn when Richard's life is swiftly teetering on the edge due to his grievous injuries.
27) Despite their desperate efforts and hopeful prayers, Richard succumbs to his wounds.
28) His final moments blossom in the deafening silence aboard the spacecraft, his last act symbolizing a hero's sacrifice for humanity, mirrored in the last flicker of his life.
29) Back on Earth, Mission Control and the world erupt into euphoria as the systems revert to normal, narrowly averting the disaster that had held its breath to strike.
30) Returning to Earth as celebrated heroes, Meg and Jack, enshrouded in exhaustion, wear their victory as a mantle— their faces glowing through the weariness, the testament of an adventure that was as harrowing as it was triumphant.
31) Richard's brave deed joins the annals of space history, his heroic saga destined to inspire future generations toward astronomical aspirations.
32) Having undergone a profound metamorphosis amid a crisis, Jack steps into Richard's enormous shoes, carrying forward his legacy and teachings for future missions.
33) As the story concludes on a heartrending note, Richard's sacrifice carves a path of honor in the annals of space history—providing a stepping stone for Jack, who strides forward to helm future missions, with the ever-dependable Meg always at his side.
34) The history of space exploration carries forth, enriched by sacrifice, culminating in hope for humanity's cosmic journey.

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Amidst the serene tranquility of Vermont's snow-capped mountains, against a backdrop of cascading foliage, we find our humble hero Basil, an endearing baker known for his winsome innocence.
2) His maple-scented bakery, quite fittingly named 'Basil's Buns and Bombs', lies nestled within a realm of rustic tranquillity.
3) Basil dreams of transforming his quaint bakery into a flourishing social hub that pulsates with the rhythm of the enchanting mountain town's community life.
4) Yet, the picturesque town doesn't echo his ardour.
5) Instead, the townsfolk amuse themselves by using Basil and his cherished bakery as the stage for their elaborate practical jokes.
6) The resultant uproar and unpredictability have unfortunately become normal for the mild-mannered Basil.
7) Basil, whose resolve is as unyielding as Vermont's granite, remains unfazed by the persistent mockery.
8) He clings to the vision of his bakery swarming with smiling faces, and air simmering with the aroma of his cinnamon buns.
9) One day, a gust of zesty vitality whirled into the quiet town in the form of an effervescent woman, Sophia.
10) Her vibrant persona was as invigorating as a breath of spring air amongst the everlasting winter.
11) With her radiant smile and infectious optimism, Sophia captured the heart of the town, becoming an overnight bearer of change.
12) While getting to know the cobblestoned downtown, she sets her foot inside Basil's bakery, straight away charmed by its homely ambiance and inviting aromas.
13) A sharp observer, Sophia begins to discern the peculiar dynamics between Basil and the townsfolk.
14) She sees past the laughter and spots the strain on Basil's face.
15) Overcome with empathy, Sophia decides to assist Basil.
16) Her plan?
17) A rejuvenation project for the bakery, with a sprinkling of assertiveness lessons for its bashful owner.
18) Basil, standoffish at first, is eventually won over by Sophia's infectious enthusiasm and vibrant spirit.
19) The two then embark on a series of adventurous escapades, starting with humorous assertiveness training sessions, where Basil’s endearing attempts leave them in fits of mirth.
20) One of their outrageous ideas even involves a confused parrot rhyming jingles and fireworks illuminating the night sky, all to promote Basil’s bakery!
21) Amidst these memorable ventures, Basil’s budding confidence also germinates an affectionate liking for the sociable Sophia.
22) Basil, now a changed man, decides to take a stand against his regular taunter - the burly and ragging football player, Brad, leading to an unforgettable creamy spectacle.
23) The meticulously crafted cream pie, initially meant as a gift to the town's mayor, finds its way to Brad's face, mid-insult.
24) News of Basil’s unexpected defiance sends ripples through the town, marking the onset of his heroic transformation.
25) Throughout this upheaval, Sophia’s unwavering support remains a constant, unknowingly knitting a romantic bond between them.
26) This newfound courage piques the interest of the residents and the once-slumberous bakery transforms into a bustling hub.
27) Basil’s daring confrontation with Brad triggers a newfound respect for the once-gullible baker.
28) Riding on his fame wave, Basil organizes a grand re-launch for his bakery, promising an entire day of free pastries.
29) This innocuous invitation takes a comedic turn when the eccentric 'Vermont Valley Nudists' club mistakenly gets invited.
30) Amidst the grand opening's mirth, Basil receives an unexpected visit from Brad who offers a public apology to Basil.
31) Riding on this wave of triumph, Basil confesses his feelings for Sophia in front of the exuberant crowd, reciprocated passionately by Sophia.
32) Following the momentous grand opening, ‘Basil’s Buns and Bombs' becomes a beloved spot amongst townsfolk, a testament to Basil's relentless efforts.
33) The once placid townsfolk are now intrigued by this newfound bravery and begin to appreciate Basil’s strength.
34) The bakery now throbs with friendly chatter, mouth-watering pastries, and amusing town gossip, all under Basil's watchful and confident glance.
35) Even his former bullies queue up for his delicacies.
36) As we bid adieu to Basil, we see him basking in the glory of his newfound success, affectionately sharing a homemade pastry with Sophia.
37) The view pans out from a warmly lit bakery, echoing with laughter, symbolizing Basil's victories and a safe haven for the townsfolk.
38) Basil’s story turns from a tale of 'Bakery Blues' to an enchanting narrative of 'Basil’s Blissful Bakery,' winding up on a jubilant note enveloped in the aroma of fresh pastries and hearty smiles.

- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)

Based on the protagonist's condition list, the story arc type can be classified as "Man in a Hole" or possibly "Cinderella". 8) However, she clings to her unwavering love for John and pledges her unwavering support for his dreams, fully acclimating to her new envisioned role as an academic spouse.
9) Kate, a ten-year veteran in the world of marketing on Wall Street, finds herself bidding a reluctant adieu to her colleagues.
10) A surprise farewell party at her favorite Italian restaurant leaves her with tear-brimmed eyes and a bittersweet cocktail of memories and anticipation.
11) They set out for their journey, leaving the familiar landscape of towering skyscrapers behind.
12) The journey through varying landscapes is punctuated with excitement, anxiety, and anticipation until they arrive at a quaint Craftsman cottage with a distinctive blue roof — their new dwelling, conveniently situated within the reach of Yale's historic campus.
13) Act two portrays John embracing his role as a University professor.
14) His thought-provoking lectures laced with congeniality earn him an adored place in the hearts of his students.
15) Meanwhile, Kate begins navigating her newfound reality.

29) This unexpected power dynamic inflicts turmoil upon their relationship.
30) John grapples with his bruised ego while Kate attempts to balance her flourishing career and a fraying marriage.
31) Act five witnesses the tensions culminating into a heated confrontation fraught with pent-up emotions, taking a toll on their two-decade-long companionship and leaving them questioning the future of their marriage.
32) Amidst the tension and hostility, they agree to take a break, to reflect on their identities, their ambitions, and their fracturing bond.
33) Amid this turmoil, a bracing encounter with Professor Smith, John's old friend, compels him to face and appreciate the true magnificity of Kate's achievements.
34) Concurrently, over heartfelt conversations with her girlfriends in a quaint coffee shop, Kate confronts her overeager competitive spirit, aiding her to realize the need for achieving balance, for the sake of the marriage she cherished.
35) Within this storm of introspection, they both comprehend the supremacy of their love, outshining any professional accomplishment.
36) Their brief hiatus ends as a more enlightened John, invites Kate to L'Appart, their preferred French restaurant.
37) It's here where he exposes his insecurities and commends her victories, marking the commencement of healing.
38) Kate, moved by John's candid expression of vulnerability, makes a pledge to adjust her ambitions, promising to strike a balance for preserving their delicate relationship.
39) With mutual understanding refueling their bond, they vow to spur each other's growth in their fields, fostering an environment of support and mutual respect.
40) As their tale completes a full circle, they are back at Yale.
41) John, brilliantly commanding lecture halls and Kate, rekindling her academia business prowess in the boardrooms.
42) As fate rolls the dice, a chance encounter at Yale's main library, Sterling, offers them a moment of warm reconciliation.
43) Their eyes meet, acknowledging each other's journeys, their shared wisdom, and their enduring love.

Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) The film "The Expat - Revenge in a Foreign Land," starts within the bleak, harsh confines of Her Majesty's Prison Belmarsh, an infamous British penitentiary known for housing high profile criminals.
2) The film's protagonist, a man named Carter, is introduced right off the bat.
3) Inside the sinister confines of the prison, he withstands his release procedures after serving a lengthy ten-year sentence.
4) Carter, a formidable ex-MI6 agent and British Army officer, walks into the outside world.
5) Using clever filmmaking through a series of insightful flashback sequences during the release proceedings, the audience slowly learns of Carter's past.
6) Released into the world that feels unfamiliar after his decade-long isolation, Carter embarks on a journey to start afresh.
7) His immediate destination is the metropolis of New York in the United States.
8) The transition of Carter from a renowned British spy into a struggling American civilian forms an intriguing subplot.
9) The story takes a tragic turn as we learn about Carter's personal loss - Emma, his only daughter, had been brutally murdered during his time in prison.
10) Overcome with skepticism towards the hastily knitted story of Emma's death, Carter decides to investigate the case himself.
11) Applying his skills, Carter scrutinises the NYPD's official reports regarding Emma's death.
12) These discrepancies indicate an intricate cover-up.
13) Unyielding and supremely focused, Carter employs his intelligence prowess to methodically decipher the mysterious events that led his daughter to her early grave.
14) As he delves deeper into the mystery, a chilling revelation comes to surface.
15) Emma had somehow become tangled with the famed Bronx-Kings Cartel, a notorious criminal organization ruling New York's underworld.
16) This shocking revelation leads Carter down a rabbit hole of deception and danger.
17) Furthering the complexity, Carter uncovers his daughter's baffling relationship with Rafael Serrano, the cartel's dangerous boss.
18) But his tenacity encounters strong resistance from the NYPD.
19) With his growing suspicion about the precinct's integrity and their repeated obstructive actions, Carter’s instincts tell him that the Bronx-Kings Cartel has severely compromised local law enforcement.
20) Undeterred by the mounting layers of danger and intrigue, Carter's fearlessness is unparalleled as he descends deeper into the corrupt and perilous underworld of New York.
21) His relentless pursuit uncovers a staggering truth.
22) Carter's tireless investigations eventually reveal a shocking truth: Emma had purposefully won the affections of the notorious gang leader, Rafael.
23) Armed with newfound evidence, Carter reaches out to a trustworthy ally back in his homeland, George Sutter, a former comrade and currently an active MI6 operative.
24) Bolstered with irrefutable evidence, Carter plans to dismantle the corrupt precinct and wreak havoc upon the Bronx-Kings Cartel.
25) The plot races towards an explosive climax where the cold and calculating Carter, utilising his military expertise and keen strategic insights, takes on Serrano's Cartel.
26) Carter's mission becomes clear: To decimate the cartel from its roots, as a tribute to Emma's bravery.
27) Emotions run wild as a ruthless battle ensues.
28) The suspense heightens, and the pressure mounts as Carter ingeniously uses the enemy’s tactics against them, leveraging his battle-hardened experience.
29) Despite all odds, Carter stands firm against the barrage of violence, and in an adrenaline-filled sequence he manages to blow the Bronx-Kings Cartel a devastating blow.
30) The film moves towards resolution displaying the shattered remains of the once formidable Bronx-Kings Cartel.
31) The nefarious officers hiding behind the façade of the NYPD uniform are stripped of their honour, forced to meet the consequences of their actions.
32) As a result, sweeping change graces the NYPD, leading to a large-scale cleanup and overhaul initiated by righteous forces inside the law enforcement community.
33) On the other side of this tumultuous battle, Carter finds vindication.
34) Despite the emotional toll of his journey, Carter makes the decision to stay in the city he’s rid from major corruption.
35) Carter develops a sense of calm amidst the concrete jungle.
36) As the story begins to wind down, we see Carter embodying a guardian angel's role.
37) As the movie draws closer to its end, we find the process of Carter's emotional healing delicately blossoming within him.
38) Subtle details suggest his shift towards a new vocation dedicated to serving and protecting his new home from any potential threats.
39) Living with his invisible scars, Carter emerges triumphant, standing tall against adversity; the city now sings praises of its new protector.
40) Post the clash with the mafia, the metropolis starts its healing process.
41) Carter's tale evolves from merely a story of revenge; it turns into a promise - a promise of an enduring battle against the corruption that lurks in the city's shadows.
42) The final scenes capture Carter's unyielding vow to continue his vigil, his dedication towards protecting New York, his new-found home.
43) His transformation from an unfamiliar outsider to the city's defender is a compelling narrative of an extraordinary character's journey.
44) He starts to find solace in serving New York, dedicated to safeguarding it from future criminal enterprises and threats.
45) The final shot features Carter, standing tall and lone against the NYC skyline, now his domain, embracing his new role with stern resolve.

- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

3) Sam is a prodigy in English Literature, and his enduring love for learning paints him as a resilient individual.

7) Sam approaches Ms. Fletcher, his empathetic English teacher, confides his secret and pleads for acceptance.
8) Ms. Fletcher encourages Sam to channel his emotions into literature.
9) Sam begins crafting a semi-autobiographical play titled, "Everyone's Whispering About Sam."
10) He incorporates his emotional journey and experiences into the script.
11) He openly announces his sexual orientation at school.
12) He experiences a mix of support and hostility after his announcement.
13) Despite a heartbreak, Sam uses his emotions to enrich his play.
14) Sam proposes his play for the Annual School Drama Contest, but it is declined by the school's conservative governing body.
15) Susan, Ms. Fletcher, and a handful of progressive students fight to get the decision reversed.
16) Their campaign succeeds, and Sam’s play is approved.
17) Relationships are formed and perceptions begin to shift as word about the controversial play spreads.

20) The applause is mixed with some dissatisfaction, but mostly approval and support.

23) He is ready to challenge prejudice and silence the echoes of homophobia with his unyielding spirit.
24) He leads a small revolution against homophobia within the school.
25) Sam's play starts a dialog about acceptance and inclusivity in the local community.
26) His play's script is incorporated into the English literature curriculum in local schools.
27) Sam, now turning into an emblem of change, uses his story to inspire a culture of tolerance.
28) His story ends on an optimistic note, as he is ready to face new challenges and victories.
29) The film ends on an image of Sam: a person silenced of whispers, and brimming with unwavering conviction.

Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Best-selling American author Sophie Brown travels to Scotland to escape the backlash from her last book, as fans were upset she killed off the male lead as she recently divorced.
2) It was compounded by a very angry television interview.
3) Visiting her father's ancestral village, Dunbar, Sophie is warmly welcomed.
4) People there love her books, even the last one.
5) Shown the nearby castle, Dun Dunbar, where her grandfather had worked as a groundskeeper by a man she'd first seen in the village, he abruptly turns her out when Sophie explores a section of the house he'd warned was private.
6) Back in the B&B, the local knitting club befriends Sophie.
7) All fans of her books, they get her to join.
8) Chatting about their personal details.
9) Sophie tells them about her daughter Lexie and mentions her recent divorce.
10) She talks about her dad Callum McGuinty, whose father had worked at the castle, one of them actually had known him.
11) Discovering the castle is for sale, Sophie meets the Duke who owns it, Myles Dunbar.
12) Both are appalled to see they'd met there the previous day.
13) Sophie feels she's fallen in love with Dun Dunbar, but must face off with the ill-tempered Myles.
14) Initially refusing to sell, he's warned he has no choice.
15) Myles approaches Sophie at the pub and proposes a deal: 90 day escrow, non-refundable deposit and they both live there simultaneously for the three months.
16) Sophie is given a new tour of the castle, focusing on its problems: no electricity in some rooms, old wiring, leaky roof, half of the fireplaces are inoperable, no heat upstairs, iffy plumbing, wifi and cell service intermittent and Myles gives her a room that's falling to pieces.
17) Sophie shows him a door jamb with her last name carved into it, which her father had done as a child when trespassing, resulting in her grandfather getting sacked and their moving to the US.
18) The next day, Sophie continues bonding with the locals.
19) As her dad was a barber, she does everyone in the knitting club's hair.
20) The group then helps spruce up her room in the castle.
21) They tell Sophie that, as their landlord, Myles is working to pay off the farmland debt so they all will be able to continue living in their homes, although he would still be homeless.
22) Lexi later tells Sophie she can't come for Christmas, as her dad is remarrying then.
23) Myles overhears, telling her he's a fool.
24) He then divulges his wife left him for someone with a more prestigious title.
25) Myles takes Sophie to the Dun Glen Holy Wishing Well.
26) He mentions the first duke and duchess had held a Christmas party for years for the village, inspiring Sophie to want to do the same.
27) They later enjoy themselves at the pub.
28) Back at the castle, they choose to ignore their definite chemistry.
29) The next day, Sophie helps Thomas lead a tour through the house as she is recognized, still has writer's block and just spoke with her impatient editor Claire.
30) It is well-received by the visitors.
31) Following Sophie down to the knitting group's meeting, Myles confronts her.
32) Complaining she is everywhere, she reiterates that she's not going anywhere, so he stomps off.
33) Back at the castle, as they need a tree, they get one in the woods together.
34) The knitting club then helps decorate and sing carols.
35) That evening, Sophie is trying on a gown from one of the closets for the upcoming party.
36) Before she can finish getting it on, the dog Hamish leads her to Myles' door.
37) They can't resist each other, kiss passionately and spend the night together.
38) In the morning, Christmas eve, Myles blows up when she asks him to continue living there with her.
39) Hurt, she declares that he wins, as staying would only remind her of him.
40) Sophie wheels her suitcase into town, but Eamon's taxi 'breaks down', so she gets a room in the B&B but refuses to go to the party.
41) Myles appears, apologizes and confesses he loves her.
42) Going to their Christmas party, Lexi has come, thanks to Myles.
43) In the final scene, Sophie McGuinty is back on the talk show, promoting her new best-seller.
