Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) The film opens with Kenneth Feinberg detailing the law's recognition of the monetary value of a person's life to his class at Columbia University.
2) Some time later, the September 11 attacks occur.
3) Feinberg is appointed the Special Master of the September 11th Victim Compensation Fund while his law partner, Camille Biros, is appointed as his administrative deputy.
4) Feinberg develops a rigid formula for each payout based on the victim's income, and is instructed that if he cannot convince at least 80 percent of the 7,000 estimated victims to sign on then they will be eligible to file a lawsuit which they may lose (as well as the pressure from the political administrations to save the airlines from being sued, leading to financial disaster).
5) Feinberg is given until December 22, 2003 to accomplish this.
6) At an introductory meeting with victims in which he attempts to explain the rules governing the fund, Feinberg is perceived as insensitive to the losses suffered by attendees.
7) The hostile group is calmed when Charles Wolf, the husband of a woman killed in the attacks, demands that they listen to what Feinberg has to say.
8) After the meeting, Feinberg is confronted by Frank Donato, the brother of a deceased New York City Fire Department (FDNY) firefighter, Nick.
9) His brother had re-entered the tower to find him after communication, which may not have reached Nick, warned that the building would fail.
10) Frank demands that Feinberg includes this information in the report to remedy this flaw in the communication system for first responders.
11) Feinberg deflects that demand in lawyerly fashion.
12) Feinberg also is disturbed to learn that Wolf was offended by the callous nature of the fund's formula and has started a protest group.
13) Biros leads the staff in holding meetings with victims and is moved by the story of a gay man, Graham Morris, whose partner (whose parents vehemently denied that their son was gay) was killed in the attack.
14) Due to the rules governing the fund, he cannot be compensated as he is a resident of the state of Virginia, which does not recognize civil partnerships.
15) Feinberg also meets with several lawyers representing the loved ones of upper-class victims of the attacks, who want more money, which threatens the success of the group as a whole.
16) As the months drag on, the fund manages to attract only a fraction of the necessary applicants, leading Feinberg to hold a private meeting with Wolf in which the latter accuses Feinberg of serving only the interests of the Bush administration.
17) A lawyer representing Donato's extra-marital partner calls Feinberg to inform him that Donato has two daughters from that relationship who qualify for compensation.
18) This leads Feinberg to try to inform Donato's widow to convince her to sign on after she had earlier refused.
19) As the months drag on, Feinberg is increasingly unsuccessful in convincing victims to file for compensation from the government fund.
20) After Wolf approaches him one evening at the opera and recounts an anecdote from years earlier in which his deceased wife encouraged him to persevere in the face of failure, Feinberg finds his spirit renewed.
21) Feinberg and Biros begin to use the discretion government gave him to expand the rules to cover as many victims as they can under the fund.
22) Feinberg begins to meet victims.
23) He constructs a shrine in his office from the various mementos given to him by fund applicants.
24) When Wolf sees that Feinberg truly cares for the victims of the attacks, he is able to convince his fellow victims to trust Feinberg.
25) By the deadline, the vast majority of those eligible for compensation sign the forms, ensuring the success of the project.
26) Feinberg is visited by Donato's widow to sign on behalf of her husband's children.
27) Biros tearfully calls Morris to inform him that while she was unable to help him as the gay partner of a victim, because his state did not recognize their relationship, the fund did compensate many other gay couples who lived in states that recognized same-sex unions.
28) The film ends with a title card stating that Feinberg and Biros were able to distribute billions in government money to 97 percent of eligible victims and that they continue to work on similar cases.

- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

- Change of Plans (tp2): 5.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 8.5 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 16.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 23.5 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").

   Sentence: "As the months drag on, the fund manages to attract only a fraction of the necessary applicants, leading Feinberg to hold a private meeting with Wolf in which the latter accuses Feinberg of serving only the interests of the Bush administration."

   Sentence: "He constructs a shrine in his office from the various mementos given to him by fund applicants."

   The story arc type can be classified as "Man in a Hole" because the protagonist starts at a relatively stable condition (6), faces challenges and setbacks that worsen his condition (5.5 to 4 to 2), but ultimately finds a way to improve his condition significantly by the climax (8). This pattern of falling into a difficult situation and then finding a way out to end in a better state is characteristic of the "Man in a Hole" story arc.

9. **Determined story arc type:** 
   Man in a Hole

input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) We begin our tale in the middle of a catastrophic disaster enveloping the Aegean Sea.
2) A sudden, deceptively calm night is disrupted as George and Anna's prized research vessel, "Sea Whisperer", is abruptly ripped apart by an unexpected storm.
3) The promising marine biologists don't make it, leaving their young daughter, Lisa, orphaned.
4) A decade later, a narrative transition unveils Lisa as a lively, robust teenager living in the picturesque coastal town of Mariner’s Haven.
5) Her guardian, a contemplative man named John, is both her mentor and grandfather.
6) Together, they create a peaceful and straightforward life in a charming white cottage that hugs the edge of the alluring sea, allowing them never to be too far from the water’s gentle lap at the shore.
7) Aging each year grew Lisa's curiosity and intensified the need to understand more about her deceased parents.
8) Every evening after dinner, she peppers John with numerous questions.
9) Reluctantly, but with emotion-filled eyes, John relays stories of George and Anna's fulfilling and adventurous lives as esteemed marine biologists while Lisa attentively listens, absorbing every detail.
10) As Lisa transitions from a juvenile girl to a young woman, we see her growth intertwined with the fantastical tales spun by John each passing day.
11) Throughout this period, she strengthens her friendships with the familiar faces around her, particularly her childhood companions, Jack and Meg, and even starts tentatively exploring romantic feelings.
12) But life isn't an endless sea of happiness.
13) John begins to betray signs of diminishing health due to his age-induced rheumatoid arthritis, causing worry to wrinkle Lisa's brow.
14) Amidst her academic commitments, the adventures with her friends, and her drive to understand the ocean, Lisa divides her time to nurse her ailing grandfather.
15) With dogged determination, Lisa convinces John to venture onto a sailing expedition, despite his fears stemming from his daughter's fatal mishap.
16) It is with a heavy heart and clear reluctance that John agrees, considering the painful memories of his daughter and son-in-law’s mishap.
17) Finally, after much consideration, John agrees to Lisa’s plea.
18) The grandfather-granddaughter duo then commences preparing for their journey across the Caribbean Sea.
19) Their expedition is filled with peals of laughter echoing off the water, illuminating talks about marine life, and stunning sunsets serving as a backdrop to their boat.
20) Abruptly, their smooth sail is interrupted by an ominous storm that descends onto them, erasing any signs of their past and future, making it impossible to find their way back home.
21) This presents them with a horrific reality where they face the vastness of the ocean, penning them alone amidst the vast blue canvas.
22) As the wrath of the tempest surrounds them, they must stand firm, their courage wavering but not yielding.
23) Ensuring their survival during this perilous plight, Lisa and John rely on each other unconditionally, strengthening their familial bond in the process.
24) After surviving the merciless night, a Spanish fishing vessel happens upon them the next day, saving them from their dire predicament.
25) Returning to their humble abode in Mariner's Haven, their bond now exists at a depth never explored before, a testament to their shared ordeal.
26) Upon her return, Lisa confronts the heart-wrenching loss of her parents, finally accepting their tragic demise.
27) For John, a new chapter of life unfolds where he learns to embrace his child's memories instead of shunning them.
28) Exhilarated by her sea expedition, Lisa, inspired by her love for her parents and their love for the sea, decides to study marine biology under John's loving and knowledgeable eye.
29) With the passage of time and the accumulation of experiences, Lisa's respect and adoration for the sea grow immensely, understanding the rhapsody of its breathtaking beauty and unpredictable dangers.
30) The narrative takes on a conclusion where Lisa, with a teary smile, articulates her newfound outlook on life: celebrating cherishes memories rather than letting the pain of loss consume her.

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) During Thanksgiving in Plymouth, Massachusetts, people are gathering outside the local RightMart superstore in preparation for a Black Friday sale.
2) Jessica Wright, whose father, Thomas, owns the store, lets her boyfriend, Bobby, and her friends, Evan, Gaby, Scuba, and Yulia, inside the store early through a side door.
3) The crowd outside sees them and, in a frenzy, stampedes into the store, resulting in multiple people dying, including Amanda Collins, the wife of store manager Mitch.
4) Bobby gets his arm broken when he tries to rescue someone and subsequently disappears from the group.
5) One year later, RightMart is preparing for another Black Friday sale, despite the protests of Mitch and several other residents.
6) Meanwhile, Jessica and her friends are tagged in a social media post of a Thanksgiving table with their names around it.
7) Bobby, who has broken up with Jessica, returns to Plymouth to work for his uncle after being injured in the riot, much to the chagrin of Jessica's current boyfriend, Ryan.
8) A waitress named Lizzie is attacked and killed by a figure dressed in black clothing wearing a John Carver mask.
9) The police discover that Lizzie was present at the Black Friday incident, which leads them to believe those involved in the massacre are being targeted by Carver.
10) Jessica aids the investigation by providing footage of the riot to the town's sheriff, Eric Newlon.
11) Carver rampages through Plymouth and kills several residents, including RightMart security guard Manny and high school students Lonnie and Amy.
12) Evan and Gaby are soon abducted by Carver, while Jessica narrowly avoids being killed.
13) Yulia's father decides to move their family to Florida, but he and the deputy sheriff guarding them are knocked out by Carver before he attacks Yulia.
14) Jessica and Scuba drive to Yulia's house, but are unable to stop Carver from disemboweling Yulia with a table saw before he escapes.
15) The police attempt to lure Carver out by having the Wright family and Scuba participate in a Thanksgiving parade, disguised as Pilgrims.
16) However, Carver deduces their plan and decapitates a turkey mascot before sending smoke bombs into the crowd, causing everyone to scatter in panic and giving Carver the opportunity to abduct the Wrights and Scuba in the chaos.
17) Carver then cooks Jessica's stepmother, Kathleen, alive in an oven before serving her as the "turkey" at a dinner table surrounded by his hostages and his victims' corpses.
18) Carver then bludgeons Evan to death in a livestream before Jessica and Scuba cut through their bindings and she escapes, luring him away from the others.
19) She eludes Carver by climbing over a fence and running through the woods.
20) Jessica makes it to a parade warehouse, and finds Newlon unconscious.
21) When she follows a figure wearing Carver's mask inside, she sees it is Bobby.
22) She calls Newlon to help capture Bobby, but he escapes.
23) The police soon arrive and inform them that the survivors are safe.
24) Once they leave Jessica and Newlon alone, Jessica notices the same bramble debris from the fence and the deep woods that stuck to her are also on Newlon's clothing and sneakers, realizing he is the killer.
25) Newlon reveals that he was having an affair with Amanda, who was pregnant with his child before she died.
26) This was his motive to become Carver and seek revenge on those responsible.
27) Newlon had abducted Bobby and put him in the Carver costume, intending to shoot Bobby and frame him for the murders.
28) To Newlon's horror, it is revealed that Jessica has livestreamed his confession, leading him to attack her until she is saved by Bobby.
29) As they attempt to escape in a tow truck belonging to Bobby's uncle, Newlon hooks it to a support beam and approaches them with an axe.
30) Jessica uses a musket to shoot a turkey parade balloon that was attached to a tank of flammable gas, causing an explosion that engulfs Newlon in flames.
31) The following morning, Bobby is taken away in an ambulance and Jessica reunites with Ryan, Gaby, and Scuba.
32) The authorities are unable to find Newlon's remains, leading them to believe he was incinerated in the explosion.
33) However, Jessica continues to have nightmares of a flaming Newlon attacking her.

- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)

- Change of Plans (tp2): 8.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 15.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 24.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 30.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:
### TASK RESPONSE

1. The protagonist in the story is Jessica Wright.

2. The first turning point is at sentence 3, which states: 
"The crowd outside sees them and, in a frenzy, stampedes into the store, resulting in multiple people dying, including Amanda Collins, the wife of store manager Mitch."
At this point, Jessica's condition is relatively high, around 8, as she has just let her friends into the store, but she is not yet aware of the tragic consequences of their actions.

3. The second turning point is at sentence 8, which states: 
"A waitress named Lizzie is attacked and killed by a figure dressed in black clothing wearing a John Carver mask."
Relative to the first turning point, Jessica's condition has decreased to around 6, as she is now aware of the tragic consequences of the previous year's events and the mysterious murders that are happening in the present.

4. The third turning point is at sentence 15, which states: 
"The police attempt to lure Carver out by having the Wright family and Scuba participate in a Thanksgiving parade, disguised as Pilgrims."
Relative to the second turning point, Jessica's condition has decreased to around 3, as she is now in grave danger and is being used as bait to catch the killer.

5. The fourth turning point is at sentence 24, which states: 
"Once they leave Jessica and Newlon alone, Jessica notices the same bramble debris from the fence and the deep woods that stuck to her are also on Newlon's clothing and sneakers, realizing he is the killer."
Relative to the third turning point, Jessica's condition has decreased to around 1, as she is now face-to-face with the killer and in extreme danger.

6. The fifth turning point is at sentence 30, which states: 
"Jessica uses a musket to shoot a turkey parade balloon that was attached to a tank of flammable gas, causing an explosion that engulfs Newlon in flames."
Relative to the fourth turning point, Jessica's condition has increased to around 9, as she has now defeated the killer and is safe.

7. The list of protagonist's condition at each turning point is:
[8, 6, 3, 1, 9]

8. Based on the protagonist's condition list, the story arc type can be classified as "Man in a Hole" because Jessica's condition starts relatively high, then decreases to a low point, and finally increases to an even higher point than the beginning. This arc type is characterized by a protagonist who faces a dilemma and finds a way out, ending better than at the beginning.

9. Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) The expansive city of New York serves as the backdrop for the lives of identical twins, James and Michael.
2) These 15-year-olds have learned the ropes of life under the watchful eye of their loving yet firm father, Charles.
3) Although he has kept them insulated from painful emotional entanglements, the looming shadow of their emotionally distant mother is inescapable.
4) Charles, acting as the central pillar of their life, has effectively kept them sheltered from any possible drama or trauma, particularly concerning their aloof mother.
5) In parallel to their lives, their mother, Nicole, navigates through her solitude, seldom encountering a familiar face who could break the monotony of her lonely life.
6) The life the twins know takes an abrupt turn when they receive an urgent, panic-filled phone call about their father's sudden health scare that called for immediate hospitalization.
7) Cornered by the circumstances with no other viable alternatives, the twins find themselves propelled onto a path that leads to their little-known mother's residence.
8) Nicole is overwhelmed by a tempest of emotions - surprise, fear, regret, as she grapples with the reality of her son's impending move into her quiet sanctuary.
9) As the boys reluctantly step into her apartment, they find themselves becoming unwilling inhabitants of an eerily silent world, an environment they're not accustomed to.
10) On one such unsettling evening, James stumbles upon a hidden treasure - a box tucked away beneath a rickety floorboard, crammed with old CDs and black-and-white pictures.
11) Intrigued by their accidental find, the twins set out on an exciting mission to unravel the enigma that is their mother's past.
12) Motivated by this curiosity, they embark on an adventurous mission to unveil their mother's history that had been rendered dormant for too long.
13) Gathering their courage, they decide to confront their mother with the picture album they found, each page lined with sepia-toned images of her in the limelight.
14) Nicole, taken aback by the sudden unveiling of her past, hesitates but soon starts recounting tales of her vivacious youth, her voice dripping with a melancholic form of nostalgia.
15) Incredibly moved by their mother's passionate discourse about music and performing, the twins slowly find a sense of respect for her buried deep within their hearts.
16) The plan was grandiose in its essence — organizing a city-wide concert in recognition and celebration of their mother's hidden and unappreciated talent.
17) Embracing the uphill task, they approach local businesses, knocking on countless doors to gather sponsorships to fuel their ambitious project.
18) As the concert date looms nearer, the old insecurities that once plagued Nicole try to snake back into her life.
19) Sensing the internal emotional tug-of-war within her, the boys offer her unwavering moral support, reassuring her of her latent capabilities.
20) During one such candid conversation in the dimly lit living room, they address unresolved issues, promising lifelong morale support in the face of all future adversities.
21) This emotional exchange concludes with a newfound sense of understanding, compassion, and connection, laying the foundation for a healthy familial bond.
22) The fast-approaching concert day engulfs everyone in a whirlwind of excitement, anxiety, and eager anticipation.
23) As the spotlight centers on a velvet-curtain concealed platform, Nicole, her eyes alight with an old flame, steps onto the stage.
24) Each lingering note stirs a deep emotional connection within her boys, moving the twins to tears of joy and astonishment.
25) The thunderous standing ovation rattles Nicole's spirit, leaving her overwhelmed with disbelief and gratitude.
26) The unforgettable night culminates with the family sharing a moving group hug on the stage, an iconic symbol of their newly discovered familial bond.
27) Post the concert, the twins start to gradually embrace the concept of a complete family, craving for the emotional warmth they had missed all these years.
28) Nicole's apartment, which once reeked of loneliness, is now bustling with the lively visits and chatter of the twins.
29) Now known by the thriving music community in New York, Nicole embarks on a rekindled musical journey.
30) Her mesmerizing performances at popular local venues hold everyone spellbound as her bewitching melodies waft through the air.
31) The scene wraps up with a tender family embrace on the stage, embodying unity, redemption, and the power of familial love and support.

- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)

- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)

- Change of Plans (tp2): 11.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 16.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 16.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 23.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:
### TASK SOLUTION

1. **Identify the protagonist in the story:** 
    The protagonist of this story is primarily the twin brothers, James and Michael, although their mother, Nicole, also undergoes significant development throughout the narrative. For the purpose of this analysis, we'll focus on the twin brothers as the main protagonists.

2. **First Turning Point (Opportunity, tp1): Sentence 6**
    "The life the twins know takes an abrupt turn when they receive an urgent, panic-filled phone call about their father's sudden health scare that called for immediate hospitalization."
    **Protagonist's State:** At this point, the twins are faced with uncertainty and fear due to their father's health scare. Their stable life is disrupted.
    **Protagonist's Condition:** 4

3. **Second Turning Point (Change of Plans, tp2): Sentence 11**
    "Intrigued by their accidental find, the twins set out on an exciting mission to unravel the enigma that is their mother's past."
    **Change Relative to tp1:** The twins shift from being passive recipients of bad news to becoming active participants in uncovering their mother's past. This indicates a rise in their engagement and purpose.
    **Protagonist's Condition:** 6

4. **Third Turning Point (Point of No Return, tp3): Sentence 16**
    "The plan was grandiose in its essence — organizing a city-wide concert in recognition and celebration of their mother's hidden and unappreciated talent."
    **Change Relative to tp2:** The twins now fully commit to a significant project that aims to celebrate their mother's talent. This shows a further increase in their positivity and proactive behavior.
    **Protagonist's Condition:** 8

5. **Fourth Turning Point (Major Setback, tp4): Sentence 18**
    "As the concert date looms nearer, the old insecurities that once plagued Nicole try to snake back into her life."
    **Change Relative to tp3:** Although the narrative doesn't explicitly describe a setback for the twins, Nicole's insecurities could indirectly affect them. However, given the context, this turning point is more about Nicole's state than the twins'. For the twins, their condition doesn't significantly drop as they continue to support their mother.
    **Protagonist's Condition:** 7 (Considering the twins' perspective, there's a slight decrease in their condition due to the potential for their mother's insecurities to impact their project, but it's not drastic.)

6. **Fifth Turning Point (Climax, tp5): Sentence 23**
    "As the spotlight centers on a velvet-curtain concealed platform, Nicole, her eyes alight with an old flame, steps onto the stage."
    **Change Relative to tp4:** The twins witness their mother's triumphant return to the stage, which signifies a peak in their emotional journey and connection with their mother.
    **Protagonist's Condition:** 10

7. **Protagonist's Condition List:** [4, 6, 8, 7, 10]

8. **Story Arc Classification:**
    The story arc can be classified as a "Man in a Hole" type. This classification is based on the twins starting at a relatively low point (their father's health scare), then embarking on a journey of discovery and support for their mother, facing minor setbacks, and ultimately achieving a high point of emotional connection and success with their mother's concert.

9. **Determined Story Arc Type:** Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Edmond Murray is an absent father who is called to the site of his son Ethan's disappearance.
2) He meets and briefly consoles his former wife Joan there, and promptly joins a search party before being interviewed by the police.
3) After being interviewed by Inspector Roy (the police), Edmond visits his former wife's new partner, Frank, and the two begin talking.
4) After seeing that Frank has made plans for a new home for himself and Joan (without bedroom accommodation for Ethan), and upon hearing that Frank has given Joan a Valium tablet to help her sleep, Edmond becomes irate and confrontational, accusing Frank of being responsible for his son's disappearance.
5) He assaults him in the kitchen, knocking him unconscious and calls Inspector Roy to have him look into Frank.
6) Edmond is arrested but no charges are filed, as Frank is apparently forgiving of Edmond due to his emotional stress at the moment.
7) Edmond is later met by Inspector Roy, who hides Edmond's phone in a microwave oven (so as not to be heard), and informs him that he has been taken off the case without any explanation.
8) Edmond looks through Frank's phone, which he took after knocking him out, and finds videos of Ethan leading up to the disappearance.
9) During this, he realises there is a car present in both videos, two weeks apart, hidden barely out of sight.
10) Relying on Joan's brother who works in the insurance industry, Edmond obtains the vehicle owner's address, a William O'Connor who lives at an isolated farm.
11) After arriving at the location, Edmond hears a vehicle approach.
12) Hiding, he grabs a crowbar and eventually knocks out O'Connor, and ties him up to a post in the shed.
13) After an aggressive interrogation involving a blowtorch, O'Connor reveals that he is responsible for sending pictures of children outside of schools to a kidnapping ring operated for paedophiles, who then "choose" which children will be kidnapped.
14) After being told of his son's location, at a hilltop lodge, Edmond drives to near the lodge, continuing on foot to hide his approach.
15) Joan arrives at the O'Connor farm, and finds another kidnapped girl unconscious in the back of his vehicle; Edmond had not thought to look.
16) She takes the child to the hospital, then leaves when Edmond sends a text telling her where the lodge is, asking her to contact Inspector Roy.
17) She calls Roy as she heads to the lodge herself.
18) When Edmond reaches the lodge, he sees that three members of the kidnap ring are present.
19) He incapacitates their vehicle, which proves fortuitous, as they were preparing to take an unconscious Ethan away.
20) Edmond knocks out Steven, the kidnapper who was repairing the vehicle.
21) After a game of cat and mouse with kidnappers Alan and Fergus, during which Alan mistakenly shoots Fergus dead, Edmond finds Ethan.
22) By then, Joan has arrived, and the three make a narrow escape.
23) During the escape, Edmond is shot and veers off the road when he loses consciousness.
24) As a vehicle approaches, Joan and Ethan exit, hiding behind a tree before being found by Roy, who takes them to safety.
25) Sometime later, outdoors and surrounded by water and mountains, Joan and Edmond stand with Ethan as he flies a small remote control quadcopter.
26) Inspector Roy calls out to Edmond, who bids Ethan farewell after promising that he will eventually be back to stay.
27) Roy and Edmond drive off, revealing that the outing had been a courtesy, as Edmond is under arrest for his part in the illegal activities of his company.
28) Roy states that the kidnapping network is being dismantled, with many more arrests pending.
29) He also assures Edmond that the judge will likely take into account the benefit of Edmond's actions during his court cases.

The protagonist in the story is Edmond Murray, an absent father searching for his missing son Ethan.

### 2. First Turning Point (Opportunity, tp1: 6.5)
Since 6.5 is not an exact sentence, we can average the two sentences around this point (6 and 7). 
 Sentence 6: "Edmond is arrested but no charges are filed, as Frank is apparently forgiving of Edmond due to his emotional stress at the moment."

 Relative to the second turning point, Edmond's condition has improved as he has obtained crucial information and is taking action to rescue his son.

### 5. Fourth Turning Point (Major Setback, tp4: 22.0)
 Sentence 22: "By then, Joan has arrived, and the three make a narrow escape."
 At this point, Edmond has found his son, but they are still in danger and have to make a narrow escape.

 Relative to the third turning point, Edmond's condition has improved as he has found his son, but the danger is still present.

### 6. Fifth Turning Point (Climax, tp5: 27.0)
 Sentence 27: "Roy and Edmond drive off, revealing that the outing had been a courtesy, as Edmond is under arrest for his part in the illegal activities of his company."
 At this point, Edmond has rescued his son, but he is now facing the consequences of his own actions and is under arrest.

 Relative to the fourth turning point, Edmond's condition has worsened as he is now facing the consequences of his actions.

### 7. Protagonist's Condition List
[2, 5, 7, 8, 6]

### 8. Classify the Story Arc Type
The story arc type can be classified as "Man in a Hole" because the protagonist's condition improves from a low point (2) to a higher point (8), but then drops slightly (6) at the end. This matches the "Man in a Hole" pattern, where the protagonist falls into a dilemma and finds a way out, ending better than at the beginning, but not without scars.

Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Elizabeth Johnson, a meticulously thorough and unprecedentedly diligent travel coordinator, pours every ounce of her energy into her job at Globetrotters, a premium international travel agency.
2) Her smooth-sailing life is violently upheaved when Michael, her reliable partner of five years since their chance meeting at Columbia University, terminates their romantic relationship without warning.
3) Amidst her personal turmoil, an intriguing envelope, inscribed with her name in beautiful calligraphy, appears on her doorstep.
4) The herald of change contains a formidable assignment for Elizabeth to boost the tourism industry of Bangkok, Thailand.
5) Managing her emotional turmoil, she perceives this intimidating mission as an ideal distraction to mend her bruised heart, along with being an opportunity to start afresh.
6) She travels to Bangkok, and is immediately swept away by the striking colors of Thai culture, the warmth of the locals, and the breathtaking landscapes.
7) She gradually immerses herself in the traditional Thai way of life, visiting sacred Buddhist temples, participating in local customs, and developing a palate for traditional Thai cuisine.
8) As she adjusts to this new life, she grapples with Thai, an unfamiliar language.
9) The high-intensity workload and extreme time pressure of her assignment add to the existing challenges, putting her efficiency and professionalism to the test.
10) She also has to cope with stark solitude and longing for her family.
11) However, the exquisite charm of Thailand's beaches and landscapes fuel her determination.
12) During the execution of her assignment, she befriends Achara — a local tour guide.
13) Thanks to their friendship, Elizabeth gets access to learn about the life stories of ordinary Thai people, experiencing their challenges, resilience, and passion for life.
14) She gains newfound respect for Thailand's rich cultural heritage, historic architecture, and remarkable diversity.
15) As Elizabeth's affection for Thailand grows, she finds herself inexplicably attracted to Than, a local business magnate.
16) However, she consciously restrain herself, her heart still bruised from her previous relationship.
17) She decides to focus her energies on fulfilling the challenging objectives of her assignment.
18) Her relentless dedication begins to bear fruit as Globetrotters successfully rejuvenates Thailand's global tourism image under Elizabeth's helm.
19) Amid her professional grand achievement, Elizabeth gains the fortitude to confront her tumultuous emotions for Than.
20) Than's unexpected marriage proposal forces her to address her muddled emotions head-on.
21) Although deeply moved by Than's earnestness, Elizabeth decides to decline his proposal, choosing her newfound self-love and independence over romance.
22) Having fulfilled her challenging job assignment and achieved personal growth, she returns to her life in Manhattan.
23) After her transformational experiences in Thailand, she pens her self-discovery journey into a memoir that becomes a top contender on the New York Times Bestseller list.
24) However, Michael unexpectedly re-enters her life, regretful and pleading for a second chance.
25) Although his remorseful words tug at her heartstrings, she maintains her newfound resolve, and declines his proposal.
26) Victorious over her past, she continues her quest for life, savoring her newfound self esteem and resilience.
27) Back in her Manhattan apartment, she packs for a fresh assignment in picturesque Costa Rica.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

Ground Truth Turning Points:
- Opportunity (tp1): 4.5 - Introductory event that occurs after presenting the setting and background of the main characters.
- Change of Plans (tp2): 7.5 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 11.5 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 18.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 21.5 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:

1. The protagonist of the story is Elizabeth Johnson, a travel coordinator.

2. At the first turning point (Opportunity, tp1: 4.5), the corresponding sentence is:

   At this point, Elizabeth's state is one of turmoil due to her recent break-up, but she sees this assignment as an opportunity to start anew. Her condition can be approximated as 4.

   Relative to the first turning point, Elizabeth is now more engaged and distracted from her personal issues. Her condition has improved slightly to 6.

   "However, the exquisite charm of Thailand's beaches and landscapes fuel her determination."
   Relative to the second turning point, Elizabeth is now more determined and inspired by her surroundings. Her condition has improved further to 7.

5. At the fourth turning point (Major Setback, tp4: 18.0), the corresponding sentence is: 
   "Her relentless dedication begins to bear fruit as Globetrotters successfully rejuvenates Thailand's global tourism image under Elizabeth's helm."
   Although this sentence does not describe a traditional setback, the surrounding context implies that Elizabeth faces emotional challenges, such as her growing feelings for Than and her need to focus on her work. Relative to the third turning point, Elizabeth's professional success is a positive development, but her emotional state is still complex. Her condition can be approximated as 8.

6. At the fifth turning point (Climax, tp5: 21.5), the corresponding sentence is: 
   "Although deeply moved by Than's earnestness, Elizabeth decides to decline his proposal, choosing her newfound self-love and independence over romance."
   Relative to the fourth turning point, Elizabeth has made a significant decision that prioritizes her personal growth and independence. Her condition has improved to 9.

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) On a balmy evening in the vibrant city of Barcelona, an ethereal figure emerges on the weather-beaten, cracked rooftop of a forgotten edifice in Girona.
2) This enigmatic silhouette is only known by his lethal moniker, the Slayer.
3) His laser-sharp gaze navigates from the amplified image in his state-of-the-art sniper scope, seamlessly shifting to feast on the simmering glow emitted from a plush suite within the renowned Ritz Carlton hotel, dwarfed by the vibrant cityscape.
4) The Slayer's encrypted Motorola phone springs to life, as it pulsates in his pocket.
5) The caller ID reveals a shroud of secrecy - the enigmatic Mr. X.
6) Their relationship is cloaked in professionalism, devoid of any personal connections, their identities veiled behind anonymity.
7) Digitized images of a feared crime lord, El Patron, alias 'The Boss' flash across the mobile screen in tandem with Mr. X’s veiled briefing - a clear instruction of assassination.
8) This kingpin's reign of fear extends its vipers over the beautiful city of Barcelona, a ruthless overlord tracing back to heinous acts of torture, ruthless drug trafficking, and blood-curdling murders.
9) The Slayer's past, a black and white reel of chilling experiences of a life he wants to leave behind, unexpectedly brims at the corner of his mind.
10) These blurred memories hint at traumatic experiences that he longs to repress.
11) Amidst this conundrum of the past, a poignant image of Maria, a mesmerizing Spanish belle clutching a heart-shaped locket, flashes before him.
12) Her portrait underlines a love story that the Slayer guards desperately amidst his blood-stained career.
13) Maria's symbolic laughter rekindles the nurturing aspect of Slayer’s life, where shedding his brutal past isn’t just a mere glimmer.
14) Her naive gaze draws out the assurance of a peaceful life he had solemnly promised Maria.
15) Resistance against performing another ruthless assassination engulfs the Slayer in a whirlwind of self-conflict.
16) Grinding this emotional surge into fuel, Slayer's inner turmoil spring into action, spurred by his promises to Maria.
17) Straddling the fence that encapsulates his unwillingness to kill yet again and the tantalizing allure of a seven-figure reward along with the possibility of starting afresh, the Slayer finds himself at a crossroads.
18) His mission rolls out like a merciless stub of a cigar, burned ruthily - El Patron’s fortified bodyguards, poised like a ring of iron forming an impenetrable fortress around him.
19) Shadowing from dilapidated buildings and executing precision profiling amidst stolen blueprints of the Ritz Carlton, the Slayer sketches out his lethal plan.
20) The brewing storm of suspicion in Maria's mind is evident as she grapples with the reality of the Slayer's mysterious absences and unexplained wounds.
21) The stress simmers over the edge, as a heated confrontation ensues in their shared apartment located in the Gothic Quarter.
22) She dreads the scent of gunpowder and betrayal masked and veiled behind false promises.
23) Although Maria braces herself for a lie, a flicker of hope pushes her to plead with the Slayer to abandon his deadly intent.
24) The internal battle within him is evident in her demeanour, where she lets her tears pool in her eyes, softly urging Slayer to veer away from his bloody course.
25) The course of the game takes an unexpected twist when a jittery local informant leaks an encoded warning to the Police about an assassination assignment set for El Patron.
26) The cityscape instantly metamorphoses into a tactical battlefield, the glaring lights from patrolling police cars casting ominous shadows onto the ancient city walls.
27) The feud turns horribly personal when El Patron's seasoned entourage kidnaps Maria, entrapping her in the Slayer's vortex.
28) A primal, ear-deafening roar and a deep-seeded tenacity wake within the Slayer, pushing him towards a bloodthirsty retribution.
29) The Slayer plots an audacious mission to save Maria, setting the expansive suite at the Ritz Carlton as his battlefield where time waits for no one.
30) Underneath glistening chandeliers, the Slayer manoeuvres like a shadow through guards and security cameras.
31) Every step he takes mirrors his deadly intentions.
32) The climax ensues as the Slayer wades through a heart-stopping fight - deceiving relentless police, brushing teeth with death, and hovering closer to his enemies.
33) Cornering El Patron in the glittering bathroom of the penthouse, the Slayer locks his exit route with a deadly gaze.
34) Trudging out through the smoky scene, the Slayer limps out from the gold-accented duel scene, his fresh battle scars are a testament to his title, leaving El Patron motionless amidst a storm of shattered glass.
35) Urgent sirens ring as the dispatched police officers swarm into the chaotic crime scene, their blue-flashing lights transforming the previously opulent suite into a turmoil-filled hurricane.
36) Maria's trembling arms embrace the blood-drenched Slayer, her emerald green eyes, tear-stricken, silently pleading for his survival.
37) Amidst the chaos, a sympathetic cop, Officer Lopez, silently assists their escape.
38) Even though his loyalty to the badge is paramount, the unfolding tale draws out an unusual kindness as he provides them with a nondescript black getaway van.
39) The Slayer whisks Maria and himself to an abandoned cathedral located on the city's bare outskirts.
40) Distressed and desperate, the towering bell tower stands aloof looming over their shared anguish.
41) Amid the silence of the cathedral, their flicker of renewed hope shrivels away as Maria and Slayer, fatigued and dwindling, collapse on the hard floor.
42) The morning rays break, glimpsing on the runaways resting in the back pew of the austere chapel, enmeshed within eerie fog and antique stones.
43) As each minute turns into an eternity of fear and uncertainty dangling on their survival, Maria and Slayer flees one more time, disappearing into the veil of thick towering pine woods located behind the cathedral.
44) With the vanishing criminals, the city breathes out relief.
45) Sultanah streets resuming their vibrancy, the collective release of the populace echoes through the city.
46) As the televised report fades out, a profound proclamation sits heavy in the viewers' minds.
47) A beacon of a fresh start for Maria and Slayer, released from the shackles of their fraught past highlights the dawn of a new era.

- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)

- Change of Plans (tp2): 11.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 19.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.

output:
### TASK SOLUTION

1. The protagonist in the story is the Slayer.

2. The first turning point (Opportunity) occurs at sentence 7: 
"Digitized images of a feared crime lord, El Patron, alias 'The Boss' flash across the mobile screen in tandem with Mr. X’s veiled briefing - a clear instruction of assassination."
At this point, the Slayer is in a neutral state, aware of his mission but not yet committed to it. His condition can be approximated as a 5.

3. The second turning point (Change of Plans) occurs at sentence 11:
"Amidst this conundrum of the past, a poignant image of Maria, a mesmerizing Spanish belle clutching a heart-shaped locket, flashes before him."
At this point, the Slayer is reminded of his past and his love for Maria, which makes him hesitant about his mission. His condition can be approximated as a 4, slightly worse than before due to the emotional turmoil.

4. The third turning point (Point of No Return) occurs at sentence 19:
"Shadowing from dilapidated buildings and executing precision profiling amidst stolen blueprints of the Ritz Carlton, the Slayer sketches out his lethal plan."
At this point, the Slayer has committed to his mission and is taking concrete steps to carry it out. His condition can be approximated as a 3, worse than before due to the danger and moral implications of his actions.

5. The fourth turning point (Major Setback) occurs at sentence 27:
"The feud turns horribly personal when El Patron's seasoned entourage kidnaps Maria, entrapping her in the Slayer's vortex."
At this point, the Slayer's situation has taken a drastic turn for the worse, with Maria's life in danger. His condition can be approximated as a 1, the lowest point in the story.

6. The fifth turning point (Climax) occurs at sentence 37:
"Amidst the chaos, a sympathetic cop, Officer Lopez, silently assists their escape."
At this point, the Slayer has managed to rescue Maria and escape the danger, marking a significant improvement in his condition. His condition can be approximated as a 7.

7. The list of the protagonist's condition at each turning point is: [5, 4, 3, 1, 7]

8. Based on this list, the story arc type can be classified as "Man in a Hole". The protagonist starts in a relatively neutral state, then faces a series of challenges and setbacks that worsen his condition, but ultimately manages to escape and improve his situation.

9. Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Jane Smith, a remarkable pianist with a fondness for both classical and contemporary pop fusion, discovers her true calling in creating a live music webcast.
2) On this platform, she showcases bursts of creativity on her cherished baby grand piano and engages with fans about her unique approach to crafting melodic narratives.
3) Jane quickly grows a strong following of passionate viewers ranging from every corner of the world, drawn in by her trademark smile, her thoughtful authenticity, and her avant-garde utilization of real-time comments and fan-instigated song suggestions, which she ingeniously incorporates into her evolving compositions.
4) However, an ominous unseen entity with malevolent intentions latches onto her progressively popular webcast.
5) Unbeknownst to Jane and her growing audience, this malevolent force uses her vibrant music stream as a bridge from the otherworldly to our reality, nesting within the limitless labyrinth of the Internet.
6) Soon enough, as Jane's fanbase swells and her online persona becomes a musical sensation, she starts receiving odd comments during her audience-interaction live-chat sessions.
7) These peculiar messages, disguised as intricate riddles and perplexing puzzles, begin to shape her performances in unforeseen ways.
8) Among these mysterious messages often comes from an eerie user named 'Diabolic12', a user whose cryptic influence starts steering her exuberant melodies to take on a darker, more ominous tone.
9) Jane, immersed in her artistic process, is none the wiser to the subtle manipulation of her music.
10) Simultaneously, the fans who downloaded Jane's chillingly transformed compositions begin to experience hair-raising incidents.
11) Screens spontaneously flicker, phones crash without explanation, and several even feel an unseen chilling touch against their skin, turning their comfortable living spaces into a house of haunts.
12) As the unsettling incidents grow more frequent, Jane herself becomes a target.
13) She begins to question her sanity as she experiences terrifying hallucinations involving menacing figures and hushed shadowy whispers, driving a wedge into her previously joyous creative process.
14) Driven by the eerie happenings surrounding her music and urged by her innate curiosity, Jane embarks on a tireless investigation into this bizarre phenomenon.
15) She dedicates long, nocturnal hours in the dimly lit local library, unearthing dusty old folklore that points towards something unnerving.
16) Jane comes across an ancient legend about a banished demon by the name of Zephyros, yearning to return to the mortal realm, following millennium-long banishment.
17) The chill down her spine deepens as she realizes that her music webcast seems to be the digital bridge Zephyros exploited to infiltrate into the human world.
18) Every piano riff that Jane tenderly develops, and every lyric she pours her heart into, unknowingly serves as an eerie chant in this digital era, further bolstering Zephyros's power in the earthly realm.
19) The revelation forces Jane to make a difficult decision: to abandon her passion or continue, risking her followers.
20) It takes days of agonizing deliberation for Jane to arrive at a decision.
21) Despite her profound sadness at the prospect of discontinuing her webcast, she resolves to confront the situation head-on.
22) Damning the risks, she uses her platform to alert her audience about the looming threat of Zephyros.
23) Her dedicated viewers, realizing the severity of the situation, begin getting creative.
24) They combine their collective wisdom, pool resources, and strategize on ways to combat Zephyros.
25) Zephyros cruelly morphs Jane’s inspiring melodies into abhorrent soundscapes that reverberate like tortured wails from damned souls, using distortions, screams, and excessive reverb to corrupt her music.
26) Yet, Jane and her viewers remain resolute, united in their determination.
27) They resolve to use Zephyros’ own influence against it by integrating the demon's haunting incantations into their original musical compositions.
28) Their aim is to dilute its power by distorting the very incantations the demon relies on, in the hope of sending it back where it belongs.
29) As the noble struggle intensifies, Jane's platform becomes the battleground for an unprecedented confrontation of sound and will, as they pit their unity and resolve against the horrifying might of Zephyrosism.
30) The viewers attempt to counterbalance the gruesome melodies of Zephyros with a powerful composition of their own – a beautiful sonic tapestry imbued with courage, hope, and an unyielding determination to reclaim control over their lives from the encroaching demon.
31) The collective composition, filled with sheer survival instinct and a defiant spirit, eventually dwindles the malevolent influence of Zephyros, creating an impenetrable force-field against the demon’s intrusion.
32) Defeated and trapped in its digital prison once more, Zephyros is unable to harness Jane's melodic compositions for its benefit any longer.
33) A visibly depleted but unbowed Jane re-emerges on her platform, reassuring her viewers that despite the harrowing ordeal, her spirit remains unbroken.
34) Jane earnestly pledges to continue her exploration of music, promising an added focus on supernatural safety rules to safeguard her audience.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

Ground Truth Turning Points:
- Opportunity (tp1): 4.0 - Introductory event that occurs after presenting the setting and background of the main characters.
- Change of Plans (tp2): 13.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 18.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 25.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 31.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:
### TASK SOLUTION

1. The protagonist in the story is Jane Smith.

2. At the first turning point (Opportunity, tp1: 4.0), the corresponding sentence is:
"However, an ominous unseen entity with malevolent intentions latches onto her progressively popular webcast."
Here, Jane is still unaware of the entity and its intentions. Her condition is roughly an 8 out of 10 because her webcast is popular, but the presence of this entity poses a potential threat.

3. The second turning point is Change of Plans (tp2: 13.0). The corresponding sentence is:
"She begins to question her sanity as she experiences terrifying hallucinations involving menacing figures and hushed shadowy whispers, driving a wedge into her previously joyous creative process."
Jane's condition has worsened relative to the first turning point because she is now directly experiencing the negative effects of the entity's presence. Her condition is roughly a 4 out of 10.

4. The third turning point is Point of No Return (tp3: 18.0). The corresponding sentence is:
"Every piano riff that Jane tenderly develops, and every lyric she pours her heart into, unknowingly serves as an eerie chant in this digital era, further bolstering Zephyros's power in the earthly realm."
Jane's condition has worsened slightly relative to the second turning point because she now understands the true nature of the threat, which increases her stress and worry. Her condition is roughly a 3 out of 10.

5. The fourth turning point is Major Setback (tp4: 25.0). The corresponding sentence is:
"Zephyros cruelly morphs Jane’s inspiring melodies into abhorrent soundscapes that reverberate like tortured wails from damned souls, using distortions, screams, and excessive reverb to corrupt her music."
Jane's condition has worsened further relative to the third turning point because Zephyros is now directly affecting her music and her audience. Her condition is roughly a 2 out of 10.

6. The fifth turning point is Climax (tp5: 31.0). The corresponding sentence is:
"The collective composition, filled with sheer survival instinct and a defiant spirit, eventually dwindles the malevolent influence of Zephyros, creating an impenetrable force-field against the demon’s intrusion."
Jane's condition has significantly improved relative to the fourth turning point because she and her audience have successfully countered Zephyros's influence. Her condition is roughly a 9 out of 10.

7. The list of Jane's conditions at each turning point is: [8, 4, 3, 2, 9].

8. Based on this list, the story arc type can be classified as "Man in a Hole" because Jane's condition initially worsens (from 8 to 2) but ultimately improves to a higher state (9) than at the beginning of the story. This is characteristic of the "Man in a Hole" story arc, where the protagonist falls into a dilemma but finds a way out, ending better than at the beginning.

9. The determined story arc type is: Man in a Hole.

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) In a suburban town in the Southern United States, a high school student named Krista is a member of her school's theater program.
2) In her childhood, she produced short videos with her next-door neighbor, the recently graduated Adam.
3) Adam has since started a YouTube channel to which he uploads videos of himself providing demonstrations on using various models of firearms that he owns.
4) However, his videos are receiving little attention online, and his father disapproves of his focusing on his YouTube presence rather than finding a job elsewhere.
5) Nito, a skateboarder, attends the same school as Krista.
6) One day, while idling outside the apartment where he and his apathetic guardian live, Nito meets a fellow tenant named Yoni, who invites Nito to a party that night after seeing him perform a kickflip.
7) At the party, Nito interacts with Krista, who earlier that evening had watched videos of Nito skateboarding online.
8) Later on, police officers arrive to break up the party.
9) In the commotion, a male partygoer tries to grab Krista, and Nito fights him off.
10) Krista escapes but Nito is arrested.
11) After being released from jail, Nito is picked up in a car by Yoni and Yoni's friends Lena and Jarrett.
12) Yoni, Lena, and Jarrett convince Nito to help them steal items such as Hot Pockets and perfume.
13) During school, Nito and Krista grow closer; he tries to show her how to skateboard, and she teaches him how to imitate being slapped and choked for stage purposes.
14) While working on a performance inspired by a past experience Nito had with a parakeet, he and Krista share a kiss.
15) In an effort to attract more viewers and subscribers to his YouTube channel, Adam produces a dramatized video of himself detailing an experience he claimed to have had wherein he fended off an attack by a wild warthog using a firearm.
16) When the video receives a number of negative and insulting comments, Adam becomes infuriated and records a video of himself angrily responding to and threatening the commenters.
17) Lena drives Nito, Yoni, and Jarrett to the house where her boss lives, and demands that they break in and retrieve her vape pen, which her boss confiscated from her.
18) Her boss is Adam's mother, and when Nito, Yoni, and Jarrett enter the house, Adam hears them from his upstairs bedroom.
19) Jarrett begins to ascend the stairs leading up to the house's second floor, and Adam fatally shoots him from the top of the stairs with a rifle.
20) After Adam proceeds to shoot Yoni, Nito attempts to flee, but is shot and killed by Adam after running outside.
21) Krista, walking home from school with a friend, watches Nito die and sees an armed Adam standing in the doorway to the house.
22) The incident is covered by the news, prompting Adam's YouTube channel to receive a surge of popularity.
23) Online commenters and local police officials refer to Adam as a "hero" for standing his ground against the three intruders.
24) Adam continues to make firearms-based videos that prove successful with his online followers, while Krista becomes an emotional wreck at school over the loss of Nito.
25) When Adam is invited to speak at a conference about firearms, Krista attends and follows him into a restroom to confront him.
26) She forces him to put his hands around her neck and she screams, drawing the attention of police officers in the building.
27) Adam is detained, and the video he made in which he threatens his YouTube commenters is leaked to the public.
28) Meanwhile, Krista returns to her theater classes with a sense of closure.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)

Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) The film begins with the scene of Jordan Miller, an extraordinary nine-year-old child, tossing and turning in bed, ensnared in an uproarious dream involving a bumbling tooth fairy with oversized wings that seem to function less effectively than a broken fan.
2) The absurdity of the dream resonates with an underlying essence of fear, causing Jordan to wake up in a chilly sweat.
3) The narrative takes us to an affluent neighborhood where Jordan resides in a tastefully furnished bungalow.
4) On the exterior, he is adored by individuals within his community, cherished by friends, but each night is a sequence of absurd yet terrifying dreams weaving an eerie tapestry in his young mind.
5) To help the child grapple with these overwhelmingly vivid dreams, Jordan's parents seek the expertise of Dr. Rose, a revered therapist renowned for her humanistic approach interlaced with an uncompromising staunchness.
6) Dr. Rose, through her empathetic counselling, proposes a unique idea to Jordan- maintaining a journal of his nightmares.
7) A striking black leather-bound book then becomes the deposit box for Jordan's self-stylized dream sequences.
8) An otherwise regular school routine takes an eerie twist when Jordan's dream-orchestrated alternate reality starts wiggling its way into routine activities like fetching milk from the cafeteria or completing assignments, layering them with portions of the ridiculous.
9) Amidst the chaos, Jordan's black leather journal documenting his so-called “Circus of Nightmares” finds its way into 'Book Haven', a bookstore frequented by locals, by an accidental misplacement.
10) Patrons of 'Book Haven' stumble upon Jordan's journal mistaking it for an eccentrically illustrated masterpiece, leading to an unexpected surge in its popularity and swiftly taking it on a merry ride to the bookstore’s bestseller list.
11) Max Wilde, a Hollywood director known for his penchant for the whimsical, finds himself intrigued by this bizarre bestseller.
12) Recognizing its potential, he envisions a comedy goldmine waiting to be unearthed by turning Jordan's nightly theatre into a script.
13) Max springs an unexpected proposition on Jordan, illuminating his plan to metamorphose Jordan's journal into a screenplay.
14) The prospect is initially met with resistance from Jordan but slowly, he begins to see its comedic potential.
15) Jordan finally agrees to Max's unusual project.
16) His apprehension is gradually replaced with anticipation, hoping to convert his fears into a comedy of errors.
17) Filming begins with Jordan's preposterously imaginative characters like extraterrestrial purple kangaroos and wing-embellished pigs morphing into reality, eliciting peals of laughter from the set.
18) The once-quiet film set, now transformed into Jordan's dream turned reality with singing frogs, tumbling tooth fairies, and clumsy aliens, becomes a breeding ground for staged confusion and unrehearsed hilarity.
19) Witnessing his fears transformed into a comedy act strengthens Jordan's resolve to face his underlying alarums head-on, helping him progressively heal with every burst of laughter on set.
20) The roller-coaster journey of filming the ridiculous finally concludes, leaving Jordan relieved, and, curiously, entertained.
21) A grand movie premiere is arranged at Hollywood's prestigious theatre.
22) It showcases the marvelous transformation of Jordan's grotesque nightmares into a comedic decree, leaving the audience doubled with laughter.
23) The Jordan that once feared nights, now stands in the spotlight as a sensational comedy figure, laughing at the absurdities of his fears and turning them into popular amusement.
24) At the rooster's call, he abruptly wakes up, chuckling at the newfound realization that his rise to stardom was all part of his ever-vibrant dreamscape.
25) Now brimming with humorous twists thanks to his dreams, Jordan awaits his next appointment with Dr. Rose, thrilled to share his transformed dreams with her.
26) In a reality-twisting sequence, Jordan wakes up once again and accepts that his entire journey from losing the journal to the grand movie premiere was a dream within a dream.
27) With his fears splayed open and laughed at, Jordan wakes up feeling invincible and liberated from latent fears, replaced by an infectious, unshakeable grin.
28) The film wraps up on a cheerful note with Jordan sharing his latest dream escapades with Dr. Rose.

Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Spiderhead is a state of the art penitentiary experimenting with the effects of research chemicals.
2) The test subjects, technically prisoners of the state, are volunteers for the project aiming to reduce their sentence time.
3) The program is overseen by the sympathetic and hospitable Steve Abnesti, along with his assistant Mark.
4) The prisoners have their own rooms, do chores, and are free to roam without guard supervision.
5) The subjects go through daily test runs of various drugs, all of which alter their emotions and their perceptions of their surroundings.
6) Inmate Jeff, still reeling from having killed his friend whilst drunk driving, is given N-40, a "love drug", which distorts his senses and drives him to have sex with two of his fellow inmates.
7) Steve asks him to choose which one of them to give Darkenfloxx, a drug that induces intense fear and psychological pain.
8) He declines to choose, claiming he feels nothing in particular for either one of them after the effects of the love drug had worn off.
9) Mark helps Steve administer some N-40 to himself.
10) The next day, Steve brings Jeff into the observation room and tells him that the "higher ups" have decided that the younger of the two women, Heather, must be injected with a dose, though it will only last 5 minutes.
11) Jeff reluctantly agrees, and to his horror, Heather commits suicide while on the Darkenfloxx after she damages her MobiPak, the device that administers the drugs.
12) This causes Mark to doubt their work in the facility.
13) As Steve rushes out of the projection room, he drops his keys.
14) Jeff unlocks Steve's desk compartment, discovering that there are no "higher-ups": the prison is run by Abnesti Pharmaceuticals, Steve's company.
15) The drugs were named from a bingo card.
16) Steve and Jeff get high together on a laughing drug, as Steve also has a MobiPak installed.
17) Steve tells Jeff that his father abandoned him as a child.
18) Jeff confesses to Lizzy, an inmate he is close with, that he not only killed his friend in the car accident but his girlfriend as well.
19) Lizzy hugs him and they kiss.
20) Steve notices Jeff's feelings for Lizzy.
21) Mark becomes doubtful of Steve's motives, and he breaks down when Jeff confronts him.
22) When Steve asks Jeff to administer Darkenfloxx to Lizzy, Jeff takes control of Steve's MobiPak, reveals that Mark has spiked his Mobipak with Darkenfloxx, and forces him to admit the true goal of the program: testing a compliance drug, B-6.
23) The other drugs are merely side projects being used to put B-6 to the ultimate test: whether or not they would harm their love when commanded to.
24) The entire time inmates had been consenting to the various tests, they had really been under the influence of the obedience drug.
25) In addition, Steve informs Jeff that he had in fact finished his sentence seven months previously, while Lizzy's appeal for release had passed the previous week.
26) Jeff forces Steve to open the door of the main entrance to free Lizzy and then tries to order him to hand over the pocket knife.
27) Steve resists the order (as complying would be killing the project, "the only thing he has ever loved"), and instead takes his phone and enables all four vials of Darkenfloxx in Lizzy's MobiPak, causing her to behave hysterically and attempt suicide.
28) The two fight for control and Jeff is able to disarm Steve, damaging his MobiPak in the process.
29) Jeff rushes to save Lizzy, successfully removes the vials of Darkenfloxx and tells her he loves her, but Steve gets up and orders the other inmates to apprehend Jeff and Lizzy.
30) They are able to escape from Spiderhead after overpowering some of the other inmates and locking the main door behind them.
31) Mark and the police are now approaching the island as Steve escapes on his floatplane, but he joyously crashes into a mountain as he is now high off of his damaged MobiPak.
32) Meanwhile, Jeff and Lizzy take the remaining motorboat and escape.
33) In a voice-over, Jeff comments that no drug can bestow self-forgiveness, instead it must be worked on and chosen.

- Climax (tp5): 31.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").

2. The first turning point occurs at sentence 6: "Inmate Jeff, still reeling from having killed his friend whilst drunk driving, is given N-40, a 'love drug', which distorts his senses and drives him to have sex with two of his fellow inmates." 
   At this point, Jeff is struggling with guilt from his past actions and is now being manipulated by the love drug. His condition can be approximated as a 2.

   Relative to the first turning point, Jeff's condition worsens as he is now faced with the horrific consequences of his actions under the influence of the prison's experiments. His condition can be approximated as a 1.

The fourth turning point occurs at sentence 27: "Steve resists the order (as complying would be killing the project, 'the only thing he has ever loved'), and instead takes his phone and enables all four vials of Darkenfloxx in Lizzy's MobiPak, causing her to behave hysterically and attempt suicide."

Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) During a July 2020 COVID-19 lockdown in London, friends Haley, Jemma, Radina, Emma, Caroline, and Teddy join the weekly Zoom call they have been using to stay in touch.
2) Haley has arranged for them to partake in a virtual séance led by the medium Seylan, who emphasises that they should not disrespect the spirits, though only Haley takes it seriously.
3) Teddy is forced to leave the call when his girlfriend Jinny disconnects him.
4) Jemma claims to feel intense tension around her neck and begins to cry, explaining that she feels the presence of a school friend who killed himself by hanging.
5) Seylan's internet cuts out and disconnects her from the call, prompting a laughing Jemma to admit to the group that she made her deceased friend up because she was getting bored, which angers Haley.
6) The remaining members begin to experience terrifying phenomena: Haley's chair is violently pulled backwards by an unseen force, the legs of a hanging corpse briefly appear in Caroline's attic when she goes to investigate a noise, and Emma's wine glass shatters even though nobody is holding it.
7) Haley points her instant camera down the hallway to take a photo of her living room, which shows a ghostly figure hanging from the ceiling.
8) As the girls panic, Haley manages to get back in touch with Seylan and tell her what happened, prompting Seylan to ask the spirit a series of yes or no questions; using this method, she quickly confirms that the spirit is not a friendly one.
9) Seylan explains that Jemma's prank, which involved fabricating a deceased person, may have led a tulpa to take on the guise of the deceased person and wear his identity like a mask that allows the demon to pass into the world of the living.
10) She gives them instructions on how to close the séance, but the demon interrupts her and she is disconnected again before the girls attempt to close the circle using her advice.
11) Relieved that the ordeal seems to be over, the members of the group begin to leave the call.
12) Radina leaves the room, unaware of her boyfriend Alan's body hanging behind her.
13) Caroline's Zoom background, which shows a looping video of her doing chores, continues playing as the real Caroline suddenly has her face smashed into the camera.
14) Forgetting to switch off a filter that superimposes masks and face paint onto her, Emma turns her camera towards her living room, where the filter places a kabuki mask on an invisible figure which then turns to look at her.
15) She runs away and scatters flour on the floor, showing the footprints of the demon approaching her.
16) Her kitchen cupboards burst open before the demon attacks her, but she escapes into her bedroom.
17) Radina attempts to flee after Alan's body drops down behind her, but the demon kills her by throwing her into the wall.
18) Noticing that Caroline is typing gibberish in the chat, Haley and Jemma watch as her camera turns back on to show her being killed by the demon repeatedly smashing her head into her keyboard while she pleads for help.
19) Haley and Jemma argue and blame each other before Haley is pulled out of the room.
20) Jemma, who lives around the corner from Haley, immediately leaves her home to help.
21) Teddy returns to the call to see that only Emma remains, and a warning pops up to remind the group that the call will end in 10 minutes unless they upgrade to the premium version of Zoom.
22) Unaware of everything that has occurred, Teddy believes Emma is pranking him, but he is attacked by the demon after it takes the form of a horrifying humanoid figure.
23) He is chased into his garden, where he sees Jinny being lifted into the air before her neck is snapped and her body falls into the swimming pool.
24) He runs away and hides, using a lighter to see where he is going, but the demon distracts him with an eerie music box his brother used to prank him with as a child.
25) The demon then knocks him down and he drops the lighter, causing a fire that burns him to death.
26) Emma, now the only person still active in the call, fearfully turns her camera towards the door of her room after it opens.
27) She throws a blanket, which drapes itself over an invisible human shape.
28) She opens her window to escape, but trips and falls to her death.
29) Jemma breaks into Haley's home and checks the Zoom call on Haley's laptop to see that Emma and Teddy are dead.
30) The demon smashes a wine bottle over her head and starts to destroy the kitchen, but she recovers and finds Haley hiding under her desk, with the pair attempting to escape the house using the flash of Haley's instant camera to light the way.
31) The demon appears in the final flash of light, taking the form of a mutilated human, and rushes at them as the Zoom call timer expires.

- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)

- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

- Major Setback (tp4): 20.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 31.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").

Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
