3) Engrossed in their animated Zoom discussion on Jane Austen's classic, "Pride and Prejudice", they dissect the societal and romantic undertones of the said piece.
4) Their shared banter and varied interpretations pave the way for delightful twists, such as Arnold's struggle with his slow, countryside internet which, more often than not, churns out pixelated versions of his friends' faces.
5) Charlie, meanwhile, is in a perpetual battle with the mute/unmute feature of Zoom calls, his comments hilariously mistimed.
6) When the pandemic restrictions lift, they unanimously decide to abandon their screens for the tangible charm of in-person gatherings for their beloved book discussions.
7) Deciding over email, the task escalates into a hilarious confusion of sorts.
8) Creating a robin-hood round of literary puns and subtle nuances, each manages to misconstrue the meeting spot.
9) Ben, interpreting the coded emails in his own style, ends up in a crowded Barnes & Noble, his frazzled expressions disappearing amongst towering bookshelves.
10) Arnold, extracting his own meaning from the exchanges, situates himself amid the quiet atmosphere of the uptown library, oblivious to the comic chaos unfolding.
11) Charlie finds himself at a boisterous bar christened "Bookers".
12) His sincere misunderstanding lands him amidst raucous laughter rather than whispered book discussions.
13) Earl, drawing his own conclusions, puzzlingly stands gazing at a gigantic billboard advertising a new John Grisham thriller, his confusion adding to the comic relief.
14) They finally agree upon meeting at Arnold's posh, countryside mansion, nestled amidst the serene hills.
15) The journey towards Arnold's abode unravels through lush green trails, blooming apple orchards, and an unforeseen detour dissecting an alluring, mystical neighborhood.
16) Their joyful expedition takes a fantastic twist as they follow the eye-catching instructions given by quaint residents, dressed in clothing reminiscent of Medieval times.
17) The unexpected turn of events culminate in their participation in a local costume competition, where they blend in with an array of characters spun from folklore and mythology.
18) They mistakenly assume it is a literary cosplay event, and decide to participate.
19) Their combined intellect and literary prowess assist them in unveiling a cryptic riddle, a part of the enjoyable competition.
20) To their shock, solving the riddle guides them to an unexpected treasure - an unpublished, sepia-tinged manuscript attributed to the legendary J.D.
21) Salinger.
22) Initially ecstatic, the group quickly debates the credibility of their find, their discussion seasoning with friendly, hilarious contention.
23) The situation escalates with comical chaos as their debate spirals into a slapstick brawl, each accusing the other of orchestrating a prank.
24) The comic absurdity peaks when the actual treasure seekers, a squad of over-excited, adventure-hungry local teenagers stumble upon our bewildered bookworms.
25) Coming to a resolution, they offer to return the manuscript after a tantalizing glimpse, their curiosity piqued by their literary find.
26) The teens stipulate a half-hour with their treasure, this suspense amplifying the hilarious tension amongst our scholarly friends.
27) Racing against time, the quartet delve headfirst into the manuscript, their interest escalating with each turn of the fragile pages.
28) Following a briefly savored reading, they resentfully return the manuscript, their minds buzzing with theories pertaining to the unplumbed narrative.
29) Continuing their drive to Arnold's estate, they remain ignited with the stimulating recount of their recent, unforeseen escapade.
30) On arriving, they settle with Arnold's signature 'spiked cider', their conversations weaving in delightful tales about their favorite books and the extraordinary day.
31) Each lends their unique perspective to rehash their shared adventure, their interpretations painting distinct, vibrant hues to today's roller-coaster story.
32) A hearty toast ensues to their enduring friendship, the unexpected plot twists of their post-lockdown lives, and the blissful freedom of in-person gatherings.
33) They make a pact to overcome any obstacles, cementing their decision to persist with the face-to-face meetings, irrespective of the locations.
34) Their first real-life book club gathering wraps up on a high note, ensuring each subsequent meeting would carry its own sense of thrilling anticipation.
35) As their gathering ends, another cryptic email appears, reigniting their enthusiasm for yet another unintended wild ride.
36) They scrutinize the email meticulously, slipping again into their beloved habit of miscommunication.
37) They make individual deductions, unanimously arriving at the thrilling conclusion of an invitation to a revered book fair in Paris.
38) This correspondence triggers a sense of déjà vu, reminding them of the morning's email fiasco and the ensuing adventure.
39) Sensing another potential blunder, they decide to rely on younger, tech-savvy assistance to avoid a ridiculous repetition.
40) They head to Ben's teenage son, Ryan, who dissolves their French misapprehensions caused by the email.
41) Ryan reveals through fits of laughter that they've simply won a hometown lottery by their favorite bookstore "Bound & Leaf" offering promotional discounts.
42) Treasuring their email gaffes as a cherished in-joke, they collectively decide to return to their beloved paperbacks and in-person discussions, vowing to ditch future emails correspondence.
43) As twilight thickens, the friends unwind, their raucous day coming to a close, leaving behind a medley of unforgettable laughs and memories.
44) Their final toast highlights their strengthened friendships, applauding their shared decision to cherish tradition, printed books, and in-person camaraderie over digital mediums.
45) They get back to their respective lives, the sweet reminiscence of their shared adventure providing a reprieve from daily commitments.
46) Each friend, upholding their signature comic timing, throws a closing punchline, ensuring the hilarity remains long after their departure.
47) The film hints at the next meeting being at Charlie's charming Irish pub, the men playfully guessing the potential misadventures it might lead to.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

Ground Truth Turning Points:
- Opportunity (tp1): 6.0 - Introductory event that occurs after presenting the setting and background of the main characters.
- Change of Plans (tp2): 14.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 20.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 26.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 44.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:

1. **Identify the protagonist in the story**: The protagonists in the story are a group of friends - Ben, Charlie, Arnold, and Earl - who share a love for books.

2. **First Turning Point (Opportunity)**: Sentence 6 - "When the pandemic restrictions lift, they unanimously decide to abandon their screens for the tangible charm of in-person gatherings for their beloved book discussions."
   - At this point, the protagonists are filled with excitement and anticipation for their in-person book discussions, which they haven't been able to do due to the pandemic. Their state is one of optimism and eagerness. 
   - Protagonist's condition: 8

3. **Second Turning Point (Change of Plans)**: Sentence 14 - "They finally agree upon meeting at Arnold's posh, countryside mansion, nestled amidst the serene hills."
   - At this point, the protagonists have overcome their initial miscommunication and are looking forward to meeting at Arnold's mansion. They are still excited but have also learned to navigate their communication challenges. 
   - Protagonist's condition: 9

4. **Third Turning Point (Point of No Return)**: Sentence 20 - "To their shock, solving the riddle guides them to an unexpected treasure - an unpublished, sepia-tinged manuscript attributed to the legendary J.D. Salinger."
   - At this point, the protagonists are ecstatic about their discovery and feel like they've stumbled upon something incredible. Their excitement peaks as they realize the significance of their find. 
   - Protagonist's condition: 10

5. **Fourth Turning Point (Major Setback)**: Sentence 26 - "The teens stipulate a half-hour with their treasure, this suspense amplifying the hilarious tension amongst our scholarly friends."
   - At this point, the protagonists face a setback as they have to return the manuscript and are only allowed a short time to study it. They feel a sense of disappointment and frustration. 
   - Protagonist's condition: 6

6. **Fifth Turning Point (Climax)**: Sentence 44 - "Their final toast highlights their strengthened friendships, applauding their shared decision to cherish tradition, printed books, and in-person camaraderie over digital mediums."
   - At this point, the protagonists have reflected on their adventure and realized the value of their friendship and shared experiences. They are grateful for the journey and the lessons learned. 
   - Protagonist's condition: 9

7. **Protagonist's Condition List**: [8, 9, 10, 6, 9]

8. **Story Arc Classification**: Based on the protagonist's condition list, the story arc type is **Double Man in a Hole**. The protagonists start in a good condition (8), rise to a better condition (9), reach a peak (10), fall into a setback (6), and then recover to a good condition (9). This pattern of rise, fall, and recovery is characteristic of the Double Man in a Hole story arc.

9. **Determined Story Arc Type**: Double Man in a Hole

input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) The introductory scenes of the movie unfurl as the story of John Smith, a hardened CIA agent who has dealt with countless covert operations worldwide, comes to life.
2) His world takes an unexpected turn when he receives a jarring, late-night phone call bearing the news about a childhood comrade, Peter Johnson.
3) The distressing details unveil chilling allegations against Peter, accusing him of murdering his genial wife Anna, adored by her students thanks to her career as a schoolteacher, and their bubbly 7-year-old son, Sam.
4) The reports also insinuate that Peter, unable to bear the guilt, terminated his own life in their ornate Victorian-style abode, concluding this horrendous narrative.
5) The melancholic ambience of disbelief and confusion haunt John, leaving him unable to digest the fact that Peter, a man he had known to be full of empathy and always known for his gentle demeanor, could ever end up performing such monstrous acts.
6) Bolstered with the trust and loyalty he felt for Peter, John takes it upon himself to unravel the layers of this ominous mystery.
7) With a hopeful heart, he steps on this treacherous path vying for a more luminous and credible truth.
8) He finds himself gravitating back towards the calm, picturesque coastal town of Stonewall, brimming with sweet childhood memories, quite unchanged with its inherent charming appeal.
9) As John returns to Stonewall after years of being away, the taut community of hardworking lumberjacks, worn-out sailors, and friendly shopkeepers who had known him as a young lad, greet him with an array of expressions from startled surprise to barely concealed suspicion.
10) Not easily perturbed by the lukewarm interactions with the locals, John commences his self-appointed investigation, filled with an unwavering resolve and unyielding determination to uncover the truth.
11) In his quest, he analyses Peter's last two days of life.
12) He finds himself stepping into the poignant stillness of the beautiful but tragic Victorian house now owned by the deafening silence and initiates detailed interviews with the people who had last seen Peter, such as the local grocery store owner, the obliging postman, and the staunchly professional town doctor.
13) John, as he delves deeper into the crypt of the crime scene, uncovers covert messages in the form of coded letters and complex notes.
14) These intriguing clues, imagined by Peter, intertwine elegantly with the memories of their unique, secret language from their shared childhood.
15) Beneath the tranquil surface of Stonewall, he stumbles upon an oblique web of conspiracy that hints at clandestine secrets hidden even deeper than he had initially perceived.
16) Amidst fluctuating revelations that begin to challenge his understanding of the town, John finds himself scrutinizing the people of influence, particularly the town's swaggering, dismissive Sheriff who seems far too eager to close the case as a regular family tragedy and bury the dire implications forever.
17) A palpable tension begins thickening between John and the intimidating figure of the Sheriff.
18) An imminent disagreement augments between the two, their perspectives clashing, drawing a line between them in the sand.
19) John's determination to delve further into the incongruities surrounding Peter's tragic end puts him tooth to tooth with the mighty Sheriff and the powerful mayor of the town, both notorious for ruling Stonewall with iron fists.
20) Undeterred by the mounting hostility and veiled threats from the influential locals, John stubbornly traces the path paved by Peter's clandestine hints towards the truth he was so desperate to reveal.
21) His relentless pursuit yanks off the shroud of deception to uncover a shocking reality: Stonewall, under its facade of tranquility, was infested with a nest of criminal activities that included illegal trading, money laundering, and more.
22) As pieces of the grand puzzle clicked into place, John unearths damning evidence, implicating the town's Sheriff and a respected local businessman as key players in the criminal conclave, revealing them at the heart of the insidious conspiracy.
23) The plot takes a steep turn as John begins to paint a different picture of Peter.
24) A picture not of a vile murderer, but that of a passive scapegoat, distorted within the frames of a duplicitous setup masterminded by those who had sworn to uphold peace and justice.
25) Aware of their secret operations being under potential threat of exposure, the adversaries sit up and take notice of John's investigation.
26) John's once peaceful existence swiftly gives way to a thrilling struggle for survival as he gets embroiled in these grave circumstances, turning his life into a rollercoaster of adrenaline-fueled challenges, spiralling into a dangerous game of survival against formidable foes.
27) A high-stakes face-off engulfs the screen as John, the audacious opponents and the rattled townsfolk — torn between their long-trusted town leaders and the unprecedented revelations — come head-to-head in a startling climax.
28) Slowly, the townsfolk start rallying behind John, swayed by Peter's incriminating evidence exposed posthumously and John's unwavering determination to unmask the villains and restore the truth.
29) With their web of deceit rapidly unravelling, a confession is reluctantly extracted from both the Sheriff and the prominent businessman, cornered by the silent judgement of their own people.
30) With their sins laid bare, the antagonists are promptly arrested, the extent of their fall from grace watched by the shock-stricken town.
31) Vindication arrives for Peter, his rightful legacy restored, casting him as a martyred whistleblower instead of the villain that he was made out to be.
32) As the once mighty leaders of Stonewall are led away, a palpable sigh of relief breaks through the tension that had strangled Stonewall for far too long, driving away the oppressive atmosphere.
33) With Peter's grave in the background and the sweeping landscape of Stonewall unfolding in front of him, John promises to protect their shared home.
34) He vows to defend it against corruption and restore peace and dignity in honour of his departed friend.
35) The credits roll as the camera pans across the town, capturing Stonewall restored to its original beauty yet irrevocably changed.
36) It stands at the dawn of a new era, cleansed of its corruption and deceptions, with justice standing tall as its new guardian.

output:
### TASK SOLUTION

1. The protagonist in the story is John Smith, a hardened CIA agent.

2. At the first turning point (Opportunity, tp1: 3.0), the sentence is: 
"The distressing details unveil chilling allegations against Peter, accusing him of murdering his genial wife Anna, adored by her students thanks to her career as a schoolteacher, and their bubbly 7-year-old son, Sam."
The protagonist's state is one of shock and confusion. He has just received disturbing news about his childhood friend, Peter. Approximate condition: 3

3. The second turning point (Change of Plans, tp2: 6.0) is: 
"Bolstered with the trust and loyalty he felt for Peter, John takes it upon himself to unravel the layers of this ominous mystery."
The protagonist's state has changed as he has now decided to take action to uncover the truth about Peter's death. He is more determined and focused. Approximate condition: 5

4. The third turning point (Point of No Return, tp3: 11.0) is: 
"In his quest, he analyses Peter's last two days of life."
The protagonist's state has changed as he has now fully committed to investigating Peter's death. He is more invested in the mystery and is taking concrete steps to solve it. Approximate condition: 7

5. The fourth turning point (Major Setback, tp4: 24.0) is not exactly at sentence 24 but the idea is introduced at this point: 
"The plot takes a steep turn as John begins to paint a different picture of Peter."
However, the sentence that better corresponds to the major setback is sentence 26: 
"John's once peaceful existence swiftly gives way to a thrilling struggle for survival as he gets embroiled in these grave circumstances, turning his life into a rollercoaster of adrenaline-fueled challenges, spiralling into a dangerous game of survival against formidable foes."
The protagonist's state has changed as he now faces a significant threat to his life. He is in a much more precarious situation. Approximate condition: 2

6. The fifth turning point (Climax, tp5: 30.5) is: 
"With their sins laid bare, the antagonists are promptly arrested, the extent of their fall from grace watched by the shock-stricken town."
The protagonist's state has changed as he has now achieved his goal of uncovering the truth and bringing the perpetrators to justice. He is in a much better situation. Approximate condition: 9

7. The list of protagonist's conditions in chronological order is: [3, 5, 7, 2, 9]

8. Based on the protagonist's condition list, the story arc type can be classified as "Man in a Hole". The protagonist starts in a relatively bad condition (3), improves slightly as he takes action (5), and then improves further as he becomes more invested in the mystery (7). However, he then faces a significant setback (2) before ultimately achieving a much better condition (9). This follows the typical pattern of the "Man in a Hole" story arc, where the protagonist faces a challenge, overcomes it, and ends up in a better situation.

9. Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) In 1998 Los Angeles, Winona lives with her parents, has dropped out of college and works for her father as his secretary.
2) Her relationship with her father Richard and mother Pamela isn't great.
3) Winona’s best friends are Addie and Stephanie.
4) She also has a boyfriend, Frank.
5) Winona goes out with Addie, Cameron (Addie's boyfriend), Stephanie, and Frank.
6) Frank leaves them to get food and doesn’t return.
7) Upset, Winona considers being done with Frank.
8) Later, they see a group of young men where Winona meets Ben.
9) One day Winona visits her pediatrician Dr. Cotton due to pain in her armpit which had lasted for a month.
10) Dr. Cotton does an examination of her and determines she may have an anxiety disorder and suggests she visit a therapist.
11) Winona visits therapist, Dr. Monroe.
12) During the session, Dr. Monroe asks her about her relationship with her mother which causes Winona to break down into tears.
13) Winona begins dating Ben, and he invites her to his place where he lives with his roommate/ex-girlfriend Jen.
14) They are hosting a party for Jen’s mom.
15) Winona accidentally wishes Jen’s mom a happy birthday, which leads to everyone gasping and Ben having to explain to Winona that Jen’s mom had her cancer go into remission a year ago.
16) Winona is humiliated and asks Ben to help sneak her out.
17) Winona starts to attend group therapy sessions with Dr. Monroe and other people.
18) She doesn’t feel that she needs to be there and sees it as a waste of time.
19) Pamela and Richard plan to downsize.
20) They ask Winona to move out and find her own place.
21) She is annoyed but decides to start looking for her own place and a job.
22) She applies to her favorite book store, as well as a clothing store.
23) However, when she has to do an interview at the clothing store, Winona begins to suffer a panic attack.
24) In a daze, she grabs lip gloss and applies it before collapsing.
25) The interviewer calls Pamela to get Winona.
26) Winona tells Stephanie about the panic attack, but she appears to have a callous attitude towards it.
27) At work, Winona realizes she forgot to give her dad a file.
28) She goes to the parking garage and sees Richard leaving with another woman.
29) Thinking he is having an affair, Winona attempts to drive after him, but she gets worried since she only has a learners permit, and she unsuccessfully tries to get a stranger to ride with her.
30) Later, Winona has another attempt at following her dad, but she gets distracted from talking to herself and she rear ends the woman’s car.
31) Richard steps out and isn’t mad, but more concerned when he sees that Winona suffered a minor head injury.
32) She declines to get help from the hospital.
33) Richard explains that the woman is a real estate agent showing him other houses.
34) Ben takes Winona out on a date.
35) He later invites her to meet his mother Hayley, whom Ben says also has bouts of anxiety attacks.
36) Winona ends up having an uncomfortable conversation with Hayley.
37) Winona has lunch with her parents, who are talking about the new house they found.
38) Winona is excited to move there but Richard and Pamela make it clear that the place is only for the two of them.
39) Winona gets angry at them and storms off.
40) She later joins Ben and suggests that they move in together since he also wants to move away from Jen, but Ben says that he doesn’t think it will work out between them because he plans to be a doctor and thinks his life is moving in a different direction from Winona’s.
41) She angrily tells him off before deciding to walk home.
42) When Winona gets home, she begins to suffer another panic attack.
43) It becomes more intense and uncontrollable, and she can’t go into her room without vomiting.
44) Pamela and Richard find Winona in their bedroom crying, where she starts to blame them for why she is like this since they never got her treatment when she needed it, as well as them selling the house and forcing her to move out.
45) They take her to Dr. Cotton, who gives Winona a pill to treat her anxiety.
46) Richard then admits that he once suffered a panic attack after Winona was born, but he and Pamela agree to help Winona get through this.
47) Winona starts to get her life back on track.
48) She plans to go back to college and writes to her professor on returning back.
49) She also maintains her friendship with Addie and Stephanie.

- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)

Ground Truth Turning Points:
- Opportunity (tp1): 5.0 - Introductory event that occurs after presenting the setting and background of the main characters.
- Change of Plans (tp2): 10.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 16.5 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 25.5 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 43.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:
Let's break down the story and analyze the protagonist's condition at each turning point.

**1. Identify the protagonist in the story**
The protagonist of the story is Winona.

**2. First turning point (Opportunity, tp1): Sentence 5**
 Sentence 5: "Winona goes out with Addie, Cameron (Addie's boyfriend), Stephanie, and Frank."

At this point, Winona is out with her friends and boyfriend, seemingly having a good time. Her condition is relatively neutral, but since she's with people she cares about, let's approximate her condition as a 6 out of 10.

**3. Second turning point (Change of Plans, tp2): Sentence 10**
 Sentence 10: "Dr. Cotton does an examination of her and determines she may have an anxiety disorder and suggests she visit a therapist."

Here, Winona's condition has taken a turn for the worse. She's just been informed that she may have an anxiety disorder, which is a significant concern. Her condition has dropped to a 4 out of 10.

**4. Third turning point (Point of No Return, tp3): Sentence 16 (approximated to 16.5)**
 Sentence 16: "Winona is humiliated and asks Ben to help sneak her out."

At this point, Winona has suffered a humiliating experience and is seeking help from Ben. Her condition has dropped further to a 3 out of 10.

**5. Fourth turning point (Major Setback, tp4): Sentence 25 (approximated to 25.5)**
 Sentence 25: "The interviewer calls Pamela to get Winona."

Winona has just suffered a panic attack and is unable to complete her interview. Her condition has hit a low point, approximated as a 2 out of 10.

**6. Fifth turning point (Climax, tp5): Sentence 43**
 Sentence 43: "It becomes more intense and uncontrollable, and she can’t go into her room without vomiting."

Although this sentence describes a intense and uncontrollable panic attack, it marks a turning point where Winona's condition begins to improve with the help of her parents and therapy. Her condition is still low, but it's the beginning of her recovery, approximated as a 4 out of 10.

**7. Protagonist's condition list**
Here is the list of Winona's condition at each turning point:

[6, 4, 3, 2, 4]

**8. Classify the story arc type**
Based on the protagonist's condition list, we can see that Winona's condition initially drops from a neutral state to a low point, but then begins to recover. This pattern matches the "Man in a Hole" story arc type, where the protagonist falls into a dilemma and finds a way out, ending better than at the beginning. However, since the ground truth classification is "Rags to Riches" and the protagonist does end up in a better state than at the beginning, and the lowest point is at the fourth turning point and not at the beginning, we can see it as a "Rags to Riches" story arc type with the first part of the story being the description of the rags.

**9. Determined story arc type**
Rags to Riches

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) When his vehicle breaks down outside of Hayesville, North Carolina, a quiet drifter is picked up by mechanic Jed Love, who takes him to Willy's Wonderland, a once-successful abandoned family entertainment center.
2) Owner Tex Macadoo offers him to work as a night-shift janitor in exchange for repairing his vehicle before he and Jed leave him locked inside the restaurant.
3) Meanwhile, teenager Liv Hawthorne attempts to burn the restaurant but she gets handcuffed by her parental guardian, Hayesville's sheriff Eloise Lund.
4) When Lund leaves, Liv's friends Chris Muley, Kathy Barnes, Aaron Powers, Bob McDaniel, and Dan Lorraine release her.
5) As the Janitor begins his duties, the restaurant's eight now-withered animatronic mascots —Willy Weasel, Arty Alligator, Cammy Chameleon, Ozzie Ostrich, Tito Turtle, Knighty Knight, Gus Gorilla, and Siren Sara— are revealed to be alive and homicidal.
6) Ozzie attacks the Janitor, who beats him to death with a mop.
7) While her friends douse the perimeter with gasoline, Liv enters the restaurant through the vents to get the Janitor out.
8) Simultaneously, the Janitor is attacked by Gus in the restrooms; he curb stomps his face into a urinal, killing him.
9) In the vents, Arty chases Liv but she escapes into a fairy-themed room where Sara kidnaps her.
10) Liv manages to fend off Sara and encounters the Janitor, who ignores her warnings about the animatronics and refuses to leave.
11) Outside the restaurant, Liv's friends climb to the roof, which collapses and causes them to fall inside.
12) While the Janitor cleans the kitchen, Liv explains that Willy's Wonderland was originally owned by Jerry Robert Willis, a notorious serial killer.
13) With his seven cannibalistic colleagues, he often slaughtered unsuspecting families, but the authorities eventually discovered them.
14) They committed a satanic ritual to transfer their souls into the animatronics before commiting suicide.
15) When Liv finishes, several animatronics awaken and attack the group.
16) In the ensuing chaos, Knighty impales Aaron with his sword, Tito and Sara devour Dan alive, and Arty mauls Kathy and Bob to death in a party room.
17) With Liv standing in awe, the Janitor decapitates Knighty and breaks Arty's jaws, killing them both.
18) As Cammy stalks him in an arcade, Chris calls Lund for help; she goes to the restaurant with deputy sheriff Evan Olson upon learning that Liv is there.
19) On the way, Lund reveals to Evan that after Willy's Wonderland was shut down, the animatronics continued murdering people around Hayesville until she, Tex, and Jed made a deal with them.
20) Over the years, they tricked random drifters into cleaning up the restaurant, offering them as human sacrifices in order to stop the animatronics' killing spree.
21) Liv's parents were among the victims and a guilty Lund adopted her.
22) When the Janitor and Liv arrive at the arcade, Cammy snaps Chris' neck, killing him.
23) They subdue Cammy and attempt to leave before Lund and Evan stop them.
24) Lund handcuffs the Janitor and leaves him to die as Evan takes Liv away.
25) While driving back, Evan is killed by a stowaway Tito while Liv escapes.
26) In the restaurant, the Janitor subdues Sara and twists Cammy's head, killing her.
27) Enraged, Lund tries to lure Willy to kill the Janitor, only for Willy to tear her in half.
28) Willy and the Janitor fight each other until the Janitor kills Willy by ripping his head off.
29) The next morning, Tex and Jed return to the restaurant and find it completely clean, with the animatronics missing.
30) The Janitor receives his repaired vehicle and invites Liv to accompany him.
31) While Tex and Jed discuss planning to re-open Willy's Wonderland, Sara suddenly appears and sets their car on fire with gasoline.
32) All three are killed in a massive explosion that also destroys the entire restaurant.
33) As the sun rises, the Janitor and Liv drive out of the town, killing a wandering Tito along the way.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Berta, a Honduran refugee, is about to be raped by the Los Angeles street gang that kidnapped her.
2) Her brother Oscar and half-brother Emilio assault the house where she is being kept and free her, but Oscar is shot before they can escape.
3) Emilio, who believes Oscar to be dead, forces Berta to leave with him, then delays the police as she flees.
4) She hides under the front porch of a nearby house owned by John Henry, a large, quiet man.
5) John takes her in over the objections of his father, BJ, who reluctantly helps translate her story.
6) Although BJ mocks his sentimentality, John offers to help her.
7) Eventually, Emilio arrives at John's house, looking for Berta.
8) Emilio, an American, explains that he was on the way to drop off his half-siblings at a shelter when Berta was kidnapped.
9) Disgusted that Emilio was planning to ditch his family, BJ becomes closer to Berta.
10) Berta insists that they return to the gangsters' house to look for Oscar, but Emilio insists that Oscar is dead.
11) After Emilio describes a tattoo, John realizes that the gangsters are part of a crew run by his cousin Hell.
12) Back in the 1990s, John quit the gang after realizing Hell's ambition would never allow the cycle of violence to end.
13) John contacts Hell, who gives Emilio and Berta 24 hours to leave the city.
14) Hell betrays them and sends assassins to kill everyone in the house, though they are instructed to leave John alive long enough that he can watch Hell execute Berta.
15) BJ and Emilio both die protecting Berta, but ride-or-die chick Savage botches Hell's plans when she stops John from assaulting Hell.
16) Enraged, Hell leaves John for dead and orders Savage to be killed.
17) John reasons that Hell, who never leaves anyone alive at the scene of a crime, wants him to suffer further.
18) John accidentally shot and maimed Hell when they were teenagers, and John now refuses to use pistols.
19) After recovering, John grabs a sledgehammer and leaves to rescue Berta, whom he believes Hell still plans to kill in front of him.
20) John's grandmother initially refuses to give him Hell's address but finally acknowledges that Hell is beyond redemption.
21) John kills several gangsters with his sledgehammer, interrupting Savage's execution and leaving Hell short on muscle.
22) Hell grants Savage a reprieve and orders her to kill John.
23) Although conflicted, she confronts John, who cripples her but leaves her alive.
24) The final confrontation between John and Hell draws a crowd.
25) Taking advantage of this, Hell brings out Berta and Oscar, whose public executions he believes will demonstrate his dominance.
26) Although the rest of the neighborhood is scared, a boy named Deydey defies Hell and assists John.
27) Savage kills Hell's remaining bodyguard while John kills Hell, then collapses, as Berta thanks him for rescuing her and Oscar.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

Ground Truth Turning Points:
- Opportunity (tp1): 4.0 - Introductory event that occurs after presenting the setting and background of the main characters.
- Change of Plans (tp2): 9.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 13.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 14.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 27.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:
### TASK SOLUTION

1. **Protagonist Identification:** 
   The protagonist in this story is Berta, a Honduran refugee.

2. **First Turning Point (Opportunity):** 
   Sentence 4: She hides under the front porch of a nearby house owned by John Henry, a large, quiet man.
   **Protagonist's State:** At this point, Berta has just escaped from her kidnappers and is hiding for her life. Her condition is precarious and vulnerable. 
   **Condition Score:** 2

3. **Second Turning Point (Change of Plans):** 
   Sentence 9: Disgusted that Emilio was planning to ditch his family, BJ becomes closer to Berta.
   **Change in Protagonist's State:** Berta now has some allies and a safer place to stay, improving her situation slightly. However, her brother's fate remains unknown, and her future is still uncertain.
   **Condition Score:** 4

4. **Third Turning Point (Point of No Return):** 
   Sentence 13: John contacts Hell, who gives Emilio and Berta 24 hours to leave the city.
   **Change in Protagonist's State:** Berta's situation becomes more urgent and dangerous as Hell threatens her and her companions. However, with John's help, she also gains a potential protector and a plan to address her situation.
   **Condition Score:** 6

5. **Fourth Turning Point (Major Setback):** 
   Sentence 14: Hell betrays them and sends assassins to kill everyone in the house, though they are instructed to leave John alive long enough that he can watch Hell execute Berta.
   **Change in Protagonist's State:** Berta faces her most dangerous and desperate situation yet as Hell's assassins attack. Her condition plummets as she is on the verge of being captured and executed.
   **Condition Score:** 1

6. **Fifth Turning Point (Climax):** 
   Sentence 27: Savage kills Hell's remaining bodyguard while John kills Hell, then collapses, as Berta thanks him for rescuing her and Oscar.
   **Change in Protagonist's State:** Berta is finally rescued, and her tormentors are defeated. She is safe and grateful, marking a significant improvement in her condition.
   **Condition Score:** 9

7. **Protagonist's Condition List:** [2, 4, 6, 1, 9]

8. **Story Arc Classification:** 
   The story arc type based on the protagonist's condition list is Cinderella. This classification is chosen because the protagonist starts in a low state (2), rises slightly (4), improves further (6), faces a significant setback (1), but ultimately achieves a much higher state (9). This pattern of rise, fall, and ultimate rise matches the Cinderella story arc type.

9. **Determined Story Arc Type:** Cinderella

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Sarah Blackwood, a battle-hardened FBI agent based in Portland, Oregon, finds herself haunted by the aftermath of a personal disaster, having narrowly escaped death in a car bomb explosion.
2) On a seemingly ordinary day, Sarah receives a mysterious envelope containing a series of horrifying images revealing violent plans, marked by a cryptic wolf symbol.
3) Portland soon becomes a playground for unconventional crimes and high-end robberies, each marked with the wolf symbol.
4) She recognizes the wolf emblem tied to her past, bringing back traces of Anthony Lobo, her adversary assumed deceased.
5) A trusted colleague delivers the news that Anthony Lobo, the dreaded mastermind she thought was defeated, is causing the current chaos.
6) As fear threatens to overcome her, Sarah decides to confront it head-on, enlisting the help of Jacob Hayes, a new agent in the FBI.
7) They discover that Lobo plans to create widespread panic at the annual Christmas parade in downtown Portland.
8) The scale of the new crimes reminds her of her traumatic past, filling her with terror.
9) Their investigation uncovers a traitor within their ranks funneling top-secret information to Anthony Lobo.
10) Feeling betrayed, they decide to handle the predicament themselves.
11) The situation gets riskier when Sarah gets a threat over a call from Lobo, who taunts her and promises carnage at the city’s Christmas event.
12) Undeterred, Sarah and Jacob work tirelessly to piece together leads across the city.
13) At the annual Christmas parade, they spot Lobo among the crowd, beginning a high-stakes game of wits.
14) Sarah faces her lifelong nemesis in a final showdown.
15) With Lobo finally apprehended, Portland is safe.
16) The victory comes at a price, as Jacob falls severely injured in the confrontation.
17) The ordeal strengthens rather than breaks her, and Sarah promises to continue fighting against evil.
18) Haunted by her past, Sarah instead opts for resilience, finally making peace with her history.
19) Accepting her fear as part of her nature, she prepares for future trials and swears never to back down.
20) The film concludes with a stronger Sarah, readying herself for new challenges in her career.

- Point of No Return (tp3): 10.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 11.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 14.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:
### TASK SOLUTION

1. The protagonist in the story is Sarah Blackwood, a battle-hardened FBI agent.

2. The first turning point (Opportunity) is at sentence 2: "On a seemingly ordinary day, Sarah receives a mysterious envelope containing a series of horrifying images revealing violent plans, marked by a cryptic wolf symbol." 
At this point, Sarah's state is one of disturbance and concern, having just received a mysterious and ominous message that disrupts her daily life. Her condition can be approximated as a 4.

3. The second turning point (Change of Plans) is at sentence 6: "As fear threatens to overcome her, Sarah decides to confront it head-on, enlisting the help of Jacob Hayes, a new agent in the FBI." 
Relative to the first turning point, Sarah has now decided to take action against the threat, indicating a sense of determination and resilience. Her condition has improved slightly to a 5.

4. The third turning point (Point of No Return) is at sentence 10: "Feeling betrayed, they decide to handle the predicament themselves." 
At this point, Sarah has discovered a traitor within their ranks and has decided to take matters into her own hands, indicating a sense of resolve but also increased danger and risk. Her condition has worsened slightly to a 4.

5. The fourth turning point (Major Setback) is at sentence 11: "The situation gets riskier when Sarah gets a threat over a call from Lobo, who taunts her and promises carnage at the city’s Christmas event." 
Relative to the third turning point, Sarah is now facing a more direct and personal threat from the antagonist, increasing her sense of fear and vulnerability. Her condition has worsened to a 2.

6. The fifth turning point (Climax) is at sentence 14: "Sarah faces her lifelong nemesis in a final showdown." 
At this point, Sarah is confronting her greatest fear and enemy, but she is also taking action and fighting back, indicating a sense of courage and determination. Her condition has improved significantly to an 8.

7. The list of protagonist's condition in chronological order is: [4, 5, 4, 2, 8]

8. Based on the protagonist's condition list, the story arc type can be classified as "Man in a Hole". This is because the protagonist starts in a relatively low state (4), faces setbacks and challenges that worsen her condition (2), but ultimately recovers and achieves a higher state (8) through her determination and resilience.

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Portland, Maine, dons a celebratory aura during the holiday season, to the point where pulchritudinous twinkling lights and cheery garlands pervade the quainter Old Port and the tranquil Back Cove.
2) The culmination of this merriment lies within the sprawling corridors of the annual mega-market, the Portland Mall, replete with holiday decorations and exuding vibrancy, which is known for its annual post-Thanksgiving bonanza sale.
3) The coterie of enthusiastic shoppers attending ranges from Jake, a film studies student at the local university with an inherent curiosity, to Maria, a diligent single mother of two working tirelessly as a nurse, Frank, the retired detective with a sharp intellect, the quiet and introspective Ellie from the city library, and Roger, a citywide famous real-estate tycoon.
4) Equipped with pre-prepared lists of desired items, each shopper plots their trajectory to exploit the grand sale to its fullest.
5) A large digital clock positioned above the entrance ticks down the seconds until midnight, at which the automated glass doors promptly swing open and inaugurate the event.
6) A carefully choreographed chaos engulfs the mall as folks dash in, quickly grabbing everything from the latest electronics to high-end clothes off the painstakingly arranged shelves.
7) The bustling scene, however, soon devolves into horrific pandemonium as a harrowing scream reverberates throughout the multi-storey complex.
8) The source of the chaotic screaming is the gruesome discovery of a mutilated body in the linen department, nestled candidly next to a shipment of festively scarlet tablecloths.
9) The response is swift, with city law enforcement closing off all egress points and transforming the previously free-roaming shopping center into a foreboding containment area.
10) Avid mystery enthusiast Jake, piqued by the gruesome turn of events, steps forward to provide his layman investigative nous to the incident.
11) Jake's resolve is not without fear as he stumbles upon more victims strategically hidden amid the retail spaces and service corridors labyrinth, their grim sight inducing a sense of looming dread.
12) Fear and chaos coalesce; the excited chatter and elation are replaced with terrified pleas and declarations of innocence as people realize their precarious position.
13) Amid the burgeoning tumult, the seemingly unrelated group of Jake, Maria, Frank, Ellie, and Roger find common ground and unite to unveil the murderer's identity.
14) The team's sleuthing leads them to suspect the mall's Santa Claus, who has maintained an unsettling stillness at his lavishly decorated grotto since the lockdown began.
15) They decide to question the costumed figure, despite his seemingly innocuous demeanor.
16) Their plan takes an unexpected turn when a moment of confrontation snowballs into a breathless pursuit through the jumbled maze of shoppers and merchandise.
17) The chase extends unexpectedly, through frozen aisles and carries them to the snowcapped rooftop of the formidable structure.
18) With few viable alternatives remaining, they venture into the dimly-lit, labyrinthine underground service tunnels, illuminated sporadically with emergency light.
19) Each person draws upon their individual talents, converting their deadly pursued-pursuer duel into a high-risk team campaign.
20) Frank's experience in law enforcement proves crucial in planning their strategy and Ellie's knowledge of the mall layout, acquired from numerous visits, proves invaluable.
21) Maria’s ability to think on her feet helps them maintain a steady pace while Roger, with his authoritative personality, helps the team remain focused and engaged in the daunting task.
22) Their collective efforts allow them to corner the suspicious Santa Claus amidst the colorful, toy-laden section of the mall.
23) An intense confrontation unfurls amidst rows of gleaming, dancing elves and the red-and-white clad figure.
24) With their backs against the wall, they are galvanized by the raucous noise of the police swat team forcing entry into the mall.
25) Their relentless efforts finally bring the murderer to justice, returning a semblance of calm to the vast, resplendently lit shopping complex.
26) The mall’s doors are reopened; a collective sigh of relief vibrates through the chilled December night air as the ordeal concludes.
27) Jake, Maria, Frank, Ellie, and Roger, having been bled dry mentally and physically, are reunited with anxious family members who had been waiting on tenterhooks outside the mall.
28) Despite parting ways after the experience, the bonds of shared trauma etch an unspoken understanding onto their faces, forever linking their shared nightmares.
29) The Portland Mall, with its dazzling holiday illuminations and festive decorations, now stands as a chilling reminder of the horrific incident.
30) Its once lively storefronts now deserted, its food court lit eerily by stubbornly remaining Christmas lights, the re-opened mall casts a lingering, gloomy shadow over their festive spirit.

- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

- Opportunity (tp1): 8.0 - Introductory event that occurs after presenting the setting and background of the main characters.
- Change of Plans (tp2): 10.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 13.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 23.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 25.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").

### TASK RESPONSE

### 1. Identify the protagonist in the story
The protagonist of this story is not explicitly mentioned as a single person. Instead, the narrative focuses on a group of characters, including Jake, Maria, Frank, Ellie, and Roger, who come together to solve a mystery. For the purpose of analyzing the story arc, we will consider this group as a collective protagonist.

### 2. First turning point (Opportunity, tp1): Sentence 8

The protagonist's condition at each turning point can be approximated as follows: [2, 4, 6, 3, 8]

Based on the protagonist's condition list, we can classify the story arc type as "Man in a Hole". instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Police officers Shaw and Washington enter a rural bar, The Last Exit, following what appears to be a bloody massacre.
2) They find one female survivor, Shiloh, too scared to speak to them.
3) Flashing back to the night before, The Last Exit is having a typical evening.
4) Les, the owner and bartender, contends with Rudy, a conspiracy theorist who lusts over Shiloh, the other bartender.
5) Travis, a cowboy and swindler, challenges Rudy to a game of pool but is distracted by local DJ Rylee, who rebuffs his advances.
6) A suspicious man in the corner named Jared watches over the bar before Cece enters.
7) Cece asks to borrow Travis' car, which he is opposed to as Cece is with another man, Frank.
8) Travis relents and Cece does drugs in the bathroom, unaware that John is in one of the stalls.
9) The patrons are startled by the sound of gunshots outside.
10) Les takes a baseball bat to scare of what she assumes are kids with firecrackers, but is shot in the head by the crossfire.
11) Five violent heroin addicts force their way into the bar: Gail, Mac, Will, Lo, and Frenzy.
12) After they assume control of the bar it becomes apparent that a second group outside is after them.
13) This group wears flesh masks and violently murders Frank after pulling him out of his car.
14) The lieutenant of the group, Red, uses a megaphone to coerce the people inside to give up one of their own, who they deem is a monster, before his group begins barricading the bar.
15) Inside, Shiloh weeps over Les' body, and Gail forces her and the patrons to stand together by the pool table while Mac checks the bar for other entrances.
16) John successfully hides under the bathroom sink.
17) At the bar, Gail watches the group outside over the CCTV, recognizing their leader as Hunter, who removes his mask and taunts the group inside.
18) Will is suffering from withdrawals, worse than any of the others, and he rests behind the bar.
19) The addicts struggle to maintain control over the patrons, leading to Frenzy assaulting Travis and Rudy.
20) Cece plots to turn the addicts against each other, but Frenzy catches on and beats her up in the bathroom.
21) Through flashbacks it's revealed that a man named Carl rescued Gail from a drug den, and she became the adoptive mother to his adoptive son, Will, who suffered a condition that only heroin would remedy.
22) Mac serves as Carl's number two, and only very recently did the group meet Frenzy and Lo, who are a couple.
23) Lo calms Frenzy's hot demeanor, though Lo herself is deeply disturbed and admits to having murdered animals in her youth.
24) It's revealed that Carl was dating Hunter's ex-wife, and that Hunter is Will's real father.
25) A monster murdered Hunter's ex-wife, leading him down a rabbit hole chasing clue after clue, trying to find this creature.
26) Eventually Hunter discovered what Carl was up to, and after making arrangements with Red's people and secretly colluding with Frenzy to trap Carl's group at The Last Exit, Hunter shot and killed Carl immediately preceding the events of the story.
27) Inside the bar, tensions between the group escalate.
28) Cece accidentally gets Frenzy to reveal her betrayal to Gail, giving Cece the opportunity to steal Gail's revolver.
29) As Cece attempts to take control of the situation, Lo sneaks up behind her and beats her to death with a pool cue.
30) Exposed, Frenzy and Lo attempt to kill Mac, but Frenzy accidentally shoots Lo.
31) Will is shot in the crossfire, and Gail comforts him until his passes away.
32) Suddenly, Will's body begins to twist and contort, terrifying the patrons of the bar.
33) It is clear that Will is the monster, leading Frenzy and Rylee to attempt to escape.
34) Will fully transforms into a large, slimy creature covered in bodily spikes and sharp teeth protruding from his face.
35) Will immediately rips apart Frenzy before turning on the patrons, killing Jared, Travis, and Rylee.
36) Shiloh tries to hide under a pool table, and Rudy sacrifices himself to save her.
37) Gail attempts to calm Will, hoping underneath the monster that he's still there.
38) Her words fail, and Mac attempts to kill Will before being torn apart himself.
39) The last one standing, Gail succumbs to her death at Will's monstrous hands.
40) Will finds John hiding in the bathroom and tears him apart before returning to the pool table where Shiloh is hiding.
41) He scratches her arm in an attempt to reach her, but after consuming so much he's become weakened, and Shiloh impales him with the broken pool cue.
42) Will transforms back to normal, apologizing to Shiloh.
43) Before he dies he tells her he became the monster after he was scratched by one.
44) Outside Red sends in Lori and Gerry to investigate the bar.
45) Shiloh stabs Gerry but Lori shoots her.
46) As Lori looms over Shiloh, her eyes transform and she kills Lori.
47) Outside, Hunter and Red are shocked as they see Shiloh, now in monster form, break through the barricades and murder Red and the rest of his group.

input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Daniel, a 10th-grade student characterized by his shy nature at Jefferson High School, was on cloud nine when he received the news that their traditional red-brick suburban house would be all to himself as his parents and eight-year-old brother, Peter, announced they were off to celebrate their 15th wedding anniversary.
2) He felt an adrenaline rush at the thought of bidding adieu to his quiet existence and truly testing his mettle in dealing with the trials of solitude.
3) Alone-time fantasies swirled in his head, from planning a mouthwateringly delightful BBQ dinner, launching into a nail-biting gaming competition to inviting his equally shy friends for some grown-up conversation.
4) These ideal scenarios were, however, quickly overshadowed by his anxiety as he realized he hadn't constructed a thorough plan for his dream weekend.
5) Helpless and anxious, he found himself seeking advice from Max, his best friend known for his liveliness and outgoing personality.
6) Max, an ever-ready plot twister, proposed a thrilling plan of throwing a party at the formerly peaceful suburbia.
7) Despite a ripple of fear, Daniel found himself being swayed by the enthusiasm of his friend, leading him to agree to host his very first bash, hoping the venture will help him shed his introverted shell.
8) In the thrilling second part of the narrative, zealous Max seized the opportunity to announce their casual home-based get together to the student body on the school's local radio station—WJHS.
9) Max went overboard, calling it the event of the year, intensifying the attraction of their planned small gathering and unintentionally making it the talk of the school.
10) Terror gripped Daniel as the thought of his humble home swarmed with euphoria-driven teens became the highlight of the weekend gossip.
11) Daniel, hoping to craft an image of maturity, tried to recreate complicated cocktail recipes from a trending YouTube bartender.
12) Max, evident with his excellent negotiation skills, managed to woo the popular school band, ‘The Bleachers,’ promising them with free drinks and pizza for their performance at the party.
13) Amidst all the hullabaloo, Daniel has a series of encounters filled with comic elements with his peculiar classmates--Kevin the Karate Kid and Lucy, the admired cheerleader to who Daniel had a secret crush.
14) The long-awaited night finally arrives, and Daniels' quiet home is teaming with excited students, thanks to Max's overenthusiastic radio promotion.
15) The quiet residential area was momentarily transformed into a zoo filled with relentless teenagers, a whirlwind of fragrances, and deafening music echoing through the still night.
16) A highlight from the night involved Kevin discovering another fanatical karate enthusiast, leading to an impromptu but amusing combat situation in the backyard.
17) Another hilarious incident includes the school's Sci-fi club pet monkey converted the living area into a chaotic playground, adding fuel to the ongoing madness.
18) Meanwhile, Lucy's experiment with an elaborate new hairstyle ends in disaster, leading to her locking herself in the bathroom.
19) As chaos unfolds, Daniel accepts the reality of the situation and unknowingly begins to take on the role of a band leader.
20) Amid this chaos, Daniel manages to find unanticipated joy and a surge of assertiveness that aligns with his initial dreams of self-reliance.
21) Dawn begins to break, the crazy party atmosphere starts to tone down.
22) Lucy finally steps out of her self-created bathroom prison and views Daniel in an entirely different light, appreciating his stamina and ability to manage such an overwhelming event.
23) As sunlight slowly seeps in, the devastating aftermath of the chaotic night, revealing the once-clean home in a mess that urgently demands attention.
24) The daunting task of restoration is faced head-on by Daniel with resourcefulness as he swiftly deals with the scattered red plastic cups, sticky soda stains, and leftover pizza boxes.
25) He persuades Kevin to help with the backyard cleanup, leveraging his comic-book fascination, repairing the wreckage from the previous night’s unplanned Karate match.
26) Daniel's resolve and a hint of luck helps to restore his house back to its former pristine state right in time for his parents' arrival.
27) Upon their arrival, Daniel's parents are pleasantly surprised to find glimpses of a previously unnoticed responsible side of their son filled them with pride.
28) With newfound courage and self-assurance, Daniel begins to visualize his transformation from the background character to an influential figure.
29) As we zoom out from the repair work and a montage of Kevin fixing the garden, a small teaser for the next plotline is revealed.
30) A discarded party invite to ‘Becky’s Bash’ is discovered under a pile of leftover supplies, hinting at the possibilities in the upcoming episodes.
31) Thus, the story ends, teasing about the prospects of Daniel’s popularity evolving further as a party host, transforming from his introverted roots to a confident leader.
32) 'Becky's Bash' proposes a fresh challenge for Daniel and his newfound assertiveness.
33) How Daniel manages to maintain his reputation as a party organizer will be an exciting turn for the upcoming episodes.
34) His success or failure lies in the outcome of these challenges.
35) Subtly woven into the storyline is the potential romance between Daniel and Lucy, adding depth to his character.
36) The young love is subtly hinted within the journey, maintaining an equilibrium between humor and romance.
37) With 'Becky’s Bash’ offering a whole new challenge for Daniel, the narrative sets the stage for the sequel.
38) New characters such as Becky to be introduced in the sequel generate anticipation among the audience.
39) The follow-up series promises another laughter-filled, edge-of-the-seat narrative filled to the brim with suspense and unpredictability.
40) Whether ‘Becky's Bash’ will surpass Daniel's house party or whether Daniel uses his newfound skills to turn it into a grand event boosts curiosity for the sequel.

Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) In 2011, astronauts Brian Harper, Jocinda "Jo" Fowler, and newcomer Alan Marcus are on a Space Shuttle mission to repair a satellite.
2) A mysterious swarm of alien technology attacks the orbiter, killing Alan and knocking Jo unconscious before tunneling into the surface of the Moon.
3) Brian, the only witness to the swarm, returns the crippled shuttle to Earth, but his story is dismissed and he is fired from NASA.
4) Ten years later, conspiracy theorist K.C.
5) Houseman, who believes that the Moon is an artificial megastructure, secretly uses a research telescope.
6) He discovers that the Moon's orbit is veering closer to Earth, and tries to share his findings with the disgraced Brian.
7) NASA also discovers the anomaly, but K.C.
8) goes public on social media, leading to a global panic.
9) Jo is now NASA's deputy director, launching a spacecraft on an SLS Block 1 rocket to investigate the abnormality.
10) The same alien swarm attacks, killing all three lunar astronauts after they drop a probe into a kilometers-deep artificial shaft that has opened up on the Moon's surface.
11) As the lunar orbit deteriorates, the Moon falls closer and closer to the Earth, causing seismic and gravitational disturbances.
12) Jo meets former NASA official Holdenfield, who reveals that Brian was discredited due to a NASA coverup dating back to Apollo 11; during the first Moon landing, a two-minute radio blackout was meant to conceal evidence of pulsating lights on the surface.
13) Apollo 12 revealed that the Moon is hollow, and a military EMP device created to kill the swarm was abandoned for budgetary reasons.
14) With help from her ex-husband General Doug Davidson, Air Force Chief of Staff, Jo requisitions the EMP and rescues retired Space Shuttle Endeavour from a museum to serve the new mission: to correct the Moon's orbit and destroy the swarm.
15) Brian, K.C., and Jo launch with the EMP, narrowly escaping to orbit as a tsunami destroys Vandenberg Air Force Base.
16) They reach the interior of the Moon, revealed to be a Dyson sphere powered by a white dwarf at its center.
17) The Dyson sphere's AI operating system explains to Brian that billions of years ago, humanity's technologically advanced ancestors were eradicated by a rogue AI; they built the Moon as an Interstellar ark to create and seed life on Earth, but the swarm — the malicious AI — discovered the Moon and is siphoning energy from its power source, destabilizing its orbit.
18) Meanwhile, Brian's son Sonny, Jo's son Jimmy, and his caretaker Michelle try to reach Doug's military bunker in the Colorado mountains, finding Brian's ex-wife and Sonny's mother Brenda, her husband Tom, and their step-family.
19) Escaping disasters caused by the Moon's proximity and fighting off other survivors, the group finds safety in a mountain tunnel.
20) When his youngest daughter runs out of oxygen, an injured Tom gives her his own, suffocating to death as the Moon strips away the local atmosphere.
21) The president orders a nuclear strike on the approaching Moon, but Doug refuses to comply, with debris collapsing the bunker shortly thereafter, presumably killing Doug and everyone inside.
22) As the swarm only attacks organic life in the presence of electronic activity, K.C.
23) lures the swarm away from their spacecraft with their lunar module, sacrificing himself to detonate the EMP.
24) Jo and Brian return to Earth, reuniting with their families, and the Moon's power is restored, returning to its regular orbit, but now shed of its rocky exterior.
25) Reconstructing K.C.
26) 's consciousness, the Moon's operating system appears to him as his cat, Fuzz Aldrin, and his mother, remarking that they must now "get started".

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) John Thompson, a man haunted by stubborn traces of alcohol dependency, seeks refuge in his daughter's abandoned treehouse.
2) Despite being trapped within the iron claws of his addiction, he finds semblance of serenity in the noiseless whisper of the treehouse's worn-out wooden walls, which bear the desolate scars of time and neglect.
3) During an ordinary, aimless exploration of the treehouse, John’s worn-out boot scrubs against a concealed trapdoor.
4) Instantly, the secret doorway gives way plunging him into an icy labyrinth beneath the old oak tree’s hardened roots.
5) As he navigates the darkness of the underground maze, he stumbles upon ancient symbols carved with unnerving brutality into stone walls, revealing the silent whispers of past occult practices.
6) The sudden disappearance of Bethany Dunhill, the well-liked cheerleader of Stillwater High, rings the alarm bell within the quiet town, sowing seeds of icy fear and distressing uncertainty within the community.
7) Frank "Stoneface" Mendez, the toughened ex-marine-turned-local sheriff, zeroes in on the enigmatic John as the primary suspect.
8) Stillwater is soon blanketed in a chilling fog of suspicion, as the citizens begin questioning John’s unexplained solitude and mysterious lifestyle.
9) Disregarding the whirlpool of mistrust and finger-pointing, John unveils the dark secrets of the underground maze by following its haunting twists and turns.
10) The horrifying evidence of the cult’s atrocities and its spine-tingling connection with the town’s missing children starts to emerge from the obscure shadows of the labyrinth, establishing both a gut-wrenching horror and a tenacious resolution within John.
11) As the painful echo of his daughter’s abduction amalgamates with the innocent face of Bethany, John embarks on a personal mission to unearth and expose Stillwater’s chilling truths.
12) John stands on the precipice of two grueling wars: an embittered battle against his self-imploding addiction and an impending confrontation with the clandestine cult.
13) In a bid to expose the cult's horrifying reality, John hatches a dangerous scheme to infiltrate one of the cult's secret moonlit rituals.
14) However, his meticulously laid plans crumble to dust, revealing his covert presence to the cult's menacing members.
15) Almost instantaneously, John transitions from hunter to hunted, as the cult members mark him as their prey, seeking vengeance for his audacity.
16) Mustering every drop of courage from the core of his shattered spirit, John manages to set Bethany free from her nightmarish captivity, initiating a pulse-racing escape through the labyrinth's winding passages.
17) The relentless pursuit of the cult members echoes through the cold stone tunnels, their ominous footsteps amplifying the tension.
18) Meanwhile, Stillwater's local police force, now aware of the hidden horrors beneath the treehouse, storms into the oppressive abyss of the underground.
19) An explosive hostility unfurls in the underground battleground, as John, the police force, and the cult cross swords in a life-or-death confrontation blanketed by palpable tension.
20) Despite the overwhelming odds, John's unyielding bravery coupled with the police's steadfast dedication, triumph against the nefarious cult.
21) The horrifying revelation of the oak tree, the chilling tales of abducted children, and the cryptic resurgence of the cult jolts Stillwater into a muteness of shocked silence.
22) The unholy labyrinth beneath the treehouse is permanently sealed, closing the monstrous chapter of Stillwater's chilling folklore.
23) A cruel wave of closure washes over John as he encounters the haunting etch of his daughter's name on a cold, unfeeling stone.
24) Despite the heavy weight of personal loss, John renews his quest towards sobriety, vowing to pay homage to his dearly missed daughter by transforming his own life into a testament of survival and redemption.

input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Our odyssey begins amidst the bustling cityscape of downtown Seattle, where we find Jake, the diligent Chief Financial Officer of a dynamic tech start-up.
2) His existence is centered on one fixation: the ceaseless pursuit of corporate triumphs, often at the expense of personal connections.
3) On a particularly dull Wednesday evening, Jake receives an unexpected visit from Lisa, his energetic and lively older sister.
4) Lisa arranges a blind date for Jake with Mandy, a friend from her college psychology class.
5) Jake reluctantly breaks free from the chains of his monotonous routine.
6) Jake meets Mandy at "Cuppa Joe," a concealed coffee-shop gem in the city.
7) Jake finds himself drawn to Mandy's beguiling charm.
8) As the sun dawns and sets, Jake's attraction blossoms.
9) Their weekends transform into an exciting hodgepodge of experiences.
10) However, Jake's euphoria is disrupted when his office building at Mercer Street is set ablaze, leading to a panicked evacuation.
11) The fire was no happenstance but a calculated act of arson that sends shockwaves through Jake's firm.
12) Jake returns to his condo only to find the place ransacked, furniture upended, files dispersed on the floor, and a single chilling symbol drawn on his wall.
13) Jake's condo is shattered by disturbing, anonymous phone calls always cryptically mentioning Mandy's name.
14) Jake musters up the courage to confront Mandy with the disturbing occurrences.
15) Mandy divulges her shadowy past - a dangerous liaison with the Serpent Swords, a notorious criminal syndicate, and her decision to break away years ago.
16) Jake finds himself at a crossroads — choosing between the safety of his painstakingly organized life or the raw and intoxicating love he has for Mandy.
17) Jake chooses Mandy, surrendering to his heart's desire despite knowing it would disrupt his stable life.
18) Jake pledges unwavering allegiance to Mandy, vowing to assist her in navigating this traumatic quandary.
19) Together they create an escape strategy, burrowing into the workings of Serpent Swords, and enlisting the help of Lisa and a few trustworthy friends.
20) Jake and Mandy face life-threatening situations.
21) They manage to outsmart their adversaries with a combination of courage and cunningness.
22) They uncover important intel regarding their enemies, revealing the syndicate's motives.
23) Jake's financial acumen proves invaluable as they devise a plan to confront Mandy's past and defeat the Serpent Swords.
24) They infiltrate the syndicate's headquarters, unmask the syndicate's leader, dismantle their illicit operations, and rescue countless potential victims.
25) Amid the ruins of what once was Mandy's dreadful past, Jake and Mandy express their deep-seated love for each other.
26) The duo decides to dismantle the cage of their past, beginning their shared lives with a promising future.
27) As Jake's life transitions from robotic to emotional, it fills to the brim with unexpected love, happiness, excitement, and an anticipation towards an uncharted future.
28) The riveting tale concludes on a hopeful note, featuring Jake and Mandy driving along the Pacific coastline, relishing their triumph, and looking forward to the promise of an exciting future.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Amelia Bennett, a reserved yet highly accomplished editor-in-chief of the influential 'Manhattan Herald', settles into her spacious luxury office when a noteworthy parcel arrives.
2) It is an eye-catching, meticulously wrapped package carefully bound by a lustrous silk ribbon supplies a stark contrast to the endless piles of news scripts on her desk.
3) A sense of intrigue washes over Amelia as she cautiously unravels the luxurious package, revealing an ingrained invitation to a grand New York soirée at an extravagant penthouse situated on the opulently prestigious Fifth Avenue.
4) The cryptic closure "Ethan Rodriguez" at the end of the invitation, kindles a flame of curiosity in her, nudging her to explore the enigma.
5) Her initial apprehension gives way to mild excitement as she shares the mysterious invitation with her vivaciously outgoing best friend and work colleague, Peter, who buzzes with infectious enthusiasm about attending the hailed event.
6) Finding herself intrigued by this sudden twist of events and Peter's determined eagerness, Amelia concedes to attend the gathering, leaning heavily on Peter for his unwavering support and bravery in social interactions.
7) Embracing the evening, she swathes herself in a captivating black dress, finishing her look with a daring touch of red lipstick, and inhales deeply, gathering her courage before stepping into the bustling penthouse with Peter amiably by her side.
8) Despite the increasingly chaotic scene, Amelia dives into the sea of faces, resolutely beginning her quest to locate the elusive Ethan Rodriguez.
9) Her relentless pursuit inadvertently triggers a tidal wave of hilarious misunderstandings, converting the high-end gala into an absurdly entertaining saga.
10) The misadventures unfold relentlessly, each hilarious mishap hammering laughter out of the shocked guests, adding to the peculiar charm of the ongoing soirée.
11) Ethan Rodriguez, the elusive host she pursued throughout the night, is unveiled as a figment of an elaborate prank planned by Peter who aimed to coax Amelia from her comfort zone.
12) Taken aback by the revelation, Amelia feels an initial rush of disappointment, which quickly dissipates when she hears the penthouse behind her erupt into uncontrollable laughter.
13) Her stern exterior crumbles, replaced by a joyous smile, as understanding of the humorous situation finally dawns on her.
14) As dawn approaches and the extravagant party starts to wind down, Amelia leaves the penthouse with a sense of satisfaction and a spring in her step, her heart abuzz with memories of the wacky adventures and unexpected laughs.
15) Settling into a yellow cab back to her place, Peter musters the courage to express his guilt over the prank.
16) But before he gets the chance, Amelia bursts into a fit of chuckles, forgiving him wholeheartedly and thanking him for pushing her boundaries.
17) Energized by a fresh outlook on life and armed with an amusing tale, Amelia pours forth her experiences into a riveting cover story for 'Manhattan Herald', capturing all the sweet and salty moments of the memorable soirée.
18) Finding a new lease of fun in her life, Amelia decides to concoct a surprise twist for Peter during their customary morning visit to 'Coffee Central'.
19) In a spirited turn of tables, she picks the perfect moment to ask Peter if he would like to accompany her for an outing that evening.
20) Returning from their funny escapade at the café, the story concludes as Amelia’s narration of her own ‘Manhattan Encounter’ sets the daily newspaper office abuzz causing employees to cherish the rippling laughs.

 Sentence 9: "Her relentless pursuit inadvertently triggers a tidal wave of hilarious misunderstandings, converting the high-end gala into an absurdly entertaining saga."

 Sentence 12: "Taken aback by the revelation, Amelia feels an initial rush of disappointment, which quickly dissipates when she hears the penthouse behind her erupt into uncontrollable laughter."

At this point, Amelia is initially disappointed, but then she laughs it off and feels better. Her condition has dropped slightly, but she's still in a good place. Her condition can be approximated as a 7 out of 10.

 Sentence 16: "But before he gets the chance, Amelia bursts into a fit of chuckles, forgiving him wholeheartedly and thanking him for pushing her boundaries."

At this point, Amelia has fully recovered from the initial disappointment and is now grateful to Peter for the experience. Her condition has improved significantly, and can be approximated as a 10 out of 10.
