Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Robert, the endearing host of a local news talk show aired on WGNX-TV, is a treasured member of Clearfield, a tranquil town nestled in Kansas.
2) The simplicity that defines Robert's life takes a sudden turn when his charismatic old college roommate, Daniel, pays him a surprise visit.
3) Daniel, a flourishing advertising executive, hails from the fast-paced world of New York City.
4) Daniel, now enveloped in the unyielding cadence of New York life, makes an enticing proposition to Robert.
5) Daniel assures him of substantial networking possibilities, as well as the chance to rub shoulders with influential media figures within the bustling city that never sleeps.
6) Stirred by a newfound sense of curiosity and piqued adventure, Robert, for the first time, ventures out of his serene life in Clearfield to embark on an extraordinary odyssey towards the dizzying skyline of New York.
7) Daniel orchestrates Robert's immersion into the city's life, introducing him to influential media personalities such as Lauren Laverne and Anderson Cooper.
8) He is taken to dazzling galas held in luxuriant locations like the Rainbow Room.
9) On a bustling Friday evening, they step into The Stonewall Inn, a vibrant gay bar situated in Greenwich Village.
10) Amid the pulsing rhythm of celebratory beats and the vibrancy of rainbow-flag adorned surroundings, Daniel chooses to reveal a part of his life that Robert was unaware of - his homosexuality.
11) This unforeseen announcement leaves Robert grappling with a whirlwind of emotions, filled with surprise, confusion, and the challenge of deconstructing preconceived notions about homosexuality.
12) Alone in his rented apartment located in the bustling heart of Midtown Manhattan, Robert contemplates this unexpected revelation.
13) Robert brings a positive change to his television show by inviting members of the LGBTQ+ community for discussions and interviews.
14) Robert discovers a multifaceted, diverse community.
15) Their resilience and vibrancy profoundly unsettle everything Robert had initially misunderstood about the community.
16) As New York's relentless bustle becomes his new norm, and his professional journey evolves into a pathway for social change, Robert finds himself wrestling his recently unearthed sexual identity.
17) The emotional tumult magnifies with the sudden realization of his deep-seated feelings towards Daniel.
18) A confusing warmth towards Daniel dominates Robert's heart, leaving him spiraling into a whirlpool of confusing emotions.
19) Looking for solace in this turbulent time, he turns to the LGBTQ+ individuals he had met during his show, candidly revealing his internal struggle.
20) The compassion and understanding he receives from these individuals grant him the acceptance he needed.
21) A heart-to-heart conversation with an elderly gay man who had weathered similar struggles inspires Robert to truly understand and accept his sexuality, and with that, his feelings for Daniel.
22) With newfound courage and determination, Robert decides to share his journey with his audience by introducing the topic of "Coming out" on his television talk show.
23) In an episode that defies societal conventions, Robert admits his love for Daniel and reveals his homosexuality to millions of viewers nationwide.
24) His revelation disrupts the societal norms, dividing his audience into two - those who commend Robert's bravery and those who raise eyebrows.
25) Yet, amidst the ensuing controversy, his admission stirs an undercurrent of change in the public psyche, sparking a nationwide dialogue on homosexuality and broader acceptance.
26) The narrative culminates with a stirring scene of Robert and Daniel, hand-in-hand, walking through the shimmering lights of Times Square.
27) The scene symbolizes not just their endearing love, but also Robert's complete acceptance of his identity in a society that's slowly but surely moving towards acceptance.

Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) A young woman, Allison, sits on a dock at the edge of a foggy lake.
2) She then retreats to a cabin and sits in a room where she looks at a notepad.
3) The film then moves to Part One: The Bear in the Road.
4) At a remote lake house in the Adirondack Mountains, Gabe and Blair entertain film director Allison, an out-of-town guest and former actress looking for inspiration.
5) Gabe's interest in her quickly becomes obvious, as does his unhappy relationship with his pregnant partner Blair.
6) Blair and Gabe constantly bicker in front of an uncomfortable Allison, with Blair targeting Gabe's lackluster musical career and Gabe criticizing Blair's drinking habits.
7) Allison becomes a part of these arguments, shifting between siding with Blair and Gabe and causing them to become even more aggressive to each other.
8) When Gabe rants against the failings of modern society, Blair becomes upset and threatens to leave after Allison jokingly sides with Gabe's criticism of feminism.
9) Allison awkwardly leaves as Blair and Gabe retreat to their bedroom; Blair accuses Gabe of being sexually attracted to Allison, but then they make up.
10) After Blair falls asleep, Gabe meets Allison for a swim at the lake.
11) Afterwards the two talk, and Gabe admits that the pregnancy with Blair had been an accident.
12) In turn, Allison admits that she had lied about many things she had told him and Blair for no reason.
13) They kiss and begin to have sex, but Blair interrupts them, attacks Gabe, and orders Allison to leave.
14) She and Gabe argue violently until Gabe shoves her against a couch.
15) Realizing that Blair is bleeding, Gabe orders Allison to get their car and drive them to the hospital.
16) As she is driving, Allison is startled by a black bear in the road and swerves, crashing into a tree.
17) The film switches to Part Two: The Bear by the Boat House.
18) The lake house is now the setting of a film shoot in which Gabe is the director and Allison and Blair are actresses, though their roles in the production are switched, with Allison the scorned wife and Blair the interloper.
19) Gabe and Allison have been married for years, but he is obviously rude and abrasive to her on set and favors Blair, which makes the crew uncomfortable.
20) Gabe continually makes Allison upset by making her believe that he and Blair are having an affair, which they actually are doing in order to make Allison's acting feel more real and intense.
21) However, they go too far and Allison begins drinking heavily, disappearing from the production and requiring the crew to bring her back.
22) When Allison returns drunk to the set, Gabe notices and quietly chastises her in front of the crew, blaming her for demanding to be the lead actress.
23) After repeated failed takes and arguments during the film's climactic argument scene, Allison eventually nails her part but begins fighting and hitting Blair for real.
24) Gabe is delighted by the results, but Allison, still upset, retreats to a room and refuses to come out despite Gabe's annoyance and her friends' support.
25) She orders a cameraman, Baako, to see her; when he arrives, she begins kissing him and pleads to him to lie to her that he loves her.
26) After she returns to the set, the scene is reshot, and Gabe asks Allison to not hit Blair.
27) The scene plays out as intended, but Allison has a genuine, uncontrollable breakdown as she yells at "her husband" that he was supposed to love her, not "Blair."
28) She continues sobbing even after the cameras are off.
29) Gabe consoles her as the uncomfortable crew looks on.
30) Afterwards, Gabe takes her away to comfort her as the rest of the crew celebrates with a wrap party.
31) Allison tells him that he should love Blair because she is better than her, and that she wishes that they could go back to the way things were before they were famous; she also calls him "Bear."
32) Gabe assures her that there had been no affair with Blair, and that things will be different in the future.
33) After she falls asleep, he leaves to sit with Blair.
34) Allison wakes up alone and tries to find Gabe in a panic, eventually returning to the lake house and having a frightening encounter with a black bear on the way there.
35) Witnessing Gabe and Blair having sex through a window, she becomes distraught as the bear appears behind her.
36) She turns and appears to walk calmly toward it.
37) The film cuts back to the opening scene, with Allison alone looking at the foggy lake.
38) She returns to the cabin to write, but this time she is seen writing "Black Bear" on the notepad before looking at the viewer.

At this point, Allison's state has reached a breaking point. She has become completely overwhelmed by her emotions and is no longer able to distinguish between reality and the film. She is having a public breakdown, which marks a major setback for her.

Protagonist's condition: 1

### Task 6: Fifth Turning Point (Climax, tp5)
 Sentence 35: "Witnessing Gabe and Blair having sex through a window, she becomes distraught as the bear appears behind her."
At this point, Allison's state has hit rock bottom. She has been betrayed by Gabe and is now witnessing him with Blair, which confirms all her worst fears. She is also facing a physical threat in the form of the bear, which adds to her distress.

Protagonist's condition: 0

### Task 7: Protagonist's Condition List
[6, 3, 2, 1, 0]

### Task 8: Classify the Story Arc Type
Based on the protagonist's condition list, I would classify the story arc type as Oedipus. This is because Allison starts in a relatively high state (6), but then experiences a series of setbacks and declines, ultimately hitting rock bottom (0). This trajectory matches the Oedipus story arc, which is characterized by a protagonist who starts high, falls, recovers, and then faces another significant downfall.

### Task 9: Determined Story Arc Type
Oedipus

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Our tale unfolds against the gorgeous canvas of San Francisco in the late 1800s, where Victorian houses speckle the rolling landscape.
2) At its heart, we find our lead character, Patrick Kearney.
3) A physician by profession, Patrick commands respect and admiration amongst his contemporaries.
4) Also forming an integral part of the Kearney homestead is Buster, a dog whose lineage forms an intriguing blend of the noble wolf and the friendly golden retriever.
5) Every day, we watch as Patrick goes about his duties, with Buster his unwavering companion.
6) However, their peaceful cohabitation is suddenly disrupted one afternoon by the arrival of a postman carrying a letter from Carson City, a rustic town located in Nevada.
7) The letter contains alarming details of the dire circumstances his long-lost brother now finds himself in.
8) Panic and worry ensue, and Patrick finds himself torn between his estranged past relationship with his brother and the undeniable bond that familial ties impose.
9) After much inner turmoil, Patrick decides to undertake a rescue mission to save his brother, Joe.
10) He spends a few days gathering essential necessities for his arduous journey.
11) Buster, his faithful companion, remains at Patrick's side throughout.
12) Leaving the familiar coasts of San Francisco behind, they embark on their journey into the unpredictable wilderness.
13) They navigate the hostile wilderness, fraught with extreme weather fluctuations, height changes, and the constant threat of highwaymen.
14) Their journey evolves into more than merely a mission to save someone.
15) It becomes a test of their bond, their ability to endure hardships.
16) As they near the Sierra peak, signs of Patrick's brother surface, amplifying his anticipation.
17) However, they discover the chilling reality of Patrick's brother being held captive by bandits over an assertion regarding an alleged treasure.
18) Patrick and Buster engage in a perilous path filled with danger, but it also provides them with an opportunity to hatch a plan to rescue Joe.
19) What follows is a gripping face-off, where Patrick, aided by a fierce dog, take on a gang of outlaws.
20) The battle ends with Patrick and Buster emerging victorious amidst the defeated outlaws.
21) Following the battle, they discover a hidden trove brimming with gold nuggets, the source of contention among the bandits.
22) Upon setting his brother free, the brothers share a heartfelt reunion.
23) Patrick chooses to leave behind the gold, and they embark on their journey back home to San Francisco.
24) Settling back into city life, the wilderness holds a newfound allure for Patrick.
25) As he sits by his hearth with Buster snoozing at his feet, he realizes that his experiences and relationships built during the journey are worth far more than tangible riches.
26) Days later, Patrick sits overlooking his beloved city of San Francisco.
27) Irrespective of his monetary wealth, he feels a richness in his life that gold cannot equal.
28) His real wealth lies in people he cherishes in his life, the experiences gained, and the wisdom acquired from each challenge.
29) As night falls, the curtain descends on our tale of a man, his loyal dog, and an unforgettable journey that forever redefined their perspective on life.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

Ground Truth Turning Points:
- Opportunity (tp1): 6.5 - Introductory event that occurs after presenting the setting and background of the main characters.
- Change of Plans (tp2): 9.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 13.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 17.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 23.5 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:
### TASK ANSWERS

1. **Identify the protagonist in the story:** 
   The protagonist in the story is Patrick Kearney, a physician by profession.

2. **Describe the protagonist's state at the first turning point (Opportunity, tp1):**
   Sentence 6: "However, their peaceful cohabitation is suddenly disrupted one afternoon by the arrival of a postman carrying a letter from Carson City, a rustic town located in Nevada."
   At this point, Patrick's peaceful life is disrupted by the arrival of a letter containing alarming details about his brother's dire circumstances. His condition is around 6, as his life is no longer peaceful but he still has his profession and respect in society.

3. **Describe the protagonist's state at the second turning point (Change of Plans, tp2):**

   At this point, Patrick decides to take action to save his brother, which shows his commitment to family and willingness to help. His condition remains around 6, as he is still in a comfortable position but is now undertaking a challenging task.

4. **Describe the protagonist's state at the third turning point (Point of No Return, tp3):**
   Sentence 13: "They navigate the hostile wilderness, fraught with extreme weather fluctuations, height changes, and the constant threat of highwaymen."
   At this point, Patrick and Buster are fully committed to their journey and face numerous challenges in the wilderness. His condition is around 4, as he is now in a more difficult and dangerous situation.

5. **Describe the protagonist's state at the fourth turning point (Major Setback, tp4):**
   Sentence 17: "However, they discover the chilling reality of Patrick's brother being held captive by bandits over an assertion regarding an alleged treasure."
   At this point, Patrick and Buster discover the true nature of the situation, which is more complex and challenging than initially thought. His condition is around 2, as he is now facing a major setback and a significant threat to his brother's life.

6. **Describe the protagonist's state at the fifth turning point (Climax, tp5):**
   Sentence 25: "As he sits by his hearth with Buster snoozing at his feet, he realizes that his experiences and relationships built during the journey are worth far more than tangible riches."
   At this point, Patrick has successfully rescued his brother and gained a newfound appreciation for life and relationships. His condition is around 9, as he has overcome challenges and grown as a person.

7. **Protagonist's condition list:**
   [6, 6, 4, 2, 9]

8. **Classify the story arc type:**
   Based on the protagonist's condition list, the story arc type is "Man in a Hole" because the protagonist's condition initially drops (from 6 to 2) but eventually rises to a higher state (9) than at the beginning. This arc type is characterized by the protagonist facing challenges, overcoming them, and emerging better off than at the start.

9. **Determined story arc type:**

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Greg's parents reveal that they are going away for the weekend and taking Manny with them.
2) Rodrick takes advantage of this and informs Greg that they are throwing a party together, reminding him of The Heffley Brothers.
3) Rodrick sends the "party text" on his phone and tells Greg to bring his "friends" over.
4) Greg invites Rowley over to help, but they both end up doing all the work while Rodrick sits and directs.
5) He locks them in the basement after telling them to get an extra table.
6) Greg loosens the doorknob and takes photos of the party as "blackmail".
7) In the morning, they are let out and Rowley runs home while Greg confronts Rodrick over what happened.
8) They suddenly get a call from their mother Susan, who informs them that Manny got sick, and they are coming home right away.
9) Rodrick tells Greg to clean up, but Greg refuses.
10) Rodrick finally gets Greg to change his mind and quickly clean up the house.
11) As they think they are done, the bathroom door slides, revealing 'Rodrick Rules' on the bathroom door just as Susan, Frank, and Manny arrive.
12) Greg tries to wipe the writing off the door, but it turns out to be permanent ink.
13) The brothers quickly remove the bedroom door to Rodrick's room, and switch Rodrick's door with the replacement to the bathroom door after panicking.
14) Following the incident, Frank makes the two boys rake the leaves.
15) Greg demands Rodrick give him advice in return for helping clean up the party.
16) Rodrick gives in and tells him about his 'Rodrick Rules' which deal with getting things done without making an effort.
17) Greg corrects that 'Rodrick Rules' should be 'Rodrick's Rules', but Rodrick's first rule was "no apostrophes".
18) After raking leaves, Greg quickly becomes impatient but is calmed down when Rodrick teaches him how to play the drums.
19) Greg meets his fellow bandmates of Löded Diper, one of whom is actually a 30-something year old man, Bill, who are going to enter a talent show.
20) Greg is also in it, but is assisting Rowley with his magic act, something which he does not think will be a hit.
21) Frank suspects that the boys are hiding something, but Susan is happy to see them getting along.
22) When Frank asks about Rodrick's "bathroom door" not being locked, Greg covers and claims that he accidentally slammed it too hard, explaining why it does not lock properly.
23) Frank and Susan are going away for the weekend again, but this time, they will leave the boys with Grandpa at the nursing home, which Rodrick seems overly eager about.
24) At the nursing home, Rodrick reveals that the board games contain plenty of Mom Bucks they can use back at home.
25) He gives some to Greg, but his pants get wet during a game, and he is forced to change in the lobby bathroom.
26) Greg accidentally ends up in the women's room where he gets accused of being a peeping tom.
27) A chase through the old folks home ensues, but he manages to get back to the room.
28) Later, Grandpa tells Greg that he knows that he and Rodrick did not want to come, but he admires that they hang out, something that Frank fails to do with his brothers.
29) The next school day, Rowley reminds Greg that he needed to do his life science project and he rushes to Rodrick for help.
30) He gives him his old life science project on the condition that he hand over some Mom Bucks.
31) Greg does so, but upon arriving at school realizes that it is a failed project about plants sneezing.
32) Greg angrily reveals his blackmail to Rodrick and demands he pay up in Mom Bucks.
33) Rodrick gives $200 but, he accidentally bumps into Susan, who sees the photos, and she and Frank punish both the boys.
34) One of Rodrick's punishments in particular is that he is not allowed to perform in the talent show, though Greg is still forced to perform with Rowley.
35) When Greg tells Rodrick he didn't expect this, Rodrick angrily tells that never would have happened if he hadn't "snitched".
36) As payback, Rodrick reveals that he took photos of the pictures in Greg's diary about the restroom incident and threatens to send them to his friends who will send them to their siblings.
37) They get the phone away from Rodrick, but Rowley accidentally sends the photos.
38) To Greg's surprise, the story at school got twisted to being about Greg winning the top prize at a bingo competition and making a big getaway, making him popular.
39) Greg is still annoyed however as he has to do the talent show with Rowley, but just before entering, Löded Diper approaches Greg about being their new drummer, as their replacement drummer Larry loves magic and would not mind switching places with him.
40) Greg starts to question whether he should drum or not, but after Rodrick makes a scathing remark to him, he agrees.
41) Upon seeing Rodrick leaving the show upset, Greg goes out to talk to him and explains that he simply wanted him to be proud of him and was worried they will grow apart.
42) Rodrick tells Greg that he does care about him and that they will continue to hang out together.
43) Greg gives Rodrick his position as drummer back, despite his parents' wishes and returns to Löded Diper.
44) Frank and Susan extend Greg's punishment, but Greg says it's worth it and Grandpa then commends Frank for raising two good brothers while Susan excitedly dances to the band's song.
45) Rowley's magic show ends up winning the competition while Löded Diper gains a wider audience thanks to Susan.
46) Despite their differences, Greg and Rodrick's relationship improves.

output:
### TASK RESPONSE

1. The protagonist in the story is Greg.

2. The first turning point (Opportunity) is at sentence 2: "Rodrick takes advantage of this and informs Greg that they are throwing a party together, reminding him of The Heffley Brothers." 
   At this point, Greg's state is excited and optimistic about the party, but also slightly apprehensive about the responsibility and potential consequences. 
   Approximate condition: 6

3. The second turning point (Change of Plans) is at sentence 10: "Rodrick finally gets Greg to change his mind and quickly clean up the house." 
   Relative to the first turning point, Greg's state has changed to being more anxious and worried about getting in trouble for the party, but also relieved that he can clean up the mess before his parents arrive. 
   Approximate condition: 4

4. The third turning point (Point of No Return) is at sentence 19: "Greg meets his fellow bandmates of Löded Diper, one of whom is actually a 30-something year old man, Bill, who are going to enter a talent show." 
   Relative to the second turning point, Greg's state has changed to being more enthusiastic and hopeful about his future, particularly about his potential as a drummer and his relationship with Rodrick. 
   Approximate condition: 7

5. The fourth turning point (Major Setback) is at sentence 34: "One of Rodrick's punishments in particular is that he is not allowed to perform in the talent show, though Greg is still forced to perform with Rowley." 
   Relative to the third turning point, Greg's state has changed to being more disappointed and frustrated, particularly about Rodrick's punishment and his own situation with the talent show. 
   Approximate condition: 3

6. The fifth turning point (Climax) is at sentence 41: "Upon seeing Rodrick leaving the show upset, Greg goes out to talk to him and explains that he simply wanted him to be proud of him and was worried they will grow apart." 
   Relative to the fourth turning point, Greg's state has changed to being more empathetic and understanding, particularly about his relationship with Rodrick, and more confident in his decisions. 
   Approximate condition: 8

7. The list of protagonist's condition in chronological order is: [6, 4, 7, 3, 8]

8. Based on the protagonist's condition list, the story arc type can be classified as "Double Man in a Hole". This is because the protagonist's condition starts at a moderate level, then falls to a lower point, rises to a higher point, falls again to an even lower point, and finally rises to a higher point than the starting point. This pattern of two cycles of dilemma and recovery matches the "Double Man in a Hole" story arc type.

9. Double Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Gary, a newly-divorced father of two, hires Cameron as a masseur and sex worker.
2) After a brief dispute between the two men, Cameron learns that Gary is closeted and has never had sex with a man before.
3) Cameron decides to help Gary by inviting over Sammy from Plungr, an anonymous gay hookup app.
4) Sammy arrives, but is not attracted to Gary, and gets into a physical confrontation with Cameron.
5) As the argument escalates, Sammy rushes to tackle Cameron, who Gary saves by pushing him out of the way.
6) In the process, Sammy crashes through Gary's window and lands on Gary's stoop.
7) Gary and Cameron then get into an argument over hiding Sammy's body.
8) Cameron storms off, but returns later and helps Gary get the body into his house.
9) Cameron and Gary brainstorm how to get rid of the body, when Sandy, Gary's neighbor, arrives at the house.
10) Cameron and Gary keep her distracted for a while but she eventually sees the body.
11) Panicked, she evades them in the house and ends up stuck inside a closet.
12) Cameron and Gary then decide to hire Buck, a necrophiliac from the dark web, to get rid of Sammy's body.
13) He arrives and helps the two men clean the house, which is stained with blood.
14) As the three become closer, Gary reveals that he has one month to live due to a brain tumor.
15) He expresses regret for his conformist lifestyle and resents himself for living a boring life.
16) He further reveals that his wife left him when he came out as gay.
17) The three men smoke crack cocaine together and go for a swim.
18) As the day breaks, they finish cleaning the house and find that Sandy cannot remember the events of the previous night due to the interaction between her medication and the wine she drank.
19) She leaves, and the three men realize that Sammy's body is missing.
20) They see him limping away from Gary's home, and Buck runs him over in order to get the body he sees as rightfully his.
21) Cameron and Gary then kill Buck and bury both men in unmarked graves.
22) Gary and Cameron then have sex.
23) One month later, Cameron receives an invitation to Gary's funeral.
24) He shows up and confronts Gary's ex-wife, Patty and the gathered mourners.
25) He accuses them of corrupting Gary's legacy, as he would have hated to be buried by the church and family that rejected him when he came out.
26) He then steals Gary's body and drives it to the lake adjoining Gary's house.
27) He fills Gary's pockets with rocks and drags his body into the lake, where it begins to sink.
28) The movie ends with a shot of Cameron reaching out for Gary's arm in the style of The Creation of Adam.

output:
### TASK COMPLETION

1.  The protagonist in the story is Gary, a newly-divorced father of two.

2.  The sentence corresponding to the first turning point (Opportunity, tp1) is:
    "Gary, a newly-divorced father of two, hires Cameron as a masseur and sex worker."
    At this point, Gary's state is one of loneliness and disconnection. He has recently gone through a divorce and is seeking companionship. His condition can be approximated as a 4 out of 10.

3.  The sentence corresponding to the second turning point (Change of Plans, tp2) is:
    "Gary and Cameron then get into an argument over hiding Sammy's body."
    At this point, Gary's state has worsened due to the physical confrontation and the need to hide a body. His condition can be approximated as a 2 out of 10, which is lower than the first turning point.

4.  The sentence corresponding to the third turning point (Point of No Return, tp3) is:
    "Cameron and Gary then decide to hire Buck, a necrophiliac from the dark web, to get rid of Sammy's body."
    At this point, Gary's state is still precarious, but he has found a potential solution to his problem. However, this solution comes with significant risks. His condition can be approximated as a 3 out of 10, which is slightly better than the second turning point.

5.  The sentence corresponding to the fourth turning point (Major Setback, tp4) is:
    "They see him limping away from Gary's home, and Buck runs him over in order to get the body he sees as rightfully his."
    At this point, Gary's state has worsened again due to the reappearance of Sammy and the violent actions of Buck. His condition can be approximated as a 1 out of 10, which is lower than the third turning point.

6.  The sentence corresponding to the fifth turning point (Climax, tp5) is:
    "Gary and Cameron then have sex."
    At this point, Gary's state has improved slightly as he has found a moment of intimacy and connection with Cameron. However, this is short-lived as Gary's death is imminent. His condition can be approximated as a 5 out of 10, which is better than the fourth turning point.

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) On his first day in Tel Aviv, Michael arrives at the apartment he is to sublet only to find it still inhabited by Tomer, who had mixed up the date Michael was to arrive.
2) Learning that Tomer's bike was stolen and he has nowhere else in the city to stay, Michael offers for Tomer to stay in the apartment with him in exchange for showing him around the city.
3) After a short, somewhat strained video call with his husband, David, Michael goes to sleep.
4) On his second day while visiting the Tel Aviv Museum of Art, Michael receives a call from an IVF clinic and learns that David has moved forward with plans to have a child via a surrogate mother without Michael's knowledge.
5) Over lunch, Michael and Tomer discuss Michael's debut book, Complications, in which he writes about his life in New York City during the AIDS crisis, documenting the death of his then-boyfriend from the disease.
6) Tomer seems to consider AIDS too "depressing" to write or think about, which bewilders Michael.
7) Michael also meets Tomer's friend Daria, who tells Michael she is frustrated with her life as an artist in Israel and plans to move to Berlin with her boyfriend, hoping for an easier time.
8) Michael tells the two that when his generation was frustrated with the state of their lives they protested and tried to effect real change, but Daria says that living only for herself is her form of protest.
9) On the third day Michael and Tomer meet at Frishman Beach, Tomer having found a copy of Michael's book on his way there.
10) They run into Guy, an informal sexual and romantic partner of Tomer's.
11) Michael asks about him, and Tomer says that Guy wants a more formal relationship but Tomer's philosophy is to "enjoy everything life has to offer" and never to enter any formal relationships.
12) Michael sees a toddler walk and fall into the water and runs to pick him up, but when he does the boy's mother becomes angry with him.
13) That night, David apologizes to Michael for going behind his back but expresses excitement at the surrogacy process moving forward.
14) Michael tells him they should just let the prospect of having a child go before leaving the call to attend a dance performance put on by Daria, a Jewish Israeli and her Palestinian boyfriend.
15) In their performance, the two push each other apart violently before ultimately embracing.
16) That evening, Tomer browses Atraf for potential casual sex partners.
17) Michael expresses interest in one profile, and Tomer asks if he should invite the man over.
18) Michael considers it and ultimately declines, but Tomer invites him anyway.
19) The man, Kobi, arrives, and after brief conversation Kobi and Tomer begin to have sex as Michael watches.
20) After a few minutes, Michael leaves the room and goes to sleep.
21) On the morning of the fourth day, Tomer wakes to find Michael boarding a taxi to leave.
22) Tomer stops him and convinces him to stay, inviting Michael to dinner with his mother on the Kibbutz that she lives on.
23) At dinner, Michael learns that Tomer's mother raised him as a single mother, having used a sperm bank to get pregnant.
24) Tomer's mother asks Michael if he ever wanted to have children, telling him that her only regret is not having more children.
25) Michael tells her that he and his husband had recently tried to have a child via IVF, but that the baby died during birth, revealing that the process that David started would actually be their second attempt at having a child.
26) Tomer and his mother urge Michael that it's not too late to try again, and before they leave Michael watches pensively as Tomer and his mother interact.
27) That night, as Michael is packing to leave, he organizes Tomer's chaotic wardrobe for him.
28) He explains to Tomer the way he has organized it and instructs him in the proper way to fold clothes, and the two sit to match Tomer's socks with each other.
29) When they complete, each is left with one unpaired sock.
30) Using the two unmatched socks as sock puppets, they mime the two dissimilar socks - one a traditional business sock and one a black sock decorated with white stars, deciding to pair up with each other.
31) Still wearing the socks on their hands, the two have sex and fall asleep together.
32) The next morning the two share a meal in the airport before Michael leaves.
33) As the two observe a mother and son sitting nearby, Tomer tells Michael he thinks Michael would be a good father and that he should try again to have a child.
34) On the flight home, Michael leaves a voice message for David, suggesting they have dinner at a park that they used to go to when they were younger.
35) The film closes as Tomer recovers his stolen bike and rides through the city.

2. **First Turning Point (Opportunity, tp1):** Sentence 4: "On his second day while visiting the Tel Aviv Museum of Art, Michael receives a call from an IVF clinic and learns that David has moved forward with plans to have a child via a surrogate mother without Michael's knowledge."
   - At this point, Michael is feeling shocked, betrayed, and uncertain about his future with his husband, which has significantly impacted his emotional state.
   - Protagonist's Condition: 4

3. **Second Turning Point (Change of Plans, tp2):** Sentence 13: "That night, David apologizes to Michael for going behind his back but expresses excitement at the surrogacy process moving forward."
   - Michael is still trying to process the news and feels that his relationship with David is strained, but there is a sense of apology and attempt at reconciliation.
   - Change Relative to tp1: Michael's emotional turmoil has slightly decreased due to David's apology, but the future of their relationship remains uncertain.
   - Protagonist's Condition: 5

4. **Third Turning Point (Point of No Return, tp3):** Sentence 22: "Tomer stops him and convinces him to stay, inviting Michael to dinner with his mother on the Kibbutz that she lives on."
   - Michael is starting to open up and form connections with Tomer, indicating a shift in his focus from his strained relationship with David to new experiences and connections.
   - Change Relative to tp2: Michael's emotional state has improved as he begins to let go of his immediate concerns about his relationship with David and starts to engage more with his surroundings and the people in it.
   - Protagonist's Condition: 6

5. **Fourth Turning Point (Major Setback, tp4):** Sentence 18: "Michael considers it and ultimately declines, but Tomer invites him anyway."
   - Although this is a setback in terms of Michael's immediate comfort and feelings about intimacy, it also represents a moment where he is forced to confront his desires and boundaries.
   - Change Relative to tp3: This event actually occurs before tp3 in the narrative but is identified as a major setback. Considering the correct chronological order, this event would have contributed to Michael's feelings of discomfort and uncertainty before the point of no return.
   - Given the correct sequence, we should reassess this in the context of the story: Before the dinner at the Kibbutz, Michael's condition had actually taken a slight dip due to the discomfort and unresolved feelings from this event.
   - Corrected Analysis for tp3 to tp4 Transition: Michael's condition improves after the point of no return as he starts to form meaningful connections and have positive experiences.

6. **Fifth Turning Point (Climax, tp5):** Sentence 33: "As the two observe a mother and son sitting nearby, Tomer tells Michael he thinks Michael would be a good father and that he should try again to have a child."
   - Michael has reached a point of significant emotional growth and resolution. He is more open to the idea of having a child and seems more at peace with his relationship issues.
   - Change Relative to tp4: Michael's condition has significantly improved from his earlier state of discomfort and uncertainty.
   - Protagonist's Condition: 8

7. **Protagonist's Condition List:** [4, 5, (dip to 4 at actual tp4), 6, 8] Corrected to reflect chronological order and accurate transitions: [4, (dip to 3 at actual tp4), 5, 6, 8]

8. **Story Arc Classification:**
   - Given the corrected protagonist's condition list [4, 3, 5, 6, 8], we see a pattern where the protagonist starts in a relatively low state, faces a setback (further dip), and then gradually improves to a significantly better condition by the end of the story.
   - This pattern closely resembles the "Man in a Hole" story arc, where the protagonist falls into a dilemma (or in this case, starts in a troubled state and faces a setback) and then finds a way out, ending in a better condition than at the beginning.

9. **Determined Story Arc Type:** Man in a Hole

Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) The movie commences with a panoramic view of the quaint landscapes of Provence — a serene symphony of pastures, vineyards, and blooming wildflowers, giving the audience a glimpse into the pastoral charms of rural France.
2) Nestled amidst the endless expanse of greenery, divided by a dense copse of mighty oaks, sit two seemingly disconnected estates — neighbours in proximity, yet distant otherwise, away from petites Pierres, their nearest settlement.
3) The focus, then, shifts to Jacques, a grizzled, weather-beaten old farmer stooped over his abundance of golden wheat field.
4) His eyes, though, hold a sorrow that belies his determined demeanor — a permanent void that had formed following the death of his dearly beloved wife, enshrouding him in a cloak of silent seclusion.
5) Separated by mere physical distance and yet worlds apart, Mathilde, the owner of the neighbouring estate is a stark contrast.
6) The enthusiastic lady whiles away her time in her art studio, finding comfort nestled amidst the riot of vibrant colours on her canvases.
7) However, the stability of Mathilde's artistic sanctuary is shattered when she observes the lavenders at the edge of her estate beginning to wilt and rot away, despite her heartfelt attempts to keep them flourishing.
8) Recognizing her limitations in dealing with the realms of cultivation, she grudgingly concedes, and approaches Jacques, her experienced neighbor, hoping for his expertise.
9) Jacques, albeit reluctant, decides to lend a helping hand.
10) He crosses over the stone boundary that separates their estates, examines Mathilde's struggling lavender plants, and provides her with practical farming advice.
11) Their initial meeting is characterized by hesitating smiles and awkward, misunderstood interactions, portraying the clashing worlds of two solitary yet similar individuals.
12) When a whisper about a mythical legend circulates through the humble settlement of petites Pierres — a story about enchanted thistle seeds bringing good fortune and prosperity, Jacques and Mathilde find their curiosity piqued.
13) Brought together by uncanny circumstances, they embark on a joint expedition to navigate the strangely mystical woods around them, navigating rivulets and wading through misty meadows in hopes of unearthing the legendary thistle seeds.
14) Through their journey, Jacques's in-depth knowledge of the land couples beautifully with Mathilde's innate understanding of colours and aesthetics — a balance that enlivens their otherwise tedious path while forging an unlikely friendship between them.
15) Their connection deepens as they tackle the riddles that lead to the thistle, using their individual abilities to solve the brainteasers that are part of the village lore.
16) Sparks flow under the night sky speckled with starlight.
17) Mathilde reveals her tumultuous past, a breathtaking canvas of Technicolor memories, while Jacques, too, shares his solitary dance with desolation.
18) Understanding each other's pasts, Jacques and Mathilde find their companionship transitioning into an unspoken bond, enabling them to steer through the tumultuous waves of loneliness.
19) The culmination of their joint adventure is marked by their perseverance, as they finally uncover the last mystical thistle seed hidden amidst thorny bushes.
20) On their return, they plant the seeds on Mathilde's bleak field, the symbolic convergence of their initially separate lives, marking a significant chapter in the history of petites Pierres.
21) As if by magic, the once barren field burgeons with lavender and thistles — a tangible representation of their flourishing companionship and emotional healing.
22) News of the miraculous revival of the once barren field spreads quickly through the many winding streets of petites Pierres, rekindling a sense of unity among the villagers.
23) The town's people, who were often overlooked in their secluded corners now come together in joy, celebrating and sharing Jacques and Mathilde's victory against the whims of destiny.
24) The tiny settlement, which was once a picture-postcard image of solitude, comes alive, echoing with laughter, chatter, and overall bonhomie — a result of the shared achievement.
25) The camera zooms out to encapsulate the thriving lavender fields in all their glory one last time, narrating an enduring tale of a friendship that blossomed against all odds.
26) Jacques and Mathilde are seen standing silently beside each other in the distance, their wrinkled faces reflecting the vibrant landscape — an emblem of newfound life.
27) The golden hues cast by the setting sun falling gently on their faces, they share a moment of quiet reflection before the eventual end, their eyes reflecting mutual respect and understanding.
28) The last shot freezes on their undisguised joy, bearing testament to their transformative journey against the backdrop of a rustic charm.
29) Their smiles, content and healed, signal the transformative magic that they discovered not just in their dying lavender but within their lives.
30) The ending depicts the rejuvenated lavender fields mirroring the newfound peace within Jacques and Mathilde, signifying a closure and the promise of a new beginning.
31) The closing scene captures their smiles, a token of their incredible journey towards healing, embedding upon its frame the essence of building genuine connections.
32) As the scene gradually fades into the black, Jacques and Mathilde's shared laughter carries within it the warmth of the golden setting sun.
33) An invigorated petites Pierres stands tall against the backdrop, a testament to the triumph of collaboration over a shared adversity.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

Ground Truth Turning Points:
- Opportunity (tp1): 7.5 - Introductory event that occurs after presenting the setting and background of the main characters.
- Change of Plans (tp2): 10.5 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 13.5 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 14.5 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 19.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").

   - "He crosses over the stone boundary that separates their estates, examines Mathilde's struggling lavender plants, and provides her with practical farming advice." (sentence 10)

   At this point, Jacques decides to help Mathilde, marking a change in his plans and the beginning of their interaction. Jacques's condition: 5/10 (starting to open up), Mathilde's condition: 7/10 (receiving help and hopeful).

4. **Third Turning Point (Point of No Return, tp3):** The story doesn't have a sentence exactly at 13.5, but the closest sentence is:
   - "Brought together by uncanny circumstances, they embark on a joint expedition to navigate the strangely mystical woods around them, navigating rivulets and wading through misty meadows in hopes of unearthing the legendary thistle seeds." (sentence 13)

   At this point, Jacques and Mathilde commit to their goal of finding the thistle seeds together. Jacques's condition: 6/10 (fully committed to helping Mathilde and opening up), Mathilde's condition: 8/10 (excited and hopeful about their joint expedition).

5. **Fourth Turning Point (Major Setback, tp4):** The story doesn't have a sentence exactly at 14.5, but the closest sentence is:
   - "Through their journey, Jacques's in-depth knowledge of the land couples beautifully with Mathilde's innate understanding of colours and aesthetics — a balance that enlivens their otherwise tedious path while forging an unlikely friendship between them." (sentence 14)

   Although this sentence doesn't seem to describe a major setback, it's possible that the story doesn't have a clear major setback. Instead, this sentence highlights the positive development of their friendship. Jacques's condition: 7/10 (developing a strong friendship), Mathilde's condition: 9/10 (same as Jacques).

6. **Fifth Turning Point (Climax, tp5):** 
   - "The culmination of their joint adventure is marked by their perseverance, as they finally uncover the last mystical thistle seed hidden amidst thorny bushes." (sentence 19)

   At this point, Jacques and Mathilde achieve their goal of finding the thistle seeds. Jacques's condition: 9/10 (successful and fulfilled), Mathilde's condition: 10/10 (same as Jacques).

7. **Protagonist's Condition List:** Since both Jacques and Mathilde are analyzed as protagonists, I will provide two lists:

   - Jacques's condition list: [4, 5, 6, 7, 9]

8. **Classify the Story Arc Type:**

9. **Determined Story Arc Type:** Man in a Hole

input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Raquel starts narrating the story of her life.
2) In a classroom we see her refusing to read her assignment as even though she knows how to write a story, she isn’t brave enough to tell it.
3) She then says that her story doesn’t start in this classroom, it actually starts in her house.
4) Her house as she describes is a humble abode that, through ups and downs, ended up surrounded by an empire called the Hidalgo mansion.
5) The Hidalgos are her next door neighbors but their lifestyle is completely different from hers.
6) The Hidalgos own Alpha 3, one of the most influential companies in the country, whose headquarters is the most spectacular building in Barcelona.
7) Alpha 3 refers to the three heirs to the empire, the Hidalgo brothers, Artemis, Ares and Apolo.
8) Raquel has an unhealthy obsession with Ares but has never said a word to him.
9) She knows everything he does and likes to collect information about him.
10) Apolo thanks Raquel for letting them use her Wi-Fi as theirs is broken.
11) She is confused and finds out that Ares has hacked into her computer and cracked the Wi-Fi password.
12) The next day Raquel follows Ares into a secluded wooded area, where she confronts him about hacking into her computer.
13) In response, he writes the password on her hand and asks her why it is a code that says, ‘Ares, Greek God’.
14) They exchange words which leads to Raquel admitting that she likes him and wants him to fall for her.
15) At night she unplugs the Wi-Fi to assert that it's her, who is in control of it.
16) But Ares climbs up her window into her room and plugs it back in.
17) They share a steamy moment that leaves Raquel wanting for more.
18) The next day Ares invites her to a party where she seduces him but doesn’t let him get what he wants and exclaims that karma is a bitch.
19) Later, she buys a drink for Apolo who gets too drunk and doesn’t want to go back to his place.
20) She takes him to her place with the help of her friend, Daniela.
21) On the way to her place, Apolo accidentally breaks her phone.
22) Ares again climbs up her window and says that until their father goes to work, they can’t go back home.
23) Ares opens up to her about his grandfather’s death and how he too has allergies just like him.
24) Ares gifts Raquel a new phone but she isn’t very pleased with this gesture.
25) So she goes to his house to return the phone but things get too steamy and they end up having sex.
26) But after this, Ares acts indifferent which makes Raquel really angry and she storms off.
27) She realizes that she has left her locket at his place so she goes back to get it.
28) She ends up staying the night but in the morning he again dismisses her and makes her leave.
29) Raquel’s friends, Daniela and Yoshi bring her to a party to help her take her mind off of Ares where she gets drunk.
30) Ares sees her in the street in a vulnerable position and takes her to her house.
31) Ares admits that he has been pushing her away as she makes him feel things and how his father has already set a path for him which he has follow.
32) A path that doesn’t involve falling for any girl.
33) Ares tells Raquel that he genuinely does care about her and asks her to give him another chance.
34) Everything seems to be going well this time.
35) But that is until Ares takes Raquel to a family party to prove a point to his father.
36) There, Raquel feels humiliated when she sees her mother working as a waiter.
37) Raquel has a heartfelt conversation with her mother where she tells her not to follow in the footsteps of her father.
38) Her father was a great writer but he never had the courage to publish his novel.
39) She encourages her to cut all the drama and just tell Ares how she really feels about him.
40) Raquel goes to Ares’s place to tell him just that but isn’t allowed into the house as everyone in his family feels that she is a distraction that will stop him from attaining his goals.
41) Ares disobeys everyone and runs to the prom where he is shunned by Yoshi for breaking Raquel’s heart so many times.
42) Yoshi is furious and doesn’t let Ares speak to Raquel.
43) They exchange words that lead to a fight where Yoshi pushes Ares into a partially empty pool, spilling chlorine into as he turns away.
44) Raquel visits him at the hospital and stays by his side the whole time until he completely recovers.
45) After the scare, Ares’s family lets him do what he wants.
46) So, he decided to study medicine in Stockholm.
47) At the airport, Ares confesses that he had purposefully broken their Wi-Fi so that he could talk to her.
48) Raquel is finally brave enough to tell her story, so four months later she publishes her book called ‘Through My Window’.
49) The end credits roll as we see Ares climb up her window to surprise her.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)

Ground Truth Turning Points:
- Opportunity (tp1): 10.0 - Introductory event that occurs after presenting the setting and background of the main characters.
- Change of Plans (tp2): 14.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 33.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 26.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 44.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:
Let's analyze the story and classify its story arc type.

### 1. Identify the protagonist in the story

The protagonist in the story is Raquel.

### 2. First Turning Point (Opportunity)

 Sentence: "Apolo thanks Raquel for letting them use her Wi-Fi as theirs is broken." (Sentence 10)

At this point, Raquel's state is neutral. She is simply being thanked by Apolo for using her Wi-Fi. However, this event sets off a chain of interactions between Raquel and the Hidalgo brothers, particularly Ares. 

Protagonist's condition: 5

### 3. Second Turning Point (Change of Plans)

 Sentence: "They exchange words which leads to Raquel admitting that she likes him and wants him to fall for her." (Sentence 14)

At this point, Raquel's state has changed relative to the first turning point. She has now expressed her feelings to Ares and has taken a risk by being vulnerable. This marks a change in her plans, as she is now actively pursuing a relationship with Ares.

Protagonist's condition: 7

### 4. Third Turning Point (Point of No Return)

 Sentence: "Ares tells Raquel that he genuinely does care about her and asks her to give him another chance." (Sentence 33)

At this point, Raquel's state has changed relative to the second turning point. Ares has now expressed his genuine feelings for her, and she has to decide whether to give him another chance. This marks a point of no return, as Raquel has to commit to her decision.

Protagonist's condition: 8

### 5. Fourth Turning Point (Major Setback)

 Sentence: "But after this, Ares acts indifferent which makes Raquel really angry and she storms off." (Sentence 26)

At this point, Raquel's state has changed relative to the third turning point. Ares' indifferent behavior has caused a major setback in their relationship, and Raquel is now angry and hurt.

Protagonist's condition: 3

### 6. Fifth Turning Point (Climax)

 Sentence: "Raquel visits him at the hospital and stays by his side the whole time until he completely recovers." (Sentence 44)

At this point, Raquel's state has changed relative to the fourth turning point. Despite Ares' previous behavior, Raquel shows her love and care for him by visiting him at the hospital and staying by his side. This marks a climax in their relationship, as they have now overcome their previous setbacks.

Protagonist's condition: 9

### 7. Protagonist's Condition List

[5, 7, 8, 3, 9]

### 8. Classify the Story Arc Type

Based on the protagonist's condition list, the story arc type can be classified as Cinderella. The protagonist starts in a neutral state (5), rises to a higher state (7, 8), faces a major setback (3), and ultimately achieves a higher state (9). This follows the classic Cinderella story arc pattern.

### 9. Determined Story Arc Type

Cinderella

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) The narrative introduced Max, who had once lived a life full of zest and danger as an intrepid explorer, trading challenging adventures for fame.
2) Now well-known as an environmental celebrity, Max graced the stages of countless conferences as a keynote speaker, disseminating the importance of wildlife conservation.
3) Over time, Max started to feel a growing sense of detachment, the adrenalin of the past trickling away, replaced by an overpowering yearning for his old life laden with exhilarating quests and groundbreaking discoveries.
4) His mundane routine was suddenly interrupted when he received an extraordinary proposition from Dmitry Blackwood.
5) Blackwood, a prominent member of the Abyss Exploration Initiative, introduced an ambitious plan.
6) With a spark in his eyes, Blackwood shared his daring dream to plunge into the depths of the Mariana Trench.
7) The trench, well-known for its depth, was long suspected to house gigantic prehistoric megalodons, a fact that made Max's heart race with excitement.
8) Max was initially hesitant, considering the enormous risks involved.
9) Nonetheless, his inherited yearn for fresh adventures and penchant for uncharted territories guided him towards what was seemingly an audacious journey.
10) He arrived at Poseidon, an impressive floating marine research facility set to serve as the central hub for the upcoming thrilling voyage, teeming with anticipation.
11) Amid the team of seasoned scientific personnel, he came across Dr. Zoe Harper, a dedicated marine biologist driven by an unwavering dedication to preserve marine life.
12) This diverse group of expert researchers was the crème de la crème in their respective fields.
13) Max's ideologies clashed with Zoe's, their shared commitment to marine preservation sparking numerous lively debates.
14) The tension between them burgeoned into a dynamic, passionate relationship.
15) The team underwent an extensive training period, equipping themselves physically and mentally for the trials they were about to face.
16) They meticulously checked and double-checked all equipment, finally securing themselves inside the Nautilus, a revolutionary submarine designed specially for the extremities of deep-sea travel.
17) Integrating Max's expert navigational knowledge, the team began their astounding descent into the ominous and unsettling depths, where adventure awaited.
18) As they descended into the heart of the ocean, they were left awe-struck by the enchanting bioluminescence of the deep-sea organisms, their eyes gleaming with wonder as they navigated this glowing, underwater realm.
19) The further down they journeyed, the stranger the creatures they encountered.
20) Gigantic prehistoric plants coupled with ancient, previously unseen marine life set a breathtaking spectacle, effectively reigniting Max's latent love for exploration.
21) In the midst of their initial jubilation, the team was jolted back to reality when an enormous megalodon raced towards the Nautilus, its jaws snapping as it hit the vessel with a thunderous impact.
22) The unexpected attack severely crippled their submarine, effectively stranding them miles beneath the ocean surface amidst a hostile marine environment.
23) They continued their journey with trepidation, eventually discovering a labyrinth sprawling with more of these terrifying sea giants inhabiting the vast gloom.
24) Dubbed as "The Megalodon’s Den", the crew came to realise the audacious marine world they were entangled within.
25) Faced with a dangerous struggle for survival, they had to deal with limited oxygen reserves, encroaching water within the vessel, and the ever-pervasive dread of the circling megalodons, each second ticking away being a match against death.
26) While attempting to salvage their vessel, Max and Zoe stumbled upon what seemed to be an unsanctioned deep-sea mining operation.
27) The operation, run by Blackwater Industries, was ominously located within the deadly depths.
28) Their worst fears were realised as they discovered that the mining activities were ruthlessly mutilating the delicate marine ecosystem, probably triggering the aggressive behaviour of the megalodons.
29) Cornered by these ghastly realities and their primal fear of the undersea predators, Max and Zoe made a steadfast resolve – they would raise their voices against these atrocities.
30) Risking the impending danger awaiting outside the Nautilus, they cautiously ventured out into the monstrous aquatic realm, embarking on a perilous mission to collect compelling evidence against Blackwater Industries' illicit operations.
31) Back inside the Nautilus, the rest of the crew worked with renewed urgency and desperation, attempting to salvage their crippled vessel.
32) Max and Zoe encountered numerous near-death experiences as they ventured deeper into the ocean, roving megalodons bordering their paths.
33) However, they finally managed to land their hands on a significant amount of damning evidence against the mining operation.
34) Their mission complete, they quickly swam back towards the safety of Nautilus, their hearts pounding as relentless predators gave chase.
35) The following hours were marked with frantic struggles as the crew grappled in a suspenseful battle against the incensed megalodons.
36) At the same time, they made desperate attempts to revive the operation of the battered Nautilus.
37) Deciding to risk their final remaining reserves of oxygen, they managed to painfully coax the surviving engines back to life, just as their last breaths were threatening to slip away.
38) Reactivating the propulsion system, the Nautilus shot upwards, barely evading the lethal jaws of a charging megalodon, a thrilling near-miss that left their hearts pounding.
39) Breaking free to the world above the water, they took deep gasping breaths of fresh air, consumed by a combination of relief and shock from the nightmarish ordeal.
40) Even in their weariness, Max and Zoe managed a triumphant smile, basking in their narrow victory against death.
41) They didn't waste any time to procure the needed attention to their shocking discovery.
42) With irrefutable evidence in hand, they exposed Blackwater Industries' illegal mining operations to international media.
43) The revelation resulted in an international scandal, causing global outrage against the criminal corporation.
44) The authorities were quick to respond, promptly shutting down all of Blackwater Industries’ unsanctioned operations.
45) Encouraged by the unplumbed depths of the marine ecosystem discovered, the government approved explorations to scientifically study and protect 'The Megalodon’s Den.'
46) Hailed as environmentalists and heroes, Max and Zoe spearheaded efforts towards the preservation of this newfound underwater sanctuary.
47) As the curtain rolled down on their story, the scene cleverly shifted from the floating Poseidon into the depths of the Mariana trench.
48) The audience was then taken on a hauntingly mesmeric underwater tour deep into an unexplored cavern.
49) The path was eerily lit by an array of soft glows from bioluminescent creatures, the scene dwarfed by an overwhelming panoramic view of the massive cavern.
50) The camera skillfully navigated the labyrinthine cavern, pausing at a particularly intriguing area.
51) The eeriness of the cavern was suddenly shattered by a slow rustling sound.
52) Illuminated by the faint bioluminescence, two gigantic eyes reflected in the camera, invoking a wave of chilling dread in the audience.
53) The eyes blinked menacingly, emanating an ominous aura thick with suspense.
54) As the glow from sea fauna glisten in the creature's eyes, a vast silhouette hinted at a marine creature dwarfing even the indomitable megalodons.
55) Even with the recent publicity around the underwater ecosystem, the introduction of this new, more formidable creature hinted at a cascade of looming threats and unseen dangers.
56) From Max and Zoe's impending battle against more environmental infractions to the terrifying lurking leviathan, the audience was left gripping their seats in anticipation.
57) The narrative ended on a high note, embedding the tantalizing impression of another adrenaline-charged encounter of 'The Megalodon’s Den'.

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) In 1944–45, Ivan has moved to Russia to study brain research and he leaves the puppets with Elisa.
2) During this time Elisa begins to have vivid nightmares about Elsa's death and Major Kraus.
3) She soon realizes this is psychic memories that she is picking up from Blade and she also has vivid visions of Blade in distress, explosions and an evil doctor and she knows these are events which will transpire.
4) Blade is the only one of the puppets that can make slight movements, despite having virtually no elixir left in his body and he spends his time either hiding behind the trunk like a guardian or observing Elisa as she bathes.
5) Elisa notices Blade is different from the other puppets and he is able to feed off of her psychic energy and she also sees that his knife is dull and she sharpens it up but cuts herself by mistake, which causes her to bleed and this creates a blood bond between the two.
6) She also uses her psychic powers to look inside of Blade, and thereby possibly discover who he was in his human life.
7) Meanwhile, Dr. Hauser, a Nazi doctor that was a former colleague of Hess, is continuing the Deathcorp Project at a hideout in California and is performing experiments on innocent victims.
8) His project is funded by an American district attorney, James D. Madison, who has betrayed America and had sided with the Nazis.
9) Madison also has top secret files from the government which have scans of the Scroll of Osiris, as well as photos and information about Toulon's puppets.
10) Blade manages to have enough energy to sneak out into the night to participate in his own solo Nazi hunting and he hides out at a factory under a sheet and Officer Bruce, a corrupt American police officer is also there and stealing supplies for the Nazis.
11) Bruce hears Blade's footsteps and discovers him under the sheet and calls him Pinocchio before hitting him across the room with his baton.
12) Bruce picks up Blade to hit him again but Blade uses his eye spikes to impale Bruce's hand, which causes him to smack Blade against a wall, which only causes the spikes to go in further.
13) Blade manages to break free and musters enough strength to impales Bruce's ankle with his hook and drag him across the room and then finishes him off by sawing his head off violently with his knife.
14) During this time Elisa is at home dreaming of these events as they play out and she feels a jolt of power every time Blade's knife is used, which reveals a psychic link between the two.
15) Later on Gloria Vasquez, a Spanish nationalist spy and her henchman break into Elisa's apartment and tare the place apart looking for Blade and the scroll of Osiris.
16) They manage to find the scroll hidden behind a painting and then she uses a special chemical to put press photographer Barney Barnes to sleep and take him back to be experimented on by Hauser.
17) During this time Blade was observing the events from a closet, before moving to the window where he had hung on by the tip of his hook, he then jumped down many stories and landed on the ground without any sign of injury and followed Gloria to Hauser's secret hideout.
18) Meanwhile, Madison used a smoke bomb at the Daily Herald to knock Elisa and detective Joe Gray unconscious and also take them back to the hideout and Blade was already there and hiding behind a shelf.
19) Joe is chained up on the ceiling and his leg is broken with a wrench and Elisa is strapped to a torture device and repeatedly electrocuted and asked to hand over the translation of the scroll of Osiris, as Hauser was unable to do it himself as he did not understand Russian, Greek and Egyptian symbols, he also reveals that he plans to uses a giant Death Ray on the roof to shoot out a signal which will kill half the population of California and then revive them as murderous zombies that will follow orders from the Nazi regime.
20) Elisa refuses and is continued to be electrocuted with the torture device but she uses her psychic bio-energy to shut the machine down.
21) After this Blade cuts Joe down from his chain and systematically goes on a killing spree across the hideout and he begins by putting his hook into the mouth of one of the henchman and cutting him in the back of the head and slitting his throat.
22) He then is fired at by Lang's gun but each bullet misses and Blade finishes him off with a few stabs to the throat.
23) Hauser then uses his machine to transform Barney into a zombie slave to go after Blade, but he attacks Gloria instead, biting her and leaving her for dead and then Blade stabs her in the throat before putting Barney out his misery by cutting his leg and then sticking his knife through the back of his head and out the front of his mouth.
24) Blade then kills the Nazi that is operating the torture machine by slitting his throat and then runs full speed at Hauser.
25) Hauser manages to grab Blade with his mechanical hand and then puts him into a scorching hot furnace.
26) Elisa is stunned on the floor as she is experiencing Blade's pain and then Hauser wants to prove that the puppets can be destroyed, despite them being magical, by hitting Blade over and over with a sledgehammer.
27) Elisa is also feels every strike of pain through her strong psychic connection with Blade and Hauser eventually smashes Blade's head to pieces, which causes his entire body to combust into ash.
28) Hauser is proud to have defeated Blade but also disappointed he could not keep the knife as a souvenir and then Hauser accidentally breathes in the bio-energy that emits from Blade's corpse, which causes Blade to be fully reborn within Hauser's belly and he kills Hauser by chopping his way out.
29) For a few moments Blade's facial form has changed to display his eyes in an evil frown but after putting his hat on, the face changes back to his regular face and all of Hauser's blood mysterious vanishes.
30) This attack on Hauser was unfinished business between Blade in his human life and his former colleague.
31) After Hauser died, his 'dead-man's switch' on his mechanical hand had been set off which meant that the Death Ray was going to shoot out its signal, so Joe hands Blade a wrench and he climbs inside of the machine and breaks the inside.
32) This causes the ray and the hideout to explode and Blade, Elisa and Joe manage to escape unharmed.
33) After this Elisa prints a story about a killer puppet foiling a Nazi death plot in her newspaper article and because the Daily Herald is known for printing fictitious tabloid headlines then it is not believed by the public.
34) After this Joe uses Blade to climb through the vent in Madison's office and unlock the door.
35) When Madison arrives he is ambushed by Blade and he is killed by having his throat slit and so that his corpse would look like he had committed suicide.
36) After this Joe sets out with Blade on a mission to track down more double crossing Americans that are assisting the Nazis.

   Relative to the second turning point, Blade has become more proactive and bold, taking risks and demonstrating his physical abilities. Approximate condition: 7.
