input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) A small, peaceful town named Edgewater is introduced, awakening to the promise of a new day.
2) The film opens with John Smith's regular morning routine.
3) John is a quiet, middle-aged man who teaches science and math at the local high school.
4) He meticulously prepares a breakfast of spinach and egg omelet, demonstrating the meticulousness with which he approaches every aspect of his life.
5) While his breakfast cooks, he occupies himself with complex algebraic puzzles.
6) The scent of toasting whole wheat bread fills his modest kitchen as he solves mathematical problems with great passion.
7) His immense love for numbers and formulas is made apparent by a calculus textbook propped open next to his steaming cup of coffee.
8) John bids cheerful good mornings to his neighbors, the Millers, elderly folk who have been a staple in the town for years.
9) He steps into his small yet reliable silver Honda Accord, beginning his usual commute down a scenic route surrounded by large oak trees towards the well-established Lincoln Henderson Secondary School.
10) Scenes from the school show John teaching physics to a class of thirty students in a slightly outdated classroom.
11) His excitement for the subject infectious, John has inspired a group of students who listen with unwavering attention pinned to their worn-out desks.
12) During his lunch breaks, John makes a habit of grading assignments in the busy teacher's lounge.
13) He delights in the steady understanding his students are gaining, leaving encouraging words with a red pen on each paper.
14) However, amidst the sea of standard assignments, one stands out to John - a curious numerical code '2, 4, 6' scrawled haphazardly on an assignment from Pete, a silent boy recognized by his classmates for his exceptional intelligence.
15) John, intrigued by the specific code, sacrifices his favorite pastime - birdwatching - to delve further into the numbers.
16) This shift captures John’s unyielding curiosity and commitment to understanding.
17) His leisure time becomes dedicated to deciphering the hidden message in those three seemingly ordinary numbers written hastily on a piece of notebook paper that had seen better days.
18) After spending countless hours analyzing the code with the help of graph paper and a scientific calculator, he uncovers two secret meeting spots in the school—an old janitor's closet and a forgotten, dust-filled storage area in the basement.
19) As John probes further, armed with only a small flashlight and his ceaseless inquisitiveness, he makes a disturbing discovery.
20) Not only are there secret meetings, but they also involve plans related to dangerous C-4 explosives.
21) The grim reality sets in; the numbers '2 4 6' signifies a plot to attack a school of over a thousand lives - students, teachers, and staff members alike.
22) Before he can warn the local Edgewater police, a group of imposing figures concealed behind masks manage to kidnap him during one of his covert investigations in the school’s poorly lit basement.
23) From the darkness, a gloved figure, towering above John and donning an ominous mask, warns him about the true significance of the '2 4 6', leaving him on edge and anxious.
24) Using his scientific background, John manages to execute a clever escape from the group's secret hideout, hidden within the grimy, decaying structures of Edgewater’s old industrial district.
25) Back at Lincoln Henderson Secondary School, several students, including the vibrant Sarah and introverted yet intelligent Tim, notice their science teacher's uncharacteristic absence.
26) Motivated by their combined curiosity and fondness for John, they discover a trail of half-solved puzzles that John had left behind on his mahogany desk covered carefully with stacks of assignments and books.
27) Sensing the enormity of the situation, they decide to follow in their mentor’s footsteps.
28) Together, they take on the numerical challenge armed with high-school algebra textbooks and a sense of determined camaraderie.
29) With sheer determination, they work together to unravel the remnants of the numerical puzzle that John was so obsessed with, detailed in his crisp and distinct handwriting.
30) Their relentless pursuit for truth leads them to a shocking discovery—the code '2 4 6' directly points at Pete's father, the esteemed government official, Mr. Anderson, always impeccably garbed in charcoal suits.
31) Slowly, the pieces fall together in a shockingly precise manner—the '2 4 6' represents the exact date and time – 2nd April at 6 PM, marking the impending catastrophe.
32) United by a common purpose, John and his team of five students set out on a mission against time to prevent the terrifying attack on their beloved school.
33) As the clock relentlessly ticks away, they attempt to convince the unflinching detective James about the imminent danger, all the while secretly gathering evidence against Mr. Anderson.
34) Through tense conversations on burner phones and whispered exchanges in abandoned alleyways, their frantic warnings begin to echo through the hallways of the Edgewater Police Department.
35) Finally, the dogged determination and teamwork of John and his students manage to blow Mr. Anderson's plot wide open, pulling back the curtain on his horrifying plans.
36) With the warning received just in time, the Edgewater SWAT team swoops in defusing the potentially deadly explosives in the nick of time, safeguarding the lives of the innocent people confined within the old school building.
37) Surviving the harrowing ordeal, John and his students find themselves sharing a moment of profound relief, safe within the familiar walls of their beloved Lincoln Henderson Secondary School.
38) After the drama unfolds and life returns to relatively normal, John resumes his quiet teaching role, armed with his chalk, blackboard, and an unforgettable tale of bravery.
39) The bond between John and his students evolves, their mutual respect, trust, and admiration cemented during their unexpected, dangerous adventure.
40) His entrance into the classroom is met with newfound reverence and admiration.
41) The words MR. JOHN SMITH, enshrined in gold letters on their classroom door, now hold a deeper significance.
42) His students have gained a new perspective on algebra and quantum physics; they have witnessed firsthand these subjects' power to decode the world's mysteries.
43) John rekindles his morning routine of delicious omelets and crispy toasts, his love for solving puzzles and decoding secrets still burning bright in his eyes.
44) The flame of curiosity and determination to unfold the hidden meaning behind the numbers lights up their faces, mirroring the spirit of their beloved science teacher.
45) Edgewater welcomes a fresh morning, with cheerful students stepping out of their cherry-red doors, prepared to face any impending challenges head-on.

- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)

- Change of Plans (tp2): 14.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 32.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 22.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 35.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:
### TASK RESPONSE

1. **Protagonist Identification:** The protagonist in the story is John Smith, a quiet, middle-aged man who teaches science and math at the local high school.

2. **First Turning Point (Opportunity, tp1):** Sentence 11: "His excitement for the subject infectious, John has inspired a group of students who listen with unwavering attention pinned to their worn-out desks." 
   - At this point, John is in a good state, doing what he loves (teaching) and inspiring his students. His condition can be approximated as 8 out of 10.

3. **Second Turning Point (Change of Plans, tp2):** Sentence 14: "However, amidst the sea of standard assignments, one stands out to John - a curious numerical code '2, 4, 6' scrawled haphazardly on an assignment from Pete, a silent boy recognized by his classmates for his exceptional intelligence."
   - Relative to the first turning point, John's curiosity is piqued, and he begins to shift his focus towards solving the mystery of the code. This change in plans signifies a slight drop in his condition due to the uncertainty and challenge presented, approximating his condition as 7 out of 10.

4. **Third Turning Point (Point of No Return, tp3):** Sentence 32: "United by a common purpose, John and his team of five students set out on a mission against time to prevent the terrifying attack on their beloved school."
   - Here, John fully commits to solving the mystery and preventing the attack, which marks a significant increase in his determination and involvement. However, the danger and urgency of the situation also increase the stakes, making his condition more precarious. Thus, his condition can be approximated as 6 out of 10.

5. **Fourth Turning Point (Major Setback, tp4):** Sentence 22: "Before he can warn the local Edgewater police, a group of imposing figures concealed behind masks manage to kidnap him during one of his covert investigations in the school’s poorly lit basement."
   - This event marks a significant setback for John, as he is kidnapped and faces direct danger, making his condition the lowest in the story so far, approximating it as 2 out of 10.

6. **Fifth Turning Point (Climax, tp5):** Sentence 35: "Finally, the dogged determination and teamwork of John and his students manage to blow Mr. Anderson's plot wide open, pulling back the curtain on his horrifying plans."
   - At this point, John and his students successfully prevent the attack, resolving the main conflict of the story. John's condition improves significantly, approximating it as 10 out of 10, as he has overcome the challenges and achieved his goal.

7. **Protagonist's Condition List:** [8, 7, 6, 2, 10]

8. **Story Arc Type Classification:** The story follows the "Man in a Hole" arc type. This classification is based on the protagonist's condition starting relatively high, then dropping to a low point (the hole), and finally rising to an even higher point than at the beginning. The significant drop in the protagonist's condition followed by a recovery to a state better than the initial one is characteristic of the "Man in a Hole" story arc.

9. **Determined Story Arc Type:** Man in a Hole

input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) In 2003, senior CIA official Donald Fitzroy visited a prisoner named Courtland Gentry in Florida.
2) Eight years earlier, Courtland was a minor convicted of killing his abusive father to protect his brother.
3) Fitzroy offers him his freedom in exchange for working as an assassin in the CIA's Sierra program.
4) In 2021, Courtland, now known as Sierra Six, is working with fellow CIA agent Dani Miranda to assassinate a target named Dining Car suspected of selling off national security secrets in Bangkok during the national Songkran festival.
5) Unable to do so stealthily without harming civilians, he attacks Dining Car directly, mortally wounding him.
6) Before dying, he reveals he was also in the Sierra program as Sierra Four.
7) He hands Six an encrypted drive detailing the corruption of CIA official Denny Carmichael, the lead agent on the assassination mission.
8) Carmichael is elusive about the true purpose of the mission and the contents of the drive when confronted by Six, and Six refuses evacuation from Bangkok with Carmichael's men.
9) Sending the drive to former Sierra Program handler Margaret Cahill in Prague, he calls a now-retired Fitzroy to request extraction.
10) Carmichael hires mercenary Lloyd Hansen, a former CIA agent kicked out for his sociopathnic tendencies, to track down Six and retrieve the drive.
11) Hansen does so by kidnapping Fitzroy's niece Claire, forcing Fitzroy to authorize Six's murder by the extraction team.
12) However, Six kills them and escapes.
13) Frustrated, Carmichael sends his subordinate Suzanne Brewer to oversee Hansen and keep him in line.
14) Hansen keeps Claire hostage in a mansion in Croatia, at his base of operations.
15) He also puts a massive bounty on Six's head to get mercenaries and assassins to hunt him down.
16) Six heads to Vienna to find the serial number of Claire's pacemaker from Laszlo Sosa, but he betrays him for the bounty.
17) Six escapes just as Hansen arrives with his team and kills Sosa, while Six kills all of Hansen's teammates and is rescued by Miranda from Hansen.
18) Her reputation is shot thanks to the Bangkok mission and she initially plans to bring him in to salvage her CIA career.
19) Six convinces her to drive him to Cahill's apartment in Prague, where she decrypts the drive.
20) It reveals the extent of Carmichael's corruption on behalf of a mysterious benefactor working for a shadow government.
21) Hansen sends several teams of assassins to Cahill, and the terminally ill Cahill blows up her home, so Six and Miranda can escape.
22) Six is arrested and handcuffed in the square.
23) A massive shootout in Prague resulted in all the police officers present slaughtered and Six escaped on a tram.
24) After a long chase and gun battle, Six is once again saved by Miranda, in Cahill's bulletproof car.
25) They infiltrate a hospital to track down Claire through her pacemaker's wireless signal.
26) A Tamil mercenary, Avik San also known as "Lone Wolf" steals the drive from them, knocking them out, and bringing it to Hansen.
27) Six and Miranda follow the pacemaker to Hansen's base.
28) She creates a distraction while he infiltrates the mansion rescuing Fitzroy and Claire.
29) Mortally wounded as they flee, Fitzroy sacrifices himself attempting to kill Hansen.
30) Miranda knocks out Hansen's men, but Lone Wolf narrowly escapes.
31) He defeats her in a fight, but gives her the drive, having become disgusted with Hansen's lack of morals and honour.
32) Hansen takes Claire hostage and drags her into a hedge maze.
33) After a standoff, he lets go of Claire and fights with Six.
34) Before Six can kill him, Brewer shoots Hansen.
35) She then tells Six that she plans to pin Carmichael's actions on Hansen to gain leverage over him.
36) Furthermore, Brewer pledges for Claire's safety, but only if Six continues to work for the CIA.
37) Six and Miranda are forced to cooperate in the cover-up, where ultimately no action is taken against Carmichael.
38) After the debriefing at the CIA headquarters, Miranda threatens to kill Carmichael if any harm comes to Claire.
39) Six escapes custody and frees Claire, who was being held at a secret location.

- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

Ground Truth Turning Points:
- Opportunity (tp1): 4.0 - Introductory event that occurs after presenting the setting and background of the main characters.
- Change of Plans (tp2): 7.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 17.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 22.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 39.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:
### TASK SOLUTION

1. The protagonist in the story is Courtland Gentry, also known as Sierra Six.

2. The first turning point (Opportunity, tp1) is sentence 4: "In 2021, Courtland, now known as Sierra Six, is working with fellow CIA agent Dani Miranda to assassinate a target named Dining Car suspected of selling off national security secrets in Bangkok during the national Songkran festival." 
   At this point, Six is a skilled and active CIA operative, but he's also somewhat of a prisoner of his circumstances, having traded his freedom for a life of service to the CIA. His condition can be approximated as a 6.

3. The second turning point (Change of Plans, tp2) is sentence 7: "He hands Six an encrypted drive detailing the corruption of CIA official Denny Carmichael, the lead agent on the assassination mission." 
   This revelation sets Six on a path of self-discovery and opposition to the corrupt forces within the CIA. His situation has become more complicated and potentially perilous, but he's also gained a sense of purpose and autonomy. His condition can be approximated as a 5.

4. The third turning point (Point of No Return, tp3) is sentence 17: "Six escapes just as Hansen arrives with his team and kills Sosa, while Six kills all of Hansen's teammates and is rescued by Miranda from Hansen." 
   At this point, Six has fully committed to his goal of uncovering the truth and taking down the corrupt CIA officials. He's had a narrow escape and has lost some resources, but he's also gained an ally in Miranda and has demonstrated his ability to outfight his opponents. His condition can be approximated as a 7.

5. The fourth turning point (Major Setback, tp4) is sentence 22: "Six is arrested and handcuffed in the square." 
   This is a significant setback for Six, as he's lost his freedom and is at the mercy of his enemies. His condition can be approximated as a 1.

6. The fifth turning point (Climax, tp5) is sentence 39: "Six escapes custody and frees Claire, who was being held at a secret location." 
   In the end, Six manages to escape and free Claire, but the corrupt officials remain at large, and he's forced to go on the run. His condition can be approximated as a 4.

7. The list of the protagonist's condition at each turning point is: [6, 5, 7, 1, 4]

8. Based on the protagonist's condition list, the story arc type can be classified as Oedipus. This is because the protagonist starts in a relatively high state (6), falls to a lower state (5), recovers and rises to an even higher state (7), then faces a significant downfall (1), and finally ends in a lower state than at the beginning (4). This pattern of rise, fall, recovery, and ultimate downfall is characteristic of the Oedipus story arc type.

9. Oedipus

input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Kelly Ferguson was plagued by nightmares as a young child.
2) She is still nicknamed Monster Girl as a high school freshman in Rhode Island because she had told people a monster had attacked her at five.
3) Although planning to attend a senior's Halloween party that night, Kelly's mom has told her boss Ms. Zellman that Kelly can babysit her son Jacob so she can attend their office party.
4) The single mother gives her pages of information, of dos and don'ts.
5) Once they're alone, Jacob tells Kelly about the monsters that plague him, showing her drawings of them.
6) Kelly tells him that he'll stop dreaming of them in the future, like she did, then she checks for monsters under the bed and in the closet before handing him a little lights to ward off dark things.
7) A few  minutes later she hurries back, only to find three small monsters abducting him.
8) While Kelly calls 911, Liz Lerue shows up.
9) She is part of a secret society of children-protecting babysitters, and she calls the small monsters who carried off Jacob toadies.
10) They go on a mission to find the boy, who has been kidnapped by the Boogeyman.
11) Liz uses the infant she cares for to lure out the toadies, after tracking them down.
12) However, the shiny object she offers it for Jacob doesn't tempt it as it normally would.
13) The toadies deliver Jacob to the Boogeyman, who gleefully explains how he plans to collect an army of monsters, thanks to Jacob's ability to imagine a large variety of them.
14) He sets up Jacob in a bed, hooks his head in a helmet designed to extract his nightmares, and tries to lull him to sleep.
15) Meanwhile, after Liz returns the baby to her home, the girls go to Brown University to the Rhode Island Order of Babysitters headquarters.
16) The vicepresident, she tasks the trainees (SITs) with emptying the pouch of the toadie they've captured and searching for Jacob.
17) Using a magic dust to recover memory, Kelly recalls the Boogeyman telling her at five that she has the ability to bring her dreams to life.
18) She realizes he's the Grand Guignol, a stealer of dreams and bringer of nightmares.
19) All of the SITs share scars from their own run-ins with boogeymen as small children.
20) They will have to imbed Angel Hair potion in the Boogeyman with a monster punch.
21) Curtis searches the globe for the ingredients.
22) In the meantime, he provides Kelly with a few tools to help her on their quest.
23) Feeding the toadie a tracker, they let it escape in hopes it will lead them to the Boogeyman.
24) The toadie finds the tracker and informs the Boogeyman, who sets up a trap.
25) Led to the Halloween party Kelly had wanted to attend, Liz and an unenthusiastic Kelly enter, seeking the tracker.
26) A shadow monster awaits them in the basement.
27) Chasing it around the house, they eventually realize they were led to a dead end.
28) Next, the girls try to prevent the cat's eye amulet from being used by the Boogeyman, but are unsuccessful.
29) Kelly escapes, but he captures Liz.
30) Simultaneously both Curtis is concocting the Angel Hair potion while Kelly finds and breaks into the condemned lighthouse where Jacob is being held and the nightmares are starting to be extracted.
31) The toadies try to cage Kelly, but she outwits them.
32) A hypnotised Liz locks her up, but she uses a multi-functional tool from Curtis which knocks her down and snaps her back to normal.
33) In the chamber where the nightmare creatures are about to be released by the Boogeyman, Kelly knocks the Angel Hair given to her by a SIT into him with a monster punch and an awakened Jacob dissipates the nightmare monsters.
34) Getting Jacob home before Ms. Zellman arrives, Kelly is commended for getting Jacob to sleep.
35) Not only is she asked to babysit the next night, but Liz tells her she's going to recommend her to the Order of Babysitters and her crush Victor asks her out.

1.  The protagonist in the story is Kelly Ferguson.

2.  The sentence corresponding to the first turning point (Opportunity) is approximately at sentence 2.5. Since it's not a clear sentence, we can analyze Kelly's state around that point. Kelly is still nicknamed Monster Girl as a high school freshman in Rhode Island because she had told people a monster had attacked her at five. At this point, Kelly's state is somewhat low due to the embarrassing nickname and her past experiences; I would rate her condition a 4 out of 10.

3.  The second turning point is Change of Plans, which corresponds to sentence 8. Liz Lerue shows up and introduces Kelly to a secret society of children-protecting babysitters. 5.  The fourth turning point is Major Setback, which corresponds to sentence 27. Chasing it around the house, they eventually realize they were led to a dead end. This event is a significant setback for Kelly, as she and Liz were outsmarted by the Boogeyman; I would rate her condition a 3 out of 10.

6.  The fifth turning point is Climax, which corresponds to sentence 33. Kelly knocks the Angel Hair given to her by a SIT into him with a monster punch and an awakened Jacob dissipates the nightmare monsters. This event marks a significant triumph for Kelly, as she successfully rescues Jacob and defeats the Boogeyman; I would rate her condition a 10 out of 10.

7.  The list of protagonist's condition in chronological order is: [4, 6, 8, 3, 10].

8.  Based on the protagonist's condition list, we can classify the story arc type. The story follows a pattern where the protagonist's condition improves, then worsens, and finally improves significantly. instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) A young Kurt Warner watches Super Bowl XIX.
2) He then makes a lifelong commitment to becoming a Super Bowl and MVP quarterback.
3) Several years later, Kurt is playing his fifth year for the University of Northern Iowa (UNI) Panthers with coach Terry Allen, and nothing is going Warner's way.
4) Allen threatens to bench him after repeatedly not heeding his coaching, which would effectively end Warner's NFL dream.
5) After a brutal practice following the coach's orders, Kurt continues to be the starter and his numbers climb to where he could have a chance at the Draft.
6) Meanwhile, Kurt becomes interested in a woman he sees dancing at a country bar, so decides to learn how to dance to impress her.
7) Her name is Brenda, is a single mom with two kids and is a nursing student struggling financially.
8) Even though she doesn't think it will work out, Kurt is persistent, walking three miles to her house to get her number.
9) He finds out she was a Marine corporal and that her son is disabled.
10) Kurt instantly bonds with the children, convincing her to be together.
11) With his last season of college football over, Kurt anxiously awaits the draft.
12) He doesn't get picked and wonders why God gave him a dream that he would never obtain.
13) Later, the Green Bay Packers give him the chance to try out, but it goes badly and Kurt goes home dejected.
14) Becoming homeless, he moves into Brenda's basement.
15) He takes a job at a Hy-Vee grocery store, working nights stocking shelves.
16) He discovers success is not found on the football field, but how one acts when confronted with disappointment.
17) Brenda's parents sell the house and move to another state, putting them in a tough situation, and the couple continue to struggle.
18) At one point, their car runs out of gas and Kurt walks several miles in a blizzard to get gas.
19) Kurt gets approached by Jim Foster, who offers him the quarterback position for the Arena Football League's Iowa Barnstormers.
20) Kurt agrees after discovering no one in the NFL is interested in him.
21) Arena football is different.
22) The field is smaller and the play is much more fast-paced.
23) He loses his first game but wins the next.
24) Kurt and Brenda's relationship is strained from the long commute, and they briefly break up.
25) Brenda's parents are killed in a tornado and she and Kurt decide to get back together.
26) They marry and Kurt finishes the 1996 Arena Football League season with the Iowa Barnstormers in ArenaBowl X, a heartbreaking loss when his completed pass on the last play of the game comes up one yard short of the end zone.
27) Kurt is invited to another tryout for the St. Louis Rams.
28) He doesn't think he will make it; he is having to re-adjust to normal football.
29) Offensive coordinator Mike Martz berates him relentlessly for every mistake.
30) Head Coach, Dick Vermeil, believes in him and tells Kurt he made the team.
31) When starting quarterback Trent Green goes down with an injury in the 1999 NFL preseason, Kurt eventually takes his place.
32) In his first game, Kurt and the Rams face a strong Baltimore Ravens defense led by linebacker Ray Lewis.
33) After a turnover on his first drive, Kurt picks the Ravens' defense apart.
34) With a 27–10 lead, the Rams go into victory formation, and Warner takes a knee to end the game.
35) He immediately gives thanks to God for the opportunity and kisses Brenda in the stands.
36) The Rams post a 13–3 record that season, becoming known as The Greatest Show on Turf due to the high-powered, Warner-led offense.
37) The Rams went on to defeat the Tennessee Titans in Super Bowl XXXIV.
38) During the game, Kurt breaks Joe Montana's record for throwing the most passing yards in a Super Bowl.
39) Doing so helped him win Super Bowl MVP and be crowned the NFL MVP, making him the first undrafted player to be named either of those in NFL history.
40) The credits show that he would play in two other Super Bowls, Super Bowl XXXVI and Super Bowl XLIII.
41) He becomes enshrined in the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 2017, and he and Brenda continue to live happily married, with seven children.

- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)

### TASK RESPONSE

1. The protagonist in the story is Kurt Warner.

2. The sentence corresponding to the first turning point (Opportunity, tp1) is:
"He then makes a lifelong commitment to becoming a Super Bowl and MVP quarterback."
At this point, Kurt is full of hope and has a clear goal in mind. His condition is around 8, as he is motivated and has a sense of direction.

3. The sentence corresponding to the second turning point (Change of Plans, tp2) is:
"Her name is Brenda, is a single mom with two kids and is a nursing student struggling financially."
This turning point marks a change in Kurt's life as he becomes interested in Brenda and starts to build a relationship with her. His condition remains around 8, as he is still hopeful about his football career and is developing a positive personal life.

However, it seems there was a mistake in the ground truth turning points; this sentence does not seem to match with the definition provided for "Change of Plans." Based on the definition of the second turning point, I would choose:
"Kurt becomes interested in a woman he sees dancing at a country bar, so decides to learn how to dance to impress her."
This alternative sentence still marks Kurt's condition around 8.

4. The sentence corresponding to the third turning point (Point of No Return, tp3) is:
"Kurt gets approached by Jim Foster, who offers him the quarterback position for the Arena Football League's Iowa Barnstormers."
At this point, Kurt's condition has dropped to around 4. Although he has an opportunity to play football, it's not in the NFL, and he has to adjust to a new type of game.

5. The sentence corresponding to the fourth turning point (Major Setback, tp4) is:

Kurt's condition has dropped to around 3. He has faced disappointment in his football career and is struggling to make ends meet.

Kurt's condition has soared to 10, as he has achieved his lifelong goal of becoming a Super Bowl and MVP quarterback.

7. The list of protagonist's condition in chronological order is: [8, 8, 4, 3, 10].

8. Based on the protagonist's condition list, the story arc type is classified as "Double Man in a Hole." The reasoning behind this classification is that Kurt's condition starts relatively high, drops to a low point, recovers slightly, drops again, and then rises to an even higher point than the beginning. This matches the definition of the "Double Man in a Hole" story arc type, where the protagonist faces two cycles of dilemma and recovery.

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) The opening scene introduces us to Tom, the agile and seasoned automotive executive of Tesla.
2) He is cruising in his avant-garde cyber-truck along a solitary country road late at night after an executive summit.
3) Suddenly, the calm is disrupted by an unforeseen storm, blocking visibility and hampering maneuvering.
4) As Tom continues to battle the storm with his mechanical beast, a jagged and rusted iron spike emerges from the asphalt, rendering him stranded amidst the tempest.
5) Around him, he discerns the silhouette of a 19th-century Victorian mansion promising shelter like a beacon in a tempest.
6) Summoning his courage, Tom submits to the need of the hour.
7) He ventures into the looming shadow of the ominous mansion standing isolated in the tempest.
8) Pushing past the massive, gnarled oak doors, he steps into an eerily quiet interior.
9) He is greeted by a stooped old man named Sebastian, alone amidst the vast corridors and echoing spaces of the mansion.
10) Sebastian, with an unearthly equanimity, offers an invitation to Tom - to escape the wrath of the storm and claim sanctuary in the strangely silent mansion.
11) As he spends time inside the neglected mansion, Tom starts noticing inexplicable happenings.
12) His fascination replacing fear, Tom finds himself drawn towards a subterranean basement filled with ancient astronomical tools, star charts, and obscure sculptures.
13) Amidst the equipment, Tom discovers age-worn journals filled with indecipherable notes and illustrations.
14) As he delves deeper, he begins to comprehend an incredible tale spun within these pages - the past tenant's relentless pursuit of a disconcerting idea - a portal to reach alternate dimensions.
15) Tom's curiosity gets the better of him, and he inadvertently activates dormant machinery initiating sequences that have remained unstirred.
16) A hum, alien and vibrating, lights up the gloomy mansion, sending strange pulsations through the floors and walls.
17) The sudden burst of cosmic energy brings forth spectral apparitions, transforming the mansion into a whirlwind of paranormal phenomena.
18) Thrown into this maelstrom of disorder, Tom and Sebastian attempt to stand their ground.
19) They dive into the labyrinthine writings of the journals, desperate to discover a method to close the destructive interdimensional rift.
20) In the chaos, they decode one revelation from the journals.
21) They uncover faded photographs of the ambitious architect of the terrifying dimensional experiment who happened to be Tom's estranged grandfather - Dr. Edward Milford.
22) To Tom's shock, Sebastian confesses his stolen identity.
23) He was not merely an old man but a loyal aide to Dr. Milford.
24) Now, he is the unwilling torchbearer attempting to manage the aftermath of their scientific curiosity gone awry.
25) Under the shadows of impending doom, the pair, now bound by both blood and mission, grapple with restoring order.
26) They handle the ancient machinery with a newfound understanding, managing to close the destructive portal.
27) Emerging from the chaos, Tom finds himself a changed man.
28) He makes a solemn promise to himself - to decode his grandfather's cryptic messages, understand the experiments that cost him his life, and ensure the safety of the mansion.
29) The storm withdraws its ferocity, an eerie silence engulfs the mansion, signaling the end of Tom's supernatural encounter - the end of "Echoes in the Storm".
30) Tom is seen standing at the entrance of the mansion, the dawn horizon reflecting his firm resolution - a commitment to protect the mansion and polish his grandfather's legacy.

- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

- Change of Plans (tp2): 12.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 15.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 21.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 26.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:
### TASK RESPONSES

1. **Protagonist Identification**: The protagonist in the story is Tom, the agile and seasoned automotive executive of Tesla.

2. **First Turning Point (Opportunity)**: Sentence 5 - "Around him, he discerns the silhouette of a 19th-century Victorian mansion promising shelter like a beacon in a tempest."
   At this point, Tom's state is one of desperation and need for shelter from the storm. His condition can be approximated as a 2, considering he is stranded but has found potential shelter.

3. **Second Turning Point (Change of Plans)**: Sentence 12 - "His fascination replacing fear, Tom finds himself drawn towards a subterranean basement filled with ancient astronomical tools, star charts, and obscure sculptures."
   Relative to the first turning point, Tom's state has changed from seeking basic shelter to becoming intrigued and engaged with the mysterious aspects of the mansion. His condition improves to a 5 as he finds something interesting and is no longer just focused on survival.

4. **Third Turning Point (Point of No Return)**: Sentence 15 - "Tom's curiosity gets the better of him, and he inadvertently activates dormant machinery initiating sequences that have remained unstirred."
   Relative to the second turning point, Tom's state has changed from curiosity to taking action that leads to a significant event. His condition can be seen as improving to a 7 as he is now actively involved in uncovering the secrets of the mansion, though this action also introduces new risks.

5. **Fourth Turning Point (Major Setback)**: Sentence 21 - "They uncover faded photographs of the ambitious architect of the terrifying dimensional experiment who happened to be Tom's estranged grandfather - Dr. Edward Milford."
   Relative to the third turning point, Tom's state has changed from being actively engaged in the mystery to facing a personal and potentially disturbing revelation. His condition worsens to a 3 as he faces a shocking truth that complicates his understanding of himself and his family's past.

6. **Fifth Turning Point (Climax)**: Sentence 26 - "They handle the ancient machinery with a newfound understanding, managing to close the destructive portal."
   Relative to the fourth turning point, Tom's state has changed from facing a personal setback to achieving a significant success by resolving the main conflict. His condition improves to a 9 as he is able to overcome the challenges and find a resolution.

7. **Protagonist's Condition List**: [2, 5, 7, 3, 9]

8. **Story Arc Classification**: Based on the protagonist's condition list, the story arc can be classified as "Man in a Hole" because Tom starts in a relatively low state (stranded in a storm), improves his condition as he becomes engaged with the mystery of the mansion, faces a setback that worsens his condition, but ultimately achieves a much better state by resolving the conflict. The overall trajectory is one of improvement from the beginning to the end, with a significant dip representing the "hole" that the protagonist must climb out of.

3) However, a storm, later identified as a bomb cyclone, causes flights at the airport to be delayed, leaving Willa and Bill to reconnect.

5) Rose also wishes to be a dancer, which worries Bill.
6) Meanwhile, Willa plans to visit her friend Ginny, who is splitting up with her husband.
7) While Willa and Bill reminisce about their past relationship, it is revealed that Willa suffered a miscarriage while she was with Bill.
8) After Bill left, Willa had a little girl with a man who left as soon as he found out she was pregnant.
9) Willa later gave her daughter up for adoption, she was able to find the perfect parents, but Willa does not know where her daughter is now.
10) Bill mentions that he saw Willa a year prior while she was changing planes in Dallas, but Bill did not say anything to her, stating that she looked lost.
11) Bill obtains a hotel voucher, but is unable to reserve a room.
12) It is announced that Willa's flight to Boston is now boarding, but she ends up giving up her seat for a family.
13) Willa tries to give Bill her ticket after upgrading to first class, so he will not miss Rose's recital, as both Bill and Willa are “W.
14) Davis”.
15) Bill refuses.
16) Willa mentions that Beth-Anne called earlier while Bill was grabbing coffee to say that Rose does not want to stay with him, but with Beth-Anne instead for a few weeks.
17) Bill then takes the ticket, only for all flights to suddenly be suspended.
18) Rose calls Bill and Bill encourages her to try her best at dancing; earlier, Bill told Willa about how he had told Rose that she would not make it as a professional dancer, making her sad.
19) Willa tells Bill that she is actually going to Boston to meet her daughter.
20) Maggie, who just turned 20, called Willa and told her that she would like to meet.
21) Earlier, Willa, using Bill's phone, texted Maggie saying that she was not going to come.
22) Maggie then replied, telling Willa to just try, initially, this was seen as Willa texting Ginny.
23) The next day, all outbound flights are then announced to be departing shortly.
24) Willa gifts Bill with her rainstick and Bill gives Willa an old card, saying that he will write his number on the back.
25) They then exchange a kiss, before leaving to board their flights.
26) Willa turns Bill's card over, only to see that he only wrote "just try".
27) Willa and Bill exchange final gestures through the windows of their planes, which are parked next to each other.
28) Bill tries to sign his phone number to Willa, only for their flights to finally depart, as the contrails from the planes form a heart.

"Bill refuses."
However, the actual turning point is more closely related to Willa's actions in sentence 13: "Willa tries to give Bill her ticket after upgrading to first class, so he will not miss Rose's recital, as both Bill and Willa are “W. Davis”." 
At this point, Willa's state has improved slightly. She is showing kindness and generosity towards Bill, which suggests that she is beginning to heal and move forward. We can approximate Willa's condition as a 5 out of 10.

5. The sentence at the fourth turning point (Major Setback, tp4, sentence 17) is: 
"Bill then takes the ticket, only for all flights to suddenly be suspended."
At this point, Willa's state has taken another hit. Her plans are once again disrupted, and she is faced with uncertainty. This is a decrease in her condition, which we can approximate as a 3 out of 10.

6. The sentence at the fifth turning point (Climax, tp5, sentence 26) is: 
"Willa turns Bill's card over, only to see that he only wrote “just try”."
However, the actual climax is more closely related to Willa's realization and newfound hope in sentence 20: "Maggie, who just turned 20, called Willa and told her that she would like to meet." 
At this point, Willa's state has improved significantly. She has found closure and is given a new chance to connect with her daughter. We can approximate Willa's condition as an 8 out of 10.

7. The list of protagonist's conditions in chronological order is: [4, 2, 5, 3, 8]

8. Based on the protagonist's condition list, we can classify the story arc type as "Man in a Hole". The list shows a clear decrease in Willa's condition, followed by a gradual increase, and finally, a significant improvement. This pattern matches the "Man in a Hole" story arc type, where the protagonist falls into a dilemma and finds a way out, ending better than at the beginning.

9. Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Our film opens on the majestic panorama of the ancient land of Nowanus, a vast, desolate desert; so barren that life is little more than a struggle, yet resilient in its refusal to bow to the harsh elements.
2) The camera finds a family, a band of six hominids, living amongst this rugged land.
3) We are introduced to the eldest amongst them, a rugged individual named Tork.
4) The tribe has traditions, one of which we see during an elaborate ceremony under the clear night sky.
5) This vision details a grand journey, one leading towards the coy blush of the dawn’s horizon.
6) Encouraged by this great prophecy, the tribe sets forth, venturing from the familiarity of their home, placing their unwavering trust in their leader's revelation.
7) Their journey is a grueling one.
8) After days of relentless travel, their journey ends as they come upon a landscape that is as stunning as it is unexpected.
9) But their joy is short-lived as they notice something out of place upon this beautiful beachfront - an enormous, ancient fossil.
10) They aptly name it 'The Leviathan', the fossil of a sea creature so large and fearsome, they could only imagine it as a beast of cataclysmic proportions.
11) Their initial jubilation swiftly gives way to anxiety as they begin to fathom the complexities and potential dangers their new home presents.
12) Yet, they persist.
13) They may have arrived with uncertainty, but they resolve to make this unanticipated land of golden sand and limitless water their home.
14) They brace themselves for the unknown, armed only with their experience and instinct.
15) They acclimatize themselves to the coastal life, building sturdier shelters from driftwood, and making a collective effort to settle into this new land.
16) However, the peace is short-lived as they uncover the existence of another tribe living beyond their sight, beyond the horizon.
17) Soon, strange occurrences persistently plague the tribe.
18) These unsettling happenings slowly transform their serene beachfront life into a haunting riddle.
19) Confronted with these mysterious occurrences, Tork and the wise elders put their heads together.
20) With this revelation, the tribe is faced with two choices.
21) Flee and risk meeting another beast of unknown terror, or confront their fears and claim their future.
22) Tork, standing tall and resolute, suggests brokering peace with the unseen tribe.
23) He proposes that by facing this threat together, they have a better chance of surviving.
24) With survival as their common goal, the tribes put their differences aside and look towards a future of unity.
25) Together, they engineer an intricate strategy to confront the sea beast and reclaim their lives.
26) The day of the decisive battle arrives, and Tork leads the charge against the monstrous Leviathan.
27) Tork, drawing upon every ounce of his strength and courage, plunges his stone spear into the leviathan.
28) Their tribal chants shift to triumphant cheers as the formidable sea creature recoils, thrashing about in confusion and pain before sinking back into the sea's dark expanse.
29) The euphoria of victory is jarringly interrupted as the monstrous creature resurfaces, causing uproar and panic.
30) But the beast, shell-shocked by the attack, retreats into the deeper waters, shying away from the land.
31) It becomes evident that the Leviathan is more of a startled herbivore than a macabre predator.
32) It was a creature of survival, much like themselves.
33) The tribes, having gained a semblance of understanding of the Leviathan, decide to replace confrontation with coexistence.
34) They choose to live in harmony with the Leviathan, marking a significant step in their survival journey.
35) Both tribes accept and decide to inhabit the land together under the principle of mutual respect and unity.
36) Tork and the leader of the unseen tribe come to an understanding, agreeing to refrain from provoking the Leviathan and to live harmoniously in their newfound home.
37) The two tribes, initially rooted in basic survival needs, now transition into a life of collaboration and shared community responsibilities.
38) Amidst this newfound unity and peace, the sound of children's laughter and shouts of excitement fills the air, painting a lively tableau of everyday life along the serene coastline.
39) With the dawn of each day comes the humbling realization that their journey towards the rising sun was symbolic of their societal evolution.
40) Tork comprehends that his prophecy was about more than mere survival.
41) It was a pilgrimage towards unity, coexistence, and progression as a societal unit amidst trials, hardship, and fear.
42) The tribes have now evolved from a hardy survivalist lifestyle and graduated into a compassionate community, strengthening bonds and nurturing shared dreams.
43) They were now more than hunters.
44) They were lovers, friends, family.
45) These shared moments of joy, laughter, and camaraderie sculpted their society into a robust, unified tribe.
46) The sun rises from the horizon, its radiant dawn kissing their land with the promise of a new day.
47) The sun, which once guided their desperate search for a better home, now signifies the enduring unity and harmony achieved by this resolute tribe.
48) The tribes now understand that unity not only ensured survival but also paved the way for peace, prosperity, and societal progression.
49) Together, under the wide azure sky, they vow to live peacefully, fostering shared happiness and residing harmoniously amidst the picturesque landscape.
50) Their unity turns into a footprint for what was to be followed by the generations to come.
51) The tribes, once fractured by the struggle of survival, now present a united front.
52) They had not just survived but thrived amidst the trials, fear, and adversity.
53) The film concludes on an uplifted note, leaving the audience with a sunlit landscape resonating with laughter and celebratory dances.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

Ground Truth Turning Points:
- Opportunity (tp1): 6.0 - Introductory event that occurs after presenting the setting and background of the main characters.
- Change of Plans (tp2): 13.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 22.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 29.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 36.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:
### TASK RESPONSE

**1. Identify the protagonist in the story:**
The protagonist of the story is Tork, the eldest and leader of the tribe.

**2. First Turning Point (Opportunity, tp1): Sentence 6**
 Sentence 6: "Encouraged by this great prophecy, the tribe sets forth, venturing from the familiarity of their home, placing their unwavering trust in their leader's revelation."
 
 At this point, Tork and his tribe are filled with hope and anticipation for a better future, leaving behind the harsh conditions of their current home. The protagonist's condition can be approximated as a 4 out of 10, as they are hopeful but still uncertain and struggling.

**3. Second Turning Point (Change of Plans, tp2): Sentence 13**
 Sentence 13: "They may have arrived with uncertainty, but they resolve to make this unanticipated land of golden sand and limitless water their home."
 
 Relative to the first turning point, Tork and his tribe have now found a new land that offers better living conditions, and they decide to make it their home. This change signifies a positive shift in their situation, and the protagonist's condition can be approximated as a 6 out of 10, as they are more optimistic and have found a potential solution to their struggles.

**4. Third Turning Point (Point of No Return, tp3): Sentence 22**
 Sentence 22: "Tork, standing tall and resolute, suggests brokering peace with the unseen tribe."
 
 At this point, Tork and his tribe are faced with a new challenge (the unseen tribe) but decide to take a bold step towards peace and unity. This decision shows Tork's leadership and determination, and the protagonist's condition can be approximated as an 8 out of 10, as they are taking proactive steps towards a better future.

**5. Fourth Turning Point (Major Setback, tp4): Sentence 29**
 Sentence 29: "The euphoria of victory is jarringly interrupted as the monstrous creature resurfaces, causing uproar and panic."
 
 Relative to the third turning point, Tork and his tribe face a significant setback as the Leviathan resurfaces, causing panic and uncertainty. This event is a major obstacle, and the protagonist's condition can be approximated as a 3 out of 10, as they are faced with a new and daunting challenge.

**6. Fifth Turning Point (Climax, tp5): Sentence 36**
 Sentence 36: "Tork and the leader of the unseen tribe come to an understanding, agreeing to refrain from provoking the Leviathan and to live harmoniously in their newfound home."
 
 At this final turning point, Tork and his tribe have overcome their challenges and achieved a state of unity and coexistence with the unseen tribe and the Leviathan. The protagonist's condition can be approximated as a 10 out of 10, as they have achieved their goal of finding a better home and living in harmony.

**7. Protagonist's Condition List:**
 [4, 6, 8, 3, 10]

**8. Classify the story arc type based on the protagonist's condition list:**
 The story arc type can be classified as "Cinderella" because the protagonist's condition starts low (4), rises to a higher state (6 and 8), faces a significant setback (3), and ultimately achieves a much higher state (10). This pattern matches the Cinderella story arc, where the protagonist rises, faces a setback, and ultimately achieves a higher state.

**9. Determined Story Arc Type:**
 Cinderella

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) In Portland, Tim has a blind date with Melissa, nicknamed Missy, who turns out to be extremely strange, and her oddball behavior turns out to be both dangerous and disastrous.
2) Her wild antics force Tim to sneak out of the restaurant through a bathroom window, thereby dislocating his ankle.
3) Three months later, Tim bumps into a beautiful and successful woman (also named Melissa) at the airport.
4) They connect over drinks, finding out they have nearly everything in common and seem to be perfect for each other.
5) She gives him her number.
6) After a series of intimate texts, he eventually invites Melissa to his work retreat in Hawaii.
7) However, Missy shows up on the plane, and Tim realizes he had been texting the wrong Melissa the whole time.
8) The antics start again as Missy forcibly gives him a tranquilizer and, when he awakens, she is giving him a handjob.
9) On the corporate retreat in Hawaii, the new CEO, Jack Winstone, greets everyone at the welcome party.
10) When Missy makes an appearance, she is awkward and wild, and seems to always leave Tim in embarrassing situations in front of his boss and colleagues.
11) Back at their room, he awakens from another tranquilized state to her on top of him, riding him cowgirl style.
12) She often becomes reckless and intoxicated and her behavior humiliates Tim.
13) However, before too long, Missy starts to help Tim succeed at his work retreat, and even hypnotizes his boss to win his favor.
14) As they spend more time together, Tim eventually begins to fall for her.
15) His workplace competitor, Jess "the Barracuda", is not pleased when Winstone gives a job to Tim instead of her, so she reveals to Missy that her invitation was a mistake, and Tim had wanted to bring someone else.
16) When Missy checks Tim's phone, she finds out the truth.
17) Saddened and devastated, she leaves Hawaii.
18) However, at the moment Missy leaves in a cab, the actual Melissa arrives in Hawaii (having been invited by Jess).
19) At lunch, Tim begins acting outlandishly, much like Missy did on their first date, imbibing a bevy of alcoholic shots and then performing a walking handstand in the dining room.
20) After falling from the balcony and crippling himself, Tim lets the new Melissa know that he has developed feelings for Missy, and then departs Hawaii.
21) Back in the office, Tim decides to remove the hypnotic spell Missy put on his boss by uttering the obscene and obscure magic words.
22) His honesty results in him losing his job.
23) Tim tricks Missy into a date, where he plays the same trick that she had used on him.
24) Except she meets Vanilla Ice at the bar.
25) Tim comes up and apologizes to her and tells her he used to want someone exactly like him, but now realizes he doesn't.
26) He tells her all the things that he likes about her, and says that he wants to be more like her.
27) She forgives him, and they kiss.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

Ground Truth Turning Points:
- Opportunity (tp1): 1.0 - Introductory event that occurs after presenting the setting and background of the main characters.
- Change of Plans (tp2): 4.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 7.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 15.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 23.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:
### TASK RESPONSE

1. The protagonist in the story is Tim.

2. The first turning point (Opportunity) occurs at sentence 1: "In Portland, Tim has a blind date with Melissa, nicknamed Missy, who turns out to be extremely strange, and her oddball behavior turns out to be both dangerous and disastrous." 
   At this point, Tim is in a neutral state, but he is about to face a chaotic and disastrous situation due to Missy's behavior. His condition can be approximated as a 5.

3. The second turning point (Change of Plans) occurs at sentence 4: "They connect over drinks, finding out they have nearly everything in common and seem to be perfect for each other." 
   Relative to the first turning point, Tim's state has improved as he has connected with someone new and things seem to be going well. His condition can be approximated as an 8.

4. The third turning point (Point of No Return) occurs at sentence 7: "However, Missy shows up on the plane, and Tim realizes he had been texting the wrong Melissa the whole time." 
   Relative to the second turning point, Tim's state has taken a drastic turn for the worse as the wrong Melissa (Missy) has reappeared, and he is now in a difficult and awkward situation. His condition can be approximated as a 2.

5. The fourth turning point (Major Setback) occurs at sentence 15: "His workplace competitor, Jess "the Barracuda", is not pleased when Winstone gives a job to Tim instead of her, so she reveals to Missy that her invitation was a mistake, and Tim had wanted to bring someone else." 
   Relative to the third turning point, Tim's state had initially improved as he started to fall for Missy, but now things have fallen apart again due to Jess's revelation, and Missy has left. His condition can be approximated as a 1.

6. The fifth turning point (Climax) occurs at sentence 23: "Tim tricks Missy into a date, where he plays the same trick that she had used on him." 
   Relative to the fourth turning point, Tim's state has improved as he has taken action to win Missy back and eventually succeeds in getting her forgiveness and affection. His condition can be approximated as a 9.

7. The list of protagonist's condition in chronological order is: [5, 8, 2, 1, 9]

8. Based on the protagonist's condition list, the story arc type can be classified as "Man in a Hole" because the protagonist's condition initially worsens (5 to 2 to 1) but eventually improves significantly (1 to 9). The story follows a pattern where the protagonist faces a series of setbacks and difficulties but ultimately emerges in a much better state than at the beginning.

9. Man in a Hole

input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) The story unfolds with a picturesque view of Wall Street's towering skyscrapers, where our protagonists, Madison Carter and Noah Mitchell, are immersed in complex financial reports.
2) The scene transitions to display Madison and Noah at the heart of Two Peak Enterprises.
3) Their relationship, albeit business-oriented, is a vital component of the firm.
4) Despite the demands of their high-pressure jobs, the two manage to cultivate a budding romance.
5) Suddenly, a transaction of unprecedented proportions starts to shake the foundations of Two Peaks.
6) This billion-dollar deal begins to dominate the conversation, raising stakes across the financial landscape.
7) Madison and Noah's covert relationship comes under scrutiny.
8) There's a simultaneous tension between their fear of exposure and the stress of the impending billion-dollar deal.
9) In their analysis of the gargantuan deal, Madison and Noah identify a discrepancy that raises alarm bells.
10) They launch a secret investigation, delving furiously into the labyrinth of deception that infects the higher echelons of Two Peaks.
11) Their once-familiar office morphs into unwelcoming territory as unknown adversaries send chilling threats in response to their probing.
12) Their interpersonal bonds are tested further as they wrestle with a moral quandary surrounding their loyalty to their employer and their duty as conscientious citizens.
13) A new roadblock appears; an unexpected internal audit is announced at Two Peaks.
14) Madison and Noah escalate their investigation.
15) Their actions lead to an earth-shattering revelation: the very person they respected and emulated, their boss, is the puppeteer behind the corruption.
16) Upon the discovery of their boss's puppeteering, retaliation is swift and vicious.
17) A gripping chase ensues with Madison and Noah racing against time to secure irrefutable evidence of the crimes.
18) They manage to secure the valuable evidence necessary to expose their nefarious boss.
19) They take a moral stand, choosing their ethical responsibility over their coveted careers.
20) Armed with damning evidence, Madison and Noah confront their colleagues at Two Peaks' annual gala, unveiling their CEO's unscrupulous activities to an astounded audience.
21) Amid the chaos, a physical altercation erupts.
22) Madison and Noah courageously battle the onslaught to protect their evidence.
23) After the ordeal, they hand over their evidence to the authorities.
24) The downfall of Two Peak Enterprises sends shockwaves across Wall Street.
25) Madison and Noah, hailed as righteous heroes, decide to distance themselves from the aggressive world of finance.
26) The narrative closes with the couple embarking on a new life in a bucolic setting.
27) A note of suspense strikes as hints point at an omnipresent surveillance.
28) The screen pans to a computer monitor, with Two Peaks' now-defunct website displayed.
29) The narrative ends leaving a lasting sense of suspense.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

Ground Truth Turning Points:
- Opportunity (tp1): 5.0 - Introductory event that occurs after presenting the setting and background of the main characters.
- Change of Plans (tp2): 9.0 - Event where the main goal of the story is defined, starting the main action.
- Point of No Return (tp3): 13.0 - Event that pushes the main character(s) to fully commit to their goal.
- Major Setback (tp4): 15.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 20.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").
output:
### TASK RESPONSE

1. **Protagonist Identification**: The protagonists in the story are Madison Carter and Noah Mitchell.

2. **First Turning Point (Opportunity)**: Sentence 5 - "Suddenly, a transaction of unprecedented proportions starts to shake the foundations of Two Peaks."
   - **Protagonist's State**: At this point, Madison and Noah are introduced to a significant challenge that will test their abilities. They are still in a relatively secure position within their company but are faced with the uncertainty of this massive deal.
   - **Protagonist's Condition**: 8 (They are about to face a challenge but are still in a good position in their careers and have a budding romance.)

3. **Second Turning Point (Change of Plans)**: Sentence 9 - "In their analysis of the gargantuan deal, Madison and Noah identify a discrepancy that raises alarm bells."
   - **Change Relative to the First Turning Point**: This discovery shifts their focus from merely navigating the challenges of the deal to investigating potential wrongdoing within their company. Their situation becomes more complex and potentially risky.
   - **Protagonist's Condition**: 6 (Their situation becomes more precarious as they begin to uncover discrepancies, putting them at odds with potential adversaries within the company.)

4. **Third Turning Point (Point of No Return)**: Sentence 13 - "A new roadblock appears; an unexpected internal audit is announced at Two Peaks."
   - **Change Relative to the Second Turning Point**: This internal audit increases the pressure on Madison and Noah, pushing them to escalate their investigation. They are now more committed to uncovering the truth, despite the increased danger.
   - **Protagonist's Condition**: 5 (Their situation worsens with the announcement of the internal audit, making their investigation more urgent and risky.)

5. **Fourth Turning Point (Major Setback)**: Sentence 15 - "Their actions lead to an earth-shattering revelation: the very person they respected and emulated, their boss, is the puppeteer behind the corruption."
   - **Change Relative to the Third Turning Point**: Discovering their boss's corruption is a significant setback because it means Madison and Noah are directly opposing the most powerful person in the company. This revelation puts them in a dangerous position.
   - **Protagonist's Condition**: 3 (This revelation marks the lowest point for Madison and Noah, as they realize the extent of the corruption and the danger they are in.)

6. **Fifth Turning Point (Climax)**: Sentence 20 - "Armed with damning evidence, Madison and Noah confront their colleagues at Two Peaks' annual gala, unveiling their CEO's unscrupulous activities to an astounded audience."
   - **Change Relative to the Fourth Turning Point**: By confronting their colleagues and exposing the corruption, Madison and Noah take control of their situation and achieve a significant victory, despite the risks.
   - **Protagonist's Condition**: 9 (They have successfully exposed the corruption and are hailed as heroes, but the aftermath of their actions and the transition to a new life may still hold challenges.)

7. **Protagonist's Condition List**: [8, 6, 5, 3, 9]

8. **Story Arc Classification**: This story follows the **Man in a Hole** arc because the protagonists start in a relatively good position, face challenges that worsen their condition, hit a low point, and then recover to achieve a better state than at the beginning. The protagonist's condition improves from the first turning point to the last, after facing a significant setback.

9. **Determined Story Arc Type**: Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each turning point. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Tom Harper, renowned as a capable engineer, has found his calling in merging his love for automobiles into a successful occupation.
2) Running a thriving car dealership, he shares this venture and life's numerous pleasures and difficulties with his remarkably driven wife, Sarah.
3) Their blissful existence unfolds against the pristine backdrop of Selton, a charmingly serene middle-class suburban neighborhood.
4) This tight-knit community, with its verdant greenery, white picket fences, and friendly faces, is home to their trio of sparkling-eyed children; Lily, whose beautifully nimble fingers vividly bring alive any piano composition, Samuel who dominates lacrosse fields, and Zac, their youngest, whose infectious smile can brighten even the gloomiest of days.
5) Everything seemed to follow a picturesque rhythm till one unusually warm Wednesday.
6) Tom noticed a large, luminously painted moving van blocking their once-tranquil street.
7) The van, plastered with cheerful imagery and parked in front of the Victorian style house next door, caused Tom a hint of anxiety.
8) Lo and behold, this anxiety magnified into a feeling of discomfort and dread once he discovered that the new occupants of the neighboring house were none other than his high school nemesis, Dan.
9) A former local football legend, Dan had always been known for his cocksure attitude and reputation for thriving in rivalries.
10) Every casual interaction with Dan since then seemed soaked with an underlying animosity.
11) Be it chance meetings at parental school functions or during the neighbor's backyard barbeque get-togethers, their conversations were invariably simmering with unsaid rivalry, hidden behind false smiles and forced laughter.
12) More disconcertingly, Tom comes to realize that Dan's return isn't merely a personal upset, but also a professional threat.
13) Dan, now a dealer specializing in coveted, high-end luxury vehicles, was not-hesitating to indirectly disparage and undermine Tom’s hard-earned business reputation.
14) This festering relationship with Dan didn't just perturb Tom.
15) It left him in a precarious spot when Dan began employing underhanded tactics, such as disseminating malicious rumors about Tom’s professional credibility, to sabotage his business.
16) Feeling progressively cornered by the unpleasant circumstances, Tom finally confided in Sarah during a quiet, reflective conversation over a peaceful evening embellished with their favorite coffee.
17) Sarah, erudite, and shrewd, proposed a strategical approach to counteract these swirling controversies.
18) She drew up a plan to host a grand neighborhood car show, a casual gathering yet a serious platform to showcase Tom's diverse and impressive array of vintage and modern vehicles.
19) Thrilled yet anxious, the couple decided to use the pride of Selton, the Faith Park, a shared open space in the heart of their community, as the venue for this ambitious event.
20) Parallelly, as the car show preparations brewed, Tom and Dan's petty antagonisms escalated during casual neighborhood gatherings.
21) Their constant one-upmanship, which began as minor, harmless jabbing, started taking on more worrying undertones.
22) Confronting and gradually overcoming this opposition had an overpoweringly positive effect on Tom.
23) It steeled his resolve and strengthened his courage to weather any adverse winds that Dan seemed determined to conjure and blow his way.
24) Finally, the much-awaited day of the car show dawned, albeit with ominous rain clouds roiling the sky.
25) To add to the mounting stress, their star attraction, a suave 1930 Ford Model A Roadster, was nonchalantly refusing to start.
26) Fearful for his professional image and credibility, Tom spent the morning under the temperamental car in a makeshift garage.
27) With the determination of a warrior, armed with tools as his weapons, he warred with the Roadster's obstinacy.
28) Amidst this electrifying chaos, baby Zac suddenly vanished.
29) A wave of panic washed over the Harpers as they frantically began looking for their youngest.
30) As it turns out, the little one was found cozily snuggled asleep inside the plush leather seats of a cherry-red 1957 Chevrolet Bel Air.
31) This discovery resulted in collective sighs of relief and subsequent laughter rippling through the family.
32) With all minor mishaps resolved, and the stubborn rain deciding to stay at bay, the Harpers finally kick-started their car show.
33) It turned into a fanfare of beautiful automobiles ranging from an imposing Rolls Royce Phantom to an agelessly charming Volkswagen Beetle.
34) Amidst all the glitz and gasps of awe, what stood out was Tom's impressive command over automobiles.
35) His expertise clearly overshadowed the petty, underhanded tactics that Dan had engaged in, affirming Tom's status as Selton's undisputed autophile.
36) The success story of the day was the unanticipated support and acceptance from the community.
37) This overwhelming display of solidarity promptly dismissed Dan's attempts at sabotage and heartened a now-relieved Tom.
38) This realization and reaffirmation of his credibility and position galvanized Tom's self-confidence.
39) It helped him understand that his authentic passion, practical knowledge, and deep domain understanding were invaluable competencies that set him apart in the industry.
40) In a surprising twist of the narrative, the once-ruthless Dan openly admitted his wrongdoings and praised Tom on his unparalleled collection, conceding defeat over his own luxury line-up.
41) His unexpectedly candid and humble admittance was the finishing touch to the success of the car show, bringing a sense of closure and redemption to the narrative.
42) As the days rolled into weeks, the neighborhood transformed as the bricks of antagonism fell apart.
43) It was replaced by a bloom of improved relations and a shared sense of harmony.
44) The metaphorical picket fences that had sprung up between the red brick houses and bespoke maple-lined streets of Selton had, at last, vanished.
45) Reflecting on the event, Tom recognized his triumph was not in trouncing Dan, but in the growing closeness within his family, and the strength of their relationship with their supportive neighbors.
46) The closing scene elegantly captures Selton at dusk, with twinkling fairy lights adorning the entire neighborhood, mirroring the canopy of glistening stars overhead.
47) The Harper family, stronger than ever, looked towards this future, filled with hope and excitement.
48) Their journey, undeniably difficult, had ultimately been one of collective growth and unity.
49) As fading laughter and lingering cheers accompanied a warm sense of fulfillment, the narrative underscored the fundamental values of unity, camaraderie, resilience, and the power to navigate and overcome adversities.
50) The realization that their resilience and community support far overshadowed any vendetta brought a new perspective to their lives.
51) It was a framework much stronger and more uplifting than what they had believed possible.
52) Thus, the warmly twinkling lights of Selton faded out, leaving behind an elegant tapestry of suburban life - whimsical, joyful, and infinitely stronger together.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

Ground Truth Turning Points:

- Major Setback (tp4): 28.0 - Event where things fall apart temporarily or permanently.
- Climax (tp5): 33.0 - Final event/resolution of the main story (the "biggest spoiler").

1. **Identify the protagonist in the story**: The protagonist in the story is Tom Harper.

2. **First Turning Point (Opportunity)**: Sentence 8 - "Lo and behold, this anxiety magnified into a feeling of discomfort and dread once he discovered that the new occupants of the neighboring house were none other than his high school nemesis, Dan."

Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Our story begins in the meticulously cataloged lab of renowned scientist, Dr. Aiden Baxter.
2) His life’s work and passion is centered around his revolutionary exploration drones, dubbed 'Galactinauts.'
3) These semi-autonomous creations are twice as large as any other existing drones, equipped with cutting-edge technology designed to probe the depths of space.
4) The metallic sterile environment of his workspace is masked by the clutter of papers filled with jotted equations, blueprints of drones, and complex diagrams of distant galaxies.
5) Tools penning his most recent drone modifications lie strewn about, showcasing Aiden's relentless pursuit of understanding the cosmos.
6) A memorable, black and white photograph of his two children, an adventurous boy and a thoughtful girl, sits encased in a simple wooden frame.
7) Set under a sprawling LED monitor that displays the interface of various planetary systems, the picture provides a warm contrast, humanizing the cold cosmos, reminding him of his past as a loving father.
8) The dichotomy of his life is explicit.
9) On one hand, Aiden is consumed with his ambitious scientific progression; on the other, he grapples with the guilt of parting ways with his family and his strained relationships.
10) This delicate balance is disrupted when a glaring screen-switch disrupts the silence, flashing "Drone 45: System Failure."
11) The haunting red light permeates across the room, illuminating the dim isolation, serving as a harbinger of the precarious status of his project.
12) Aiden is under unrelenting pressure from the stern Science Council.
13) Their cold, businesslike voices often echo in his lab during the recurrent video conferences.
14) Recent warnings about withdrawal of funding - an ominous threat - plague his thoughts and compound his concern.
15) His groundbreaking project hangs in the balance, threatening to cease completely under the weight of financial restraints, sending Aiden into a state of internal turmoil and newfound fear.
